description:
You know how sometimes you check out a place to find out what the hype is about but then get let down?  This is NOT the case when checking out Salt & Straw.  I freaking LOVED my visit here.

Let me be completely blunt :  There is a LONG line when you get there.  The line extends outside... where SF weather can try to blow you away, or the nasty bus & street smells can chase you away.  BUT don't be discouraged!!! The line moves at a pretty good pace and they post their menu on the windows so you're ready when it's finally your turn.

The workers are AMAZING.  Every single one of them has such enthusiasm and patience.  It's as if they know you were waiting in line for errmm... maybe 20 min or more and are hoping you forgive them by being so kind and lively.  (Which yes, I forgive!!!).  I definitely appreciate the questions they ask you and knowledge they give you.  

The flavors I fell in LOVE with:
- Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches
- Salted, Malted, Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough

There really are no words to describe these flavors except DELICIOUS.  I have never had ice cream this grand anywhere else.  They are even great together (which I shared with my bf, of course).  The waffle bowl is a smart pairing as well. 

I'm pretty happy Salt & Straw made its way to NorCal and am hoping for the day it finds a home in my side of the bay.
author: Rossel C.

description:
This Portland import was a highly anticipated opening in SF last year and was such a successful one, that there are now two locations in SF and two other locations opening in the Bay Area.

No wonder fans are crazy about Salt & Straw, this is interesting ice cream that always keeps you on your toes with its rotating flavors, insanely delicious and sources local ingredients and works with artisanal vendors. 

What can I say that hasn't been said? yes, there's always a line. You will have to wait for your turn since the staff are trained to fully explain flavors/products to customers and give them as much free samples as requested. (this is the real reason for the long lines!)

I refuse to wait in long lines so the couple of times I've been here happen by chance, usually when I'm hopping off the #22 bus line or friends wanted to come here and there were only 2 people ahead of us.

Every month Salt & Straw releases 4-5 different flavors highlighting nature's best: summer saw a lot of berries and cheeses, spring brought floral flavors, fall is always exciting because of Halloween (Dracula's blood pudding? candytopia? no pumpkin spice anything in sight, Starbucks can keep that!) and winter usually retains more the familiar flavors like their classic Sea Salt with caramel ribbons or Sightglass Coffee. 

A few seasonal standouts to me have been the roasted strawberries and coconut. This was an intense expression of the pure fruit. Literally, you could taste nothing but fresh strawberries mixed with coconut milk (vegans rejoice!) and I remember this from last year because SF also hit 100+ degrees and in a decade of living in fog filled SF, this was quite unheard of. Another weird flavor was the smoked bone marrow with cherries. It left me feeling odd as I do typically like that combination, but in ice cream form, it was just that: strange.

On the next warm SF day (ha!) I'd most likely get the honey lavender or the Organic Root's Arbequina Olive Oil. You should try those if you haven't!

I'm not sure I can justify paying more than $7 for a single scoop of ice cream with an extra topping and freshly made waffle cone all the time. (nor could my waistline take the abuse) I like it very much when I do have t, but I'm not crazy about it. How come Bi-Rite or Humphrey Slocumbe aren't as overpriced?
author: Janice C.

description:
I lived in Oregon for 4 years while in college so I had the privilege to know Salt & Straw before they opened in San Francisco. 

I was very excited to find out that Salt & Straw had opened in San Francisco so I went with my girlfriend to try it out. 

It was absolutely delicious just like the one in Oregon. My favorite flavor is the classic salty caramel.
author: Daniel B.

description: My favourite ice cream chain! I always recommend honey lavender with ANYTHING else you match it with. There is always a line but it goes pretty fast. I love how there are so many creative and seasonal flavours that each time I go back, I get to try something new. It's also great that they don't rush you when you are choosing or trying flavours. AWESOME!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Came here on Labor Day with a few of our friends and it was my fiancé's and I's first time. I got the matcha black raspberry and that is SOOO GOOD!! I want to go back to get more of it! There needs to be a Salt & Straw in the East Bay Area, haha. 

The service was truly friendly and attentive- making sure that we are helped and served. I really need to go back :)!
author: Trina R.

description:
I knew I loved Salt & Straw the moment I smelt it (which was 2 blocks away on Muni)! And I loved it even more once I tried it. 

They love to let you sample everything, so don't be shy! After doing my own taste testing, my favorite ice cream is the Honey Lavender Ice Cream with Caramel and Whipped Cream on top. 

And I highly recommend getting a waffle cone as they are famous for their delicious waffles.

The reason for the missing star is that I find $7 very expensive to pay for a single scoop of ice cream with toppings.
author: Sydney G.

description:
On a cold and Foggy Monday night (Typical San Francisco Summer night!) we headed over to Salt & Straw for a sweet treat.

One would think nobody would be out for Ice Cream on such a cold night.

Wrong

The line at S&S was out the door. And for good reason their Ice Cream is magnificent. 

This is my second Salt and Straw to go to; the other being in Hayes Valley. And I must admit the consistency of quality is fantastic. Both locations have wonderful service and fantastic Ice cream.

The flavors are just so subtle and delicious I am drooling thinking about my Carrot Cake batter with praline Hazelnuts....god it was good. 

The texture is rich and creamy not too dense nor overly sweet.

If you are in the neighborhood go...the line moves quickly!

P.S. They will let you sample everything!!!   Just sayin
author: David G.

description:
The ice cream at Salt & Straw is really good; perhaps the best I've had in San Francisco.

This is a chain from Portland with two locations in SF. This store in Pacific Heights opened in April 2017 and another location opened 6 months later, less than 2 miles away, in Hayes Valley in October 2017. At the time of writing this review, there are 15 locations across the West Coast. 

What differentiates Salt & Straw from the competition is its wide variety of high quality and unique ingredient and flavor combinations. In this sense, it reminds me a lot of Jeni's Splendid Ice Creams from where I'm from (most of Jeni's locations are in the Midwest and South). When we visited, Salt & Straw offered 13 classic flavors like Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache and Black Olive Brittle & Goat Cheese plus 5 special guest chef collaboration flavors like Duck Crackling with Cherry Preserves and Ras el Hanout & Pickled Rose Petal Jam (ras el hanout is a North African spice mix). The chefs hailed from cities where there is a Salt & Straw location. The chef collaboration flavors change monthly. All of Salt & Straw's ice cream flavors are handmade in small batches using seasonal, local ingredients.

A handful of flavors have direct ties to Bay Area local businesses such as Sightglass Coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate and Berkeley Olive Grove's Olive Oil. I'm not sure if these are SF exclusives or if they're available at all Salt & Straw locations.

I sampled a few flavors including Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons, Honey Lavender, and Chocolate Gooey Brownie. All of the flavors were terrific. I experienced immediate satisfaction as soon as each flavor hit my mouth. It made deciding which flavor to order difficult. My friend and I settled on scoops of Salted Malted Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough and Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches, both classic flavors. They were excellent. The Salted Malted Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough was rich and creamy with delectable, chewy chunks of cookie dough and sweet fudge swirls. The Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches tasted like a wonderful strawberry cake with a yummy strawberry jam. This flavor is made with Oxnard strawberries from the Oxnard Plain in Southern California. In general, all of the flavors I tried were nice and bold and very comforting.

Prices during our visit were as follows:

Ice cream
* Single scoop (tennis ball size) - $5
* Double scoop (tennis ball size) - $7
* Kids scoop (golf ball size) - $4
* Split scoop (1 scoop, 2 flavors) - $0.50 extra
* Tasting flight (4 kids scoops) - $11
* Pint - $11

Extras
* Waffle cone - $1.25
* Hot fudge, caramel, whipped cream, hazelnuts - $1 each
* Finishing salt, sprinkles - $0.50 each

They also offer sundaes ($8.50 each), floats ($7.75), and whole-pint milkshakes ($10.50). These are "gourmet" ice cream prices and pretty much what you should expect for ice cream of this caliber (higher end), especially in the city. We visited just before 8pm on a Friday and a small line had already built up inside. The line moved pretty fast, however, even with customers sampling.  My friend and I went through the line, sampled, and got our orders in only 7 minutes. Speedy.

The staff was helpful, friendly, and efficient.

The shop is at the corner of Fillmore and Sacramento (entrance on Fillmore) with very limited seating inside (counters against the storefront windows) and a small bench outside. Complimentary self-serve water is available just inside the entrance.

TL;DR - For great ice cream in San Francisco, I recommend this place.
author: Daniel B.

description:
This was my fourth time coming to this place today. I asked for a single scoop split and was charged for the double scoop. The cashier wasnt friendly in terms of letting me know that i was given double scoop. 

They just lost a loyal customer who lives only couple of blocks away and was not treated nicely. Terrible customer experience today.
author: Surbhi K.

description:
Unique flavors.

What I tried:
*Mint Techo-colate chip
*Jasmine green tea
*One of my favorite flavors was something I tried in portland(will update when I find out what the flavor was called)

Overall thoughts:
*Something for everyone, whether you want to be simple or want to try some unique flavors 

*Personally think a kid scoop is enough Ice cream 

*Not a lot of seats in this location 

*You can expect a line on a warm day  

*Good service, don't forget to sample before ordering!
author: Sarah W.

description:
Salt & straw is the best ice cream in the city.

The Chocolate Brownie Sundae at this place is awesome! 

Try it :)
author: Alec H.

description:
Another ice cream spot that opens in SF. They're all starting to be the same. Looking cute and offering original and unique flavors...but really, it's presentation. This locale used to be Jamba Juice and then some earthy juice bar that was nasty back a few years ago. 

Ordered an almond brittle with ganache on a waffle cone. It was ok, nothing jaw-dropping delicious. Generous serving of a single scoop but damn it was expensive. I bought 3 scoops, one for myself, my daughter and her boyfriend. Twenty bones. Uh...yeah, no. I'd still choose Mitchell's anyday.
author: Sharon B.

description:
Solid ice cream place with some interesting flavors. We got a split single scoop ($5.50) with Honey Lavender and Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough. I would happily consume these flavors again, or try new ones. 

It costs $.50 to split a scoop. A split single scoop ($5.50) = 2 kid scoops (2 different flavors). A split double scoop ($7.50) = 1 large single scoop and 2 kid size scoops (3 different flavors). A kid scoop is $4. So if you are planning to get a kid scoop, it's much cheaper to share a split single or split double with a friend!
author: Julia C.

description:
Pros: excellent customer service, free samples, great options and combinations, and unique flavors!

Cons: long lines and wished I had more ice cream!

I ordered an ice cream with Jasmine Blossom Milk Tea and Chocolate and Rhubarb Crumble with Toasted Anise, and I enjoyed both very much because it was not sweet and had lots of yummy flavors!
author: Claire G.

description:
Probably one of the best ice cream spots in SF, hands down. And, I've made my rounds. My girlfriend has been begging me to take her to a Salt & Straw ever since they opened in SF - she loves her unique ice cream flavors. I used to be happy with just vanilla before moving to SF. 

Instead of sharing, we ordered 2 single scoops in a cup. She opted for the Tokyo PB&J, and I got the sea salt and caramel ribbons. Both were like nothing I've ever tasted before. The flavors are perfectly paired, unique, and so memorable. The ice cream is handmade, and you can tell. It's creamy, soft, and the perfect texture. There's nothing like salt and straw between the texture and flavor, although bi rite is a close second. I think salt & straw wins with their variety of unique and "limited edition" flavors. 

Don't be discouraged by the line. It moves really quickly. The staff are friendly, and they are cool with samples as long as it doesn't hold up the line. I liked that the shop was spacious and not like your typical SF ice cream shop. There were even places to sit! 

Will I be back? Hell yes for unique ice cream flavors!
author: Ashley S.

description:
Great ice cream but arguably some of the worst customer service I encountered in a long time,and this is coming from someone who has been in retail management for 25 years .Every person behind the counter looked like they truly hated their job and the service I got backed up that impression.I asked for a couple of samples to help me decide.The counter person handed them to me,with absolutely no life or personality whatsoever in the interaction.Then when I made my choices and got to the register to pay,I was asked if I wanted a bag,and when I said yes please, I was handed the bag to bag it myself.When the clerk finished swiping my card,she just handed it back to me and walked away.No "thank you",nothing!

Note to management...invest a little time and money in teaching your employees some basic customer service skills,so it at least looks like they care.Customers shouldn't have to receive this kind of service,especially for the prices you charge!
author: Jason P.

description:
First time I had Salt n Straw was in Portland. I've been to both location there. It was a great treat to have! Served at the perfect temperature where the ice cream isn't frozen hard nor is it to the point where it is melting and dropping.

On opening day the line was out the door AND around the corner. Pretty busy but the line moved fairly quickly. The moment we were in the store, we were greeted well and asked to try some samples. Unfortunately I dont remember her name but she was very nice and genuine about allowing us to try virtually all the flavors. In the end, I went with the roasted strawberry tres leches in a waffle cone.

SO GOOD. MUST GET or you could just sample it and let everyone know how great it is. 



Update! Olive oil lemon custard my go to!
author: Wesley L.

description:
For a birthday treat, one of my coworkers got ice cream. (For some reason, she doesn't like cake, so that was out.) I believe we got our delivery order through Postmates as no one wanted to actually go to the location to pick it up. Our dessert arrived on Tuesday, April 24th around 3:15pm.

*Rose & lavinder patels
*Honey lavender
*Berkeley olive grove olive oil
*Sea salt with caramel ribbons
*Sightglass coffee & single origin dandelion chocolate

I first had Salt & Straw when I went to Portland, so I was excited to try the flavors offered in San Francisco. Out of the ones above, I tried the Rose and Honey lavender. (I'm not much of a sweet and salty person or a chocolate person.) The rose texture was more like a sherbet and kind of reminded me of strawberry. The honey lavender was creamier, so I actually liked that one more as I wanted something that resembled typical ice cream. Also, I'm not a huge honey fan, so I was glad it wasn't too strong here.

Happy I finally tried the Salt & Straw in SF. Though my favorite flavor in Portland was the scotch one, so I hope they bring it here. I do like my scotch.
author: Elena N.

description:
not my first time at Salt &straw. I initially went to one of their locations in LA, but didn't think much of it. Maybe it was the flavor selections? I know each location has different menus that are catered to that area. their limited editions are what draws me. I went to portland last November and since that's where they started, i felt obligated. that's when i couldn't get enough of it. the quality hasn't changed since the first time I tried it. But while in portland, i've had it maybe.....2 times on the same day. haha. guilty. but it was so good, even though i didn't go with their seasonal/ limited edition thanksgiving flavors. 

ANYWAYS. Specifically for this location and experience. Their limited edition flavors really caught my eye. i've always been a fan of floral flavored scents and taste. they had two in particular that I wanted to try since they are only available for the month of April. I got the Spring Flower Cream and the rose/ lavender petals. these two are sooooo good! I probably wouldn't recommend getting both together because the rose/ lavender is more of a sorbet, whereas the other is more of a cream base. definitely different and unique. i really enjoyed them!   the flavors are enhanced enough, but not overpowering to where you can't finish.
author: Audrey K.

description:
Best ice cream. Worth the wait in line.
I was hoping to have their famous peach ice cream that I had heard so much about. But that wasn't on the menu. Other delight-full  flavors were on the menu. Olive oil ice cream? Yes! It was amazing. And their strawberry ice cream is also an amazing . I can't wait to taste their Thanksgiving selection.
author: Jaleh B.

description:
Happy that Salt & Straw migrated to California. This location is ALWAYS busy but I only come during the weekends. There is usually a long line that wraps around the corner...and it's totally worth it. They change their monthly specials menu and their flavors are quite unique. The staff are welcoming and are experts at what are local favorites and what are favs among the staff as well.

Tasting flights. A good choice if you're interested in sampling multiple flavors and sharing with a group or another person. Their pints to-go are pricy, but people DO purchase them... I know I have! Their signature sea salt w/ caramel ribbons is a winner and their roasted strawberry tres leches is also a winner. With Salt & Straw and Smitten literally just a couple blocks away, it's hard to choose where to go. But for now, Salt & Straw has my heart and my stomach. Oh and my wallet too.
author: Debby N.

description: I've been wanting to come here forever! Came here after work for a sweet treat, and I wasn't disappointed. I probably sampled over half the menu before I finally made my decision, and everything I tried was so good! Probably the most unique flavor I tried was the cheese and baguette (not bad, but also not my favorite flavor). I finally settled on a waffle cone with the chocolate chip cookie dough and the seasonal carrot cake. The cookie dough has that nostalgic flavor, and the carrot cake was full of cinnamon, fresh carrot shreds, and great crunch from walnuts. What also sets it over the top is the swirls of cream cheese frosting running throughout! Loved my ice cream, and I can't wait to come back and try some of the other flavors!
author: Rachel D.

description:
Parking 
Haha! None. Good luck with finding street parking
Location
I became familiar with this place in Oregon and was so delighted to discover they opened up one in the Bay Area! One of my best friends lives right down the street from it so everytime I visit- we are stopping here!  
Service 
Don't be alarmed with the line out the door. It moves pretty quickly. As a bonus, someone will ask you what flavors your like to sample as you wait so by the time you reach the front, you know what you want. It was great! 
Flavors
So many cool flavors to choose from! I ended up getting the strawberry tres leches- sooo good! 
Price 
Yup, pricey but worth it 
Overall
Plan on coming back next time I'm in the area! Mmmm life is too short not to have amazing ice cream
author: Elisha P.

description:
Salt & Straw is always a classic, and with many locations open in the city, it is slowly becoming my new go-to ice cream place in SF.  

I got a single scoop of the Sightglass coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate in a cone. This flavor never disappoints (it's my go-to flavor haha), and I like how local companies were involved in the making of this flavor (and many other flavors as well). 

I tried their olive oil flavor, and it was so light and refreshing!
author: Tiffany H.

description: Never ending patience and smiles here. They let me sample everything I wanted and more. I first chose chocolate brownie and Essence of Ghost (ha!) but changed my mind on the Ghost after a few bites (tastes like whiskey). I went back in line to purchase a honey lavender scoop and they were so gracious they just gave me the replacement scoop free of charge. They earned my loyalty for life.
author: Priscilla T.

description:
There are so many options for ice cream in SF, but you can't go wrong with Salt & Straw if you are nearby!

I happened to be shopping around Fillmore Street on a sunny afternoon when I noticed there was a tiny line inside and saw my opportunity! I strolled in and was shortly thereafter greeted by a friendly employee who told me that I could try as many flavors as I wanted. I tried a bunch and settled on her favorite, the Dandelion chocolate hazelnut cookies & cream. It just so happens to be vegan and gluten free, but it tastes just as rich and decadent as other flavors. I got a single scoop with a sugar cone. It was a pretty generous scoop and I am thinking I could go for the kids size next time, so as to not ruin my appetite for dinner.

Overall, delicious and high quality options for flavors and excellent customer service. Would recommend!
author: Roya B.

description:
Extremely busy location, especially  during the week end,  but it's definitely worth it! 
We tried the chocolate fudge and was to die for, you know what you are eating, I mean, it really tasted of rich chocolate ( not just sugar as often happens when I try to enjoy an ice cream in the area) the cone was crispy, tasty, delicious.
Yes, it is definitely pricey, but you can also tell that it's a great quality product, so for me, totally worth it.
author: Michelle C.

description: We were taking a stroll around the block of salt & straw and didn't have ice cream on our minds. Standing at a red light across from this shop was enough to drive our attention to the mouth watering aroma of the freshly made waffles. In the next second we were in this shop and tried a bunch of samples and finally ordered the chocolate gooey fudge and honey lavender ice cream. Both were extremely good especially with the waffle bowl. Must try!
author: Akshat G.

description: Hands down the best ice cream you will find in San Francisco. The inventive flavors which change every time you go are so interesting. The staff are very nice and encourage you to taste all different flavors. The ice cream is very fresh and there is always a vegan option! Can't wait to go back
author: Ruchi M.

description: I had this on a flight to Hawaii and then had to seek it out again.  Might be one of my favorite ice creams because even their simple vanilla is amazing (something I have not said since I was a small child).  There are plenty of fancy ice cream places in SF that are all about the show or a gimmick.  This is a company that decided to be all about the product and that's exactly what you want when you are splurging on ice cream.
author: Sallie P.

description:
I've been to the locations in SoCal, but this was my first time visiting a location up in NorCal. My party came here for dessert after dinner around 9pm and there was still a decent line out the door. The line wrapped around the store and we waited for about 20min before we got to the front of the line.

This place has a lot of really unique flavors. On top of that, they do seasonal flavors too. Since it's close to Valentine's day, the theme was around chocolate, so most of their seasonal flavors were chocolate-related. One thing that I also love about Salt & Straw is that you can technically try as many flavors as you want before making a decision. I tend to be somewhat indecisive when it comes to picking flavors, so I really appreciate being able to try different ones before I make up my mind. 

I think I ended up trying 5-6 flavors before I decided to get one of the seasonal flavors - Dick Taylor's Black Fig and Madagascar Chocolate. It sounds exotic but it's actually a good flavor because the tartness of the fig actually matches really well with the chocolate taste (the slight bitterness when you eat dark chocolate). Even though each scoop is $5, you get a HUGE scoop. I definitely recommend sharing with someone. You are able to get the ice cream in a cup or in a sugar cone, which is free. Or you can upgrade to a waffle cone for an additional $1.25. 

Definitely one of the more popular ice cream places around town that is worth the wait, especially because of all the unique flavors they offer!
author: Nina W.

description:
Pretty pretty good...I get the hype

I tried the popular Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons but it was a bit much for me (typically don't like Sea Salt with choco etc but maybe it's for you)

Settled on :
Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches- Yumm....
Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache- Super good as well. 

Definitely lived up to the hype and the service was very friendly. One thing that I realized that they didn't ask that I appreciate  from other venues is which flavor I wanted "on top". Definitely not necessary, but it  a nice touch that some of the other local "notable" competitors ask . 

Good experience would return , they are # 5 in my rankings below. 

So many good ice cream spots in the city. Here is my ranking but they are all pretty darn good.

Who doesn't love Chocolate and Ice Cream? (If you're raising your hand you can stop here ) 

I like making lists what can I say. I have lists for Ramen, Steakhouse/Brazilian , Milk Tea, Egg Tarts, Chicken & Waffles (super random list right). Give my profile a follow if you like them. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings. 

Rod's San Francisco Chocolate and Ice Cream shop Rankings: 
1 Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous
2 Marco Polo Gelato
3 Dandelion Chocolate
4 Polly Ann Ice Cream
5 salt and straw
6 Chocolate Covered
7 Smitten Ice Cream
8 Teuscher Chocolate 
9 Humphry Slocombe Ice Cream
10 Over the Moon
11 The Ice Cream Bar
12 Coletta Gelato
13 Cako Creamery
14 Bi-Rite Creamery
15 San Francisco's Hometown Creamery 
16 Miyako Old Fashioned Ice Cream
17 Mitchells Ice cream
18 St. Francis Fountain
19 Z Cioccolato
20 Joe's Ice Cream
21 Christopher Elbow Artisanal Chocolate
22 The Baked Bear- Custom Ice Cream Sandwiches
23 Recchiuti Confections 
24 Poco Dolce Chocolates
author: Rod M.

description:
Favorite ice cream for their unique seasonal flavors and friendly staff! I come here on days I'm craving ice cream and this place has never disappointed!

Sugar waffles here are the best! You can smell them from a block away! My doggie and I always stop by when were walking up Fillmore Street because we can resist the smells coming from this ice cream shop! 

Best park of this place-- samples. If you can't make up your mind, might as well have a few taste tests to help you decide!
author: Michelle C.

description:
I came here back in December when I was visiting some friends In San Francisco. I initially wanted to go to Smitten ice cream by my friends said Salt&Straw was sooo much better. And I'm very glad they took me here. 

There was a small line but it was going by fast. I was helped by this super nice girl who showed no ounce of impatience when I asked to try like 10 flavors (which was a little culture shock coming from the east coast LOL) She explained the seasonal flavors and their usual flavors , but their usual flavors were anything but normal.

I tried the almond brittle, lavender, roasted strawberry, and a few more I couldn't remember. Each one made my decision for two flavors so much harder. I ended up choosing the roasted strawberry and lemon custard olive oil! 

The lemon custard olive oil was very unique- I expected more sour and tangy, but the olive oil balanced it out so well, I can't even explain it! And the roasted strawberry was a local favorite and I could taste why. How do they create such flavors ?! I'm definitely returning here when I go back to San Francisco. You won't be disappoint with this unique artisan ice cream shop.
author: Catherine W.

description:
My boyfriend just spoiled me with ice cream one night. I can't remember what happened exactly that led to this place, but I do remember it was cold outside and there was still a line out the door. Granted, the line did move pretty fast and give the customers a lot of time to browse the menu... parking is all on the streets and metered till 6pm so keep your eyes peeled if you're coming to this area before then. 

Their menu is pretty extensive. They have a good amount of flavors that get you thinking and if that's not enough they also have a seasonal menu, too, that makes you think you need to get more than 1 giant scoop because you kinda wanna taste everything and anything they had to offer. 

For what you're paying I think you're getting a pretty good amount. And it looks even more impressive when you're eating it on a cone because holy hell, take a photo. Put it on the 'gram. You are eating something photo worthy right now, foo'.

They don't limit you on how many flavors you can try, but to be nice and courteous my boyfriend and I limited ourselves to 2 samples each before deciding on our flavors and moving on out from the shop to the outside world. 

Yes, I am for the hype. My sweet tooth is for the hype. Waiting in a long line for ice cream may sound insane, but San Francisco does have great places to go and hey.. it's one night out of your whole life. Why not?
author: Venus L.

description:
Love everything about this place! From the moment you walk in, the smell of the frehsly made waffle cones immediately gets you drooling.

The gelato flavours here are out of this world. I had a double scoop of the honey lavender and caramelized grapefruit eggnog - it was fantastic!

Would totally come back again! Love love love it!!
author: Anthony S.

description:
Delicious ice cream! I love it
They have unique flavors that change very often. It's one of my favorite ice cream places
author: Alondra R.

description:
Not to sound older than I am, but I can recall the days when I'd get a scoop of ice cream at Thriftys for $.15.  Yet I didn't bat an eye when the bill for one scoop of lavender honey  ice cream in a freshly made waffle cone bowl come to $6.

This place must get crazy popular as I noticed there were stanchions in the sidewalk (those things used to corral humans) for the overflow line. We lucked out as there were only two people ahead of us. Mind you it was a Monday afternoon.

I think the price partially subsidizes the endless amount of sampling that goes on here. I mean, how could one pass up the limited edition Thanksgiving flavors? I had to try the persimmon stuffing ice cream. True to it's word, I could taste it. Reminded me a bit of that scene from Willy Wonka and Veruca Salt with the chewing gum...

Fantastic service: friendly, patient and personable! Seems they could do with another person behind the counter however as the line kept growing behind us.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
50 degrees in San Francisco? So... should I get hot chocolate? Nah, I'm gonna go for ice cream! We came here at around 4 PM on a weekend and the line was out the door. We waited about 30 minutes until we ordered. 

You can sample all the flavors your heart desires, and I ended up ordering a scoop of honey lavender and a scoop of strawberry in a waffle cone. The honey lavender was the perfect mix of honey and lavender, while the strawberry was a bit too sour-y tasting for me. It was definitely still delicious though!

Currently, they have a Thanksgiving-themed menu with flavors such as mashed potatoes, turkey, and cranberries. Very interesting, but I went with the other 2 flavors I mentioned.

There is not a lot of seating space inside; there were 4 spots at a counter, and just 2 other open seats. If you don't want to wait in a long line, go during off-hours. Also, get the waffle cone. It makes a difference and is worth the extra money. They're freshly made too!

Ugh, I love ice cream so much. The image on my Apple watch is of an ice cream cone from when I went to Salt & Straw in LA forever ago :)
author: Michelle T.

description:
52 degree weather in San Fran wasn't gonna stop me from trying this place out. Although the line was wrapped around the corner of the street, I was promised the wait was worthwhile. 

Service was fantastic! All of the workers were extremely friendly and helpful when it came to picking flavors. Don't let the long lines intimidate you. It goes by fairly quickly and the workers speed up the process by offering samples while you're still in line- talk about efficiency! 

Flavor-wise, Salt & Straw offers way more than your typical icecream shop. They offer seasonal flavors that are truly unique and almost shocking how they could possibly invent flavors like these.. but nonetheless, I highly recommend trying out the seasonal flavors (just sample it!) if not committing to one in your actual scoop of icecream. 

+ Mashed Potatoes & Gravy: 5/5 The description didn't sound very appealing but the flavor was very enjoyable. The mashed potatoes had a subtle aftertaste that just made it feel like Thanksgiving in that very moment. 
+ Roasted strawberry tres leche: 3.5/5 The strawberry flavor was very rich and prominent. The leche portion tasted like cake batter which I really liked-the texture was grainy and less sweet compared to the rest of the icecream. I ordered a split scoop of this flavor and it was just overwhelmingly sweet for my taste. I couldn't stomach to even finish the whole split scoop. 

The prices seem a bit steep but Salt & Straw makes their products in small batches using fresh, local ingredients. In addition, the workers are pretty generous with their scoops. One scoop will run you  $5.00 without a waffle cone. I recommend doing a split scoop to try more flavors and the $.50 is worth it! Parking can be a pain but if you go to the park, there should be plenty of parking and its about 3-4 blocks away. All in all, I had a great experience here and I'll be back for more if I'm ever in SF.
author: Sandra N.

description:
This spot is for the adventurous minded ice cream lovers.  While they have some standard flavors, they're known for their unique and sometimes odd sounding flavors.  

Their servings are very generous.  My two scoops were very filling:  olive oil and almond brittle (with salted caramel swirl).  

Yum Yum!
author: Gene D.

description:
Gosh, I am such a fan of Salt & Straw; their flavors are so unique and very tasty. They also try to use local ingredients/local stores too. I first tried their ice cream in Portland and was hooked. Each location has a few different flavors (such SF flavors include salted honey marshmallow & walnuts, and roasted strawberry tres leches), but most can be found at all locations (mmm, the delicate honey lavender and very chocoaltely chocolate gooey brownie). 

One of my favorites from Portland is the Coava Coffee & Cocanú Craque. Translated over to SF it's  offered as Sightglass Coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate. It's pretty good (coffee ice cream with a crunch), but I find the Portland flavor to be way better (unless I tried it on an off-day). 

They have a seasonal menu that changes monthly as well, which is so fun. Back in July I found all the flavors to be on top of their game, it was a very berry-centric menu. 

Anyway, don't worry about the lines, because they take time with each customer to sample flavors (and are really friendly) and it's totally worth it!
author: Jessica H.

description:
A very delayed review but I have to applaud Salt & Straw on their novelty Halloween flavors. While not all of them resonated with me, I still appreciate their creativity and pushing the envelope on flavor profiles

Overall Thoughts

I look forward to keeping an eye on their monthly rotating flavors to see what else they come up with
author: Eddie W.

description: I don't get the hype for this place.  Ok, I had them in Portland before and wasn't impressed with them, so i didn't have any expectations here.  The seasonal flavors did sound interesting and they work with local small businesses to make interesting flavors.  I got here after dinner and got the carrot cake and lavender ice cream.  The carrot cake one was ok, it really tasted like carrot cake, however, i really didn't like the lavender ice cream, its one of those ice creams where you either love it or you either hate it.   They have limited seating here and there's no restroom, so be prepared to stand around eating your ice cream.
author: Belinda C.

description:
Hate me for this but I am probably the only person that gave a low rating for their ice cream... But please. Let me tell you why.

First of all, I smelled the aroma of the waffle cones literally a block away. My nose was magnetizing towards it as I kept getting closer and closer. We walked in on a Monday around 3PM and there was no line.

I know many people have raved over Salt and Straw. They are so happy it finally made their way to here. However, I couldn't find anything special about it. Perhaps I got the wrong flavor? Did I go on a bad ice cream batch day? I am not sure what went wrong here but I thought their ice cream was just OK. I got the Sea Salt Ribbon ice cream and it was way too sweet for my liking. The ice cream was a bit too churned for me. Maybe it is because I like my ice cream really hard? It was nothing to rave about or dying to come back for.

I will say their ice cream flavors are not your ordinary ice cream shop. You will see some interesting ones like Honey Lavender or something with Goat cheese(?) which you do not see very often. Be prepared to expect not the ordinary ice cream flavors.
$5 for a scoop sounds quite $$, but they do pack a big scoop in if that helps.

Also, be prepared for the horrendous parking. Meters will require some feeding and parking is a bit tight. We were lucky enough to get parking right when we arrived. If it was too busy I would have dipped..

The waffle cones might have magnetized me in, but the ice cream sure didnt! :/
author: Christine N.

description: Salt & Straw is so yummy and a must have if you're in the area. They always have something new so make sure you sample a little bit of everything before you make your choice. The employees are always so friendly and energetic and greet you as you walk in the door with a smile and a welcome.
author: B H.

description: The highlight of this place is how unique their flavors is ! And they let you try the flavors first before choosing it ! It was jam packed when I went at night at around 10pm. By the time I left they had a line around the corner ! The have seasonal floral flavors and their classic . We tried the sea salt caramel , honey lavender , chocolate rose petal , strawberry coconut , andddd then we were offered the edible flower seasonal flavor and jasmine milk tea! They get 5 stars for service ! My favorite was the sea salt caramel and honey lavender . I would definitely return to try their seasonal flavors because it so darn interesting and I love trying weird sh-t.  I wish their texture was a bit more creamy though . But still must try !
author: Ang L.

description:
FINALLY got the chance to try Salt & Straw. The line has died down in the last...couple months :) Worth the wait! I had the opportunity to visit at around 2pm on a weekday (perfect timing), and there was NO LINE! I ordered the honey lavender ice cream in a waffle cone. The ice cream had a beautiful purple hue, and it was DELICIOUS! I could pick up on the hints of honey amongst the more dominating lavender flavor. Plus, the waffle cone was still warm...fresh off the waffle iron. 

The flavors offered at Salt & Straw are incredibly unique. I was being safe on my first go-around, but don't expect plain jane vanilla or chocolate here. Truly a gourmet style ice cream (*is that a thing?!) 

I have a couple of tips for ya:

Tips: 

1. Go during "down times" for ice cream. Morning, or late afternoon is best. Also, the dreaded line that so many have described is worst on the weekends, so beware! 

2. For the love of god, order the waffle cone. It's worth the extra dollar. Salt & Straw makes them to order.  

Bottom Line: Outstandingly fresh and unique ice cream.
author: Jaime W.

description:
Despite having lived on the west coast for basically my entire life, I've still never been to Portland (or Seattle, or Mexico, for that matter). 

As a self-proclaimed lover of avant-garde ice cream flavors and long-time member of ice creamaholics anonymous however, I had to check this spot out when I learned this Portland transplant had moved here. 

I swear I got a buratta and honey flavored one, but I no longer see it on their website. I don't recall the ice cream really standing out to me-- just your standard upscale ice cream shop creamy.

The thing is, the shop's not even really that far from me, so maybe I should go back and check it out sometime...

Line was decently long but moved quickly enough!

--

Edit: Made it back here for Round 2! I tried way too many flavors because the lady at the front was oh so nice about it...and definitely encouraged my indecisiveness. 

Starting with their summer seasonal flavors: carrot cake batter with hazelnut praline-- not my personal favorite because the cream cheese ribbon made it a bit sour (not carrot cake-y) and I always find that nuts get in the way of my ice cream / chocolate zucchini bread-- this one was strong on the spices and had bits of bread in it, was a-ok in my opinion / green fennel and maple-- I ended up getting this. I liked how the fennel almost came in as an after-taste, but didn't think the maple was that strong / eggplant honey custard-- got this one as well, the ice cream itself only had light hints of eggplant, but when combined with the eggplant bits, it really worked well. who woulda thunk? 

Onto their regular flavors: roasted strawberry tres leches: my roommates really enjoyed this one, but it seemed mostly like strawberry ice cream to me, though with cake chunks / sightglass coffee-- this was very deep in coffee flavor, almost borderline black coffee in taste, which was a bit much for me / salted honey marshmallow and walnut-- this didn't really stand out to me too much, but then again not a fan of nuts in ice cream / olive oil and lemon custard-- smooth, but again not my thing / teranga baobab-- a bit sour, and while i generally love coconut based ice creams, this one didn't do it for me. 

With a line out the door at 10pm on Sunday, they must be doing something right! Personally, the ice cream isn't as creamy as the ones at Bi-Rite or Smitten. Still a 3/5 on taste, but I do love the innovation!
author: Nicole H.

description:
Ohmuhgosh. I didn't really believe in the hype, but I finally had Salt & Straw this past weekend and I AM HERE FOR IT. 

Two of my friends and I stopped in on a Saturday afternoon and our timing was perfect; there wasn't an insane line until after we were placing our order. (Be forewarned though, there may a line when you visit. It's worth it.) I decided to get a kid's scoop of Salted, Malted Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough. I also requested chocolate sprinkles because duh, they're the best. (They're the extra skinny, super crunchy kind.) Our server was knowledgeable about all of the ingredients and let us taste a few of May's flavors. He couldn't have been more friendly!

I officially love Salt & Straw.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Salt & Straw is consistently the best ice cream place I've been to in my many years of indulgence. I used to stop by the locations on Larchmont and in the Arts District in LA almost weekly, so this spot had a lot to live up to for me.

There are always any number of unique seasonal flavors available for tasting, as well as standby favorites (my personal being honey lavendar). The last time I came here was during the holiday season, with my personal favorite being the Apple Brandy & Pecan Pie.

Every time I come here I'm always blown away by how rich and delightful the various flavors available are, no matter how out there they might be. The portions are also quite generous, which is important when we're talking about the quite steep prices of artisan ice creams these days. 

At the end of the day, Salt & Straw is always worth the trip for me. I'll be coming here as long as I am alive.
author: Jenny D.

description:
Came here to see and taste the HYPE! 

The ice cream was not bad. We got the Salted, Malted cookie dough and a special seasonal concoction flavor. The line was out the door super long, but that just means the place is great and popular! 

The ice cream itself was not bad. Super sweet, and definitely wouldn't recommend eating a big dinner beforehand. The scoops are generous, and the ice cream is well made. They even have pints to go if you don't want to wait in line (genius idea). They are big on local ingredients, and community involvement too which I appreciate. 

The service however, is all downhill from there, hence the 2 star review. I asked the young lady with a USF shirt on to recommend some flavors since this was my first time, and she said "I really don't have any." I obviously have read the menu, and had a few in mind, but I always ask just to get a pulse. For someone that works at an ice cream place, I would hope that they would have SOME opinion about their ice cream! She seemed disinterested in us, a little aloof, and quite candidly rude. It has definitely left a bad taste in my mouth after all that sweet ice cream. We also asked for regular cones, and she charged us extra for 2 waffle cones that we didn't ask for. A pretty sneaky way to make a few extra bucks in my opinion. 

I may try again but maybe visit a different store. I live in San Jose, so this was my first time trying the ice cream, and I was a little disappointed by the sub-par uninterested employee. Maybe she was having a bad day (always giving the benefit of the doubt here), but I wouldn't rule out a second visit to Salt and Straw to edit this review and see if they're able to improve.
author: Alison D.

description:
It was my first time getting Salt & Straw and I was a bit skeptical on how good it would be in comparison to how pricey it was. In the end, I think it was a good decision and was well worth the $5. I was lucky that there wasn't much of a line and also because they had their holiday ice cream flavor selection. 

The service was really nice, as the guy behind the counter let us sample many flavors. Nonetheless, my friend and I got to try out most of the holiday flavors. In the end, I chose the gingerbread cookie dough and I think it was the literally the best ice cream I ever had. The gingerbread flavor was super good, wasn't overly sweet at all, and still had the nice creamy consistency. 

If I had to rank the 3 best flavors, it'd be: Gingerbread Cookie Dough, Apple Brandy and Pecan Pie, and Olive Oil and Lemon Custard.

They were also doing this holiday promotion where if you bought a pint of ice cream, they'd donate a pint too. Salt & Straw -- you guys have won me over.
author: Victor L.

description:
I have heard of this being the place to go for ice cream in Portland.  Nice to see another boutique icecreamery find a home in SF.

They had some quite unique flavors with ingredients sourced from local well known local businesses such as Sightglass Coffee. Good job supporting local affiliate businesses!

After getting to the counter the first time I came here, I tried about 6 flavors. I didn't feel pressured by any staff to make up my mind which was nice considering the crowd, but just looking behind at the queue I felt like the pressure was coming from the waiting crowds even if it wasn't from the staff. It's very reminiscent of BiRite ice creamery lines so nothing new here, just pointing it out. 

I initially liked the 'thick creaminess' of the ice cream but after a quite a few times back trying other flavors my palette started to dislike it. I don't know what it is but it feels like it could be whatever they are using to thicken or give that gluggy sensation to the icecream. On occasion it even feels 'powdery' if that even makes sense. 

The flavors are changed up every few months, introducing new delectable treats to your taste buds. Some interesting flavors for sure. There's nothing I put my finger on as my all time favorites that I would go back for, every time has been an adventure of what will this taste like.
author: Y B.

description:
I highly recommend Salt & straw for their novel flavors. I have been to their location in LA before and was excited to find out that they have a branch in SF. They have their classic flavors and also a selection of limited/seasonal flavors. In this last visit, I tried two flavors:

Ras el hanout and pickled rose patel jam (seasonal flavor - spices and rose, very delicious)
Black olive brittle and goat cheese (classic flavor - highly recommended, it was mind blowing. I never would think this would be good for ice cream). 

Expect to wait in line outside and also they don't have more than a few seats inside.
author: Doruk B.

description:
Cool new ice cream shop in sf from Portland? Of course I had to come check it out. I went when they had their interesting thanksgiving flavors (they have limited editions flavors that rotate every month) which were interesting to say the least! Mashed potatoes tastes exactly like mashed potatoes. Salted turkey?! So unique!

The vibe is so hipster, very Pac heights sf. Love it

I got a split double scoop ($7.5) which is basically 4 small scoops! Roasted strawberry and peach vinegar cobbler were my favorites!
author: Sunny K.

description: This place is a very different kind of ice cream place ever. They have all kinds of different flavors. You are more then welcome to try as many flavors as you want. Some flavors I tried were so different the one taste was enough. I enjoyed my version of the rocky road and will go Anaheim to try more flavors
author: Hidemy B.

description:
Really good ice cream. We tried it the first time last year in Portland and am so glad they are here in SF. Hubby had dinner with a friend in the hood and I told him to bring home a pint. He called after 8 PM on a Friday night to tell me there was a huge line and picked out the salt and caramel from the freezer and was getting an additional Meyer lemon buttermilk blueberry pint. At $11 a pint it was costly but who am I to say no to ice cream. 

There was a huge glob of gelatinous caramel in the center of the ice cream which had just the right amount of salt. Too much caramel for my taste. The lemon ice cream was delish. I would prefer to leave out the blueberry swirls in the middle and could just eat an entire pint of the lemon ice cream. I don't usually like lemon ice cream but I wish they would put this on their regular menu instead of it being seasonal.  Can't wait to sample other flavors. Their original store in Portland also has long lines.
author: Ry T.

description:
Review #057 - 2018

We showed up around 4 PM on Sunday afternoon and I sent the boys in to taste a few different flavors for me since I couldn't find a parking spot, and the baby was actually sleeping in the backseat so I didn't want to wake her up.

My nephew chose the two flavors that he thought I would like, which he was right about in most cases, but not in this particular instance.

The honey lavender was good, but the sea salted caramel was too salty for my liking.  The ice cream also seemed to melt a lot quicker than I expected especially since it was pretty cold out.

Joshua had the chocolate gooey brownie, which he said was really good.

Phil had the honey lavender and roasted strawberry tres leches, which he raved about.

Overall, I liked the flavor of the honey lavender, but I'll just have to come in and personally choose the flavors myself next time.
author: Sivilay T.

description: I was in the area and curious to see what this place was that had a long line at 10pm on a Tuesday. Turns out to be an awesome ice cream spot. Friendly employees and a lot of unique flavors. The lined moved fast and I emerged successfully with a blondie sundae which was delish. Makes me wish I lived closer!
author: Sunil R.

description: Wow! What bold flavor combinations! They have a seasonal and regular menu! I tried Honey Lavender, Chocolate Caramel potato chip cupcake (with real potato chips inside!), and a few of their other taste bud busting combinations. I decided to go with the flagship flavor of Salted Caramel Ribbons. Just the right combination of sweet and salty with the caramel infusion that makes everything right in the world. I'll be back to try their other confections! 5 stars!
author: Mike C.

description:
This place sweetens the smell of the entire street. A bit too sweet imo, but great texture and flavors. We shared the almond one (second one on the list) in a waffle cone and loved every bite of it. 

Barely any line on Sunday 10pm, but surprisingly had more people then expected. The Halloween flavors were a bit strange and one apparently has shellfish! Vom.

Very friendly staff!
author: Juliana P.

description:
Let me start of my stating that the product made by Salt & Straw is by FAR the best ice cream I've ever eaten. Out of this universe good-and no other ice cream should ever be compared to their product. Wow. 

UPDATE-
After a few try's, the SF location has got it down. We come here on the regular-as we love trying the monthly limited flavors. The scoopers working at the OG SF location are pleasant and helpful. This is the best ice cream on earth. Love this months Goat Cheese and Pumpkin Pie!

Will be a life long customer. Thanks for the private message after my initial less-than-perfect review.
author: Steve S.

description: One of my favorite spots when I lived in Portland. Im glad theyre taking over the bay as well. They have a wide variety of delicious  and and interesting flavors. I had the almond butter with salted ganache this time in a waffle cone. It was great all around I especially liked the bits of crunchy ganache.
author: Sean G.

description:
Creativity is not lacking at Salt & Straw! Most of the flavors include at least one ingredient that makes you think, does that really work in ice cream? I love going back to Salt & Straw to see what new crazy flavors I can try. Although, my absolute favorite is the Lucky Charms flavor they serve throughout March. My only complaint is sometimes I find the flavors too sweet and cannot eat all of my ice cream.

Pro tip: Want to try two flavors, but only want one scoop? You can ask for half scoops to try two flavors in one scoop!
author: Emitom H.

description: I am not a fan of waiting in line to pay lot of money for food. This place can be tried if you are ok with above.
author: Ricky G.

description:
I caught up with a friend during her lunch at work and we grabbed ice cream after lunch:

I had the:
- peppermint cocoa: delicious!  The peppermint paddies really made the ice cream.  The chocolate ice cream was good, but didn't particularly stand out.  
- apple brandy pecan pie: also delicious!  It actually tasted like apple pie.  I had a chunk of crust and it tasted really buttery and delicious. The only think I could suggest for improvement is to add a little more brandy.  It's hard to taste it and almost absent.

The service here was exceptional.  The lady behind the counter let us know that there were unlimited samples and as we were sampling, she even offered samples of flavors she liked.  I've never had this happen to me ever before.  

TL/DR: Its good! I like it! They have unique funky flavors that are delicious! I would recommend it!
author: Jon P.

description: Loving the March flavors - Pots of Gold and Rainbows, Sweet Corn and Waffle Cone!!
author: Elaine N.

description:
Loved Salt & Straw in Portland, love Salt & Straw in Los Angeles... so of course, I love Salt & Straw in San Francisco! 

After dinner at State Bird Provisions with my boyfriend and his family, we needed to walk it off! So we did - to dessert at Salt & Straw. :) There were so many people waiting to get ice cream at Salt & Straw on a Saturday night that we waited 40 minutes to get to the front of the line! Since there were four of us, we decided to get 2 ice cream flights so we could try more flavors. Sweet deal!
author: Christine S.

description:
WORTH THE WAIT. While the line seems daunting, the ice cream at salt & straw is well worth it! For those of us who can't travel up to Portland for the original location, this SF outpost serves up the same quality and creative flavors that have made the creamery at the top of all national ice cream lists.

Service is attentive and quick, they allow as many samples as necessary before choosing a core or seasonal flavor(s).

Pro tip: if the line is too daunting, grab a pint from the freezer at the front and cut the line to pay.
author: Taylor H.

description: The customer service is exemplary and part of the experience. The shop is modern and homey at the same time. The single scoop is no less than $5, but cashier charged me $4 instead...yay! He said he calls single scoop a kid's scoop or something. I got the strawberry flavor and it tasted like regular strawberry with a little zing. I had the sugar cone. They don't offer cake cone. Waffle cone is more expensive by $1.75. I was with Z. We enjoyed our experience in Pacific Heights.
author: Denise C.

description:
First visit was Portland. So good.

Second visit was this store. Didn't care for it. I tried some Moon Pie mint or something, and another flavor I can't even remember, but they were really forgettable.

Wish I would have gone for the honey lavendar. Not a fan of the vegan flavors at all.
author: Russ P.

description:
Mmmmm, Salt and Straw has been a bookmark forever! Honestly, sad to say I heard about this place first when Real World Portland was on tv....yes, I said Real World. 

When I heard Salt and Straw came to San Francisco, I was pumped to finally try it. I'm not the biggest ice cream person but I'm a sucker for strawberry flavored things. If you're here and reading this review for what flavor to get, YOU HAVE TO TRY THE STRAWBERRY AND CHEESE!!!! I grew up eating those strawberry vanilla cups and it's similar but with a more cream cheese taste. It's so yummy and their freshly made cones really do it for me. 

The lines are fairly long and with the way Bay Area weather has been heating up, I'm expecting longer lines during this Indian summer. Otherwise staff are super friendly and patient. I had a few samples before I decided on this one. If I'm craving ice cream again, this is forsure a top 3 on my list in SF :)
author: Shelly W.

description:
This is probably my new favorite ice cream spot in the city. Wow.

Pros:
+ Abbey, the sweetest gal there!
+ So many creative flavors, how does one choose?!
+ So many scoop sizes, perfect!
+ Spacious interior for the long snaking line

Cons:
- Line gets long
- Maybe more seating, or you can opt to walk around Fillmore

Recommendations:
+ Almond Brittle
+ Chocolate Brownie
+ Double Fold Vanilla

The most basic of flavors are reinvented in the best way, rich in flavor but not overkill. I don't usually opt for vanilla, but the Double Fold Vanilla here was pretty darn good. I'm not sure how the pricing and scoop sizes work, but I saw Abbey holding a really small scoop, so I asked for all three flavors in that golf ball sized scooper. Perfect for those of us who can't eat much but want to try it all. Abbey was so pleasant and helpful, letting us try flavors more than once. She also gave us her discount of the day! Thanks Abbey!! Can't wait to come back!
author: Fanny W.

description:
I've been here twice already and both times were met with lines out the door and around the corner! But for good reason of course. The flavors they have here are quite unique such as their olive oil and lemon combo. They are also very good about helping you choose the right flavor for you by letting you try as many samples as you want. Salt & Straw also have reoccurring monthly special edition flavors which of course I always overdo. 

The last time was no exception and since it's October, they had creepy/ scary flavor sounding names out. One in particular was Dracula's Blood Pudding. I didn't think anything of it and quickly stuffed it in my mouth as soon as she gave me my spoon. It tasted so heavenly and delicious. I don't really go for chocolate type ice creams but after that first taste, I was like "Yup this is the one. I want this on a waffle cone." It was after the fact that I discovered there was 8% PIG'S BLOOD in it! 

Listen, man. I'm all for trying out new things and all but I'm ....totally vegetarian. So I just did NOT feel right afterwards. She was very apologetic afterwards and I hold no grudge or anything (although I did drop a star). It would just be nice if Salt & Straw made a sign or anything to indicate non-vegetarian. It could've saved other vegetarian/ vegans from being deeply disturbed from an ice cream shop. Other than that incident, this place does have pretty good ice cream and if you've never been here before, the wait is definitely worth it!
author: Kimberly B.

description:
Ah I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet after how many times I've visited and had to endure the long wait times! The ice cream at Salt & Straw is phenomenal and I'm ecstatic that they've opened a location in the Bay Area. No need to venture out to Portland or LA anymore!

Every time I visit, ordering the Honey Lavender is a must. I also love that they offer new flavors every month. I guess I have a reason to go on a monthly basis! My other favorite flavors worth mentioning is the Double Fold Vanilla, Salted Honey Marshmallow, Sightglass Coffee, and of course the Sea Salt Caramel.

Also a huge shoutout to all the employees who've had the patience to deal with me as I try a minimum of 5 flavors before deciding what I want to order. You guys are the real MVP! Also if you're really indecisive like how I am, why not just order an ice cream flight instead?! No regrets and worth the calories!
author: MyTien P.

description: This place is awesome!  I love the variety of flavors, freshness and the staff are super nice! Great vegan options as well!
author: Lia M.

description:
Yay for the unique flavors!
Yay for the creaminess!
Yay for testing flavors before you buy!

Nay for the 40 minute line...
Nay for the crabby staff member that won't let your group try flavors together then pushes you to hurry up...
author: Mandi W.

description:
Best ice cream place ever! My friends and I were eating dinner at Fillmore, and suggested we get some ice cream afterwards. Salt & Straw a block away, so we walked over. Just steps away from the store, there was a delicious smell coming outside of Salt & Straw. All their ice cream is home made :)

There was just a little short line, and while waiting in line, someone came to help us and provide samples for us. She was very helpful in providing recommendations, and even suggested some ice creams to pair together. She recommended pairing the olive oil & lemon custard with the honey lavender. It was a delicious combination..thank you for that rec! The store has a good number of classic options, and then they have special options that are changed monthly. All the flavors tasted delicious, and you honestly can't go wrong with any flavor. We ended up sharing the honey lavender..it was delicious and I loved the hint of lavender in it :) 

There is limited seating inside, but with Fillmore being such a fun place to walk, it was nice to grab our ice cream and walk along the street. I will definitely come back again!
author: Jackie C.

description:
Okayyyy, I have to say, Salt & Straw definitely lived up to their hype! We popped in here after Dim Sum on a Thursday morning and in need of a sweet treat! I had heard so much about this lovely place but never had the opportunity to try it - until now! 

Their flavors are SO unique - WARNING: you will have trouble choosing! Unique ingredients included lavender, olive oil, goat cheese, herbs, vinegar, and more. They had a great regular selection but also a variety of monthly flavors that sounded delightful. They were so friendly and gave us a variety of samples so that we could actually narrow them down to choose, otherwise it would have been so hard. One of everything please!! ;) 

I ended up ordering a scoop of birthday cake + blackberry and a scoop of almond brittle with salted ganache. FLAVOR EXPLOSIONS! These made the best combo and were absolutely incredible. So creamy...basically what ice cream dreams are made of. If passing by when in the city again, I would definitely stop in, and you should too!
author: Hailey P.

description:
People complain about everything these days. They complained that nothing in SF compared to Salt & Straw in Portland/LA, but when Salt & Straw shows up in SF, they complain that it's "overhyped." MAKE UP YOUR MIND. Ok, sorry, needed to get that out there.

I came on National Ice Cream Day awhile back, and of course, there's a line. But thankfully, the line moves quickly and the fruits of your labor (wait?) is delicious ice cream. I love all of the seasonal flavors that Salt & Straw has, and I love that it changes with the seasons. I had Fresh Cheese with Strawberries and Birthday Cake & Blackberries. Between the two scoops, I think I liked the Birthday Cake the best! I do think that Salt & Straw has stiff competition here in SF, but having had both the Portland and SF experiences, I'm certainly glad they're here!
author: Lisa I.

description: Of course, this place is good! But Portland flavors were better. SF had a shorter line! Choose your battles
author: Moji O.

description:
Salt & Straw is one of those places that seem really overhyped for what it is. How creative can people get with ice cream? The answer to that? PRETTY DAMN CREATIVE. Salt & Straw is not only delicious, their creative twists and flavors make it completely different from your average basic vanilla. Though they may seem over the top, it's completely worth going here to experiment different varieties in ice cream, especially for the adventurous foodie at heart.

I came here at around 10pm at night with a friend, and the line wrapped out and around the door, which intimidated me especially since they closed at 11, but the line moved relatively quickly. I got to the front of the line within 15-20 minutes or so, which was impressive considering how many people were in front of me.

The person who helped me was really sweet, and let me sample as many flavors as I liked. Though there were so many customers in line, the workers there were patient and really kind. In the end, after trying a variety of flavors- I decided on Peach Vinegar Cobbler with Nutmeg.

The Peach Vinegar Cobbler with Nutmeg really intrigued me at first- as I really love peach cobbler in general but was intimidated by the prospect of vinegar and nutmeg, but it was surprisingly really good. The sweet peach taste was very refreshing without being too overwhelmingly sweet, and the nutmeg added a subtle addition of nuttiness to it. I was surprised how much I really loved it.

I also sampled the Sea Salt Caramel swirled with ribbons of Caramel and it might have honestly been one of the best Sea Salt Caramel ice creams I've ever had. I for SURE will come back for another scoop of this gloriousness, but I really wanted to try something different that I haven't had before. Really lightly salted, it wasn't overwhelmed with sea salt like I've noticed other places with their sea salt caramel, and the ribbons of caramel really tied the whole ice cream together completely.

I also sampled their seasonal July Birthday Cake and Blackberry ice cream, but for me personally it was a tad too sweet. It kinda reminds me of a birthday cake mixed with black berries with a chunks of graham cracker crust. Personally for me there was too much going on at one time, plus it was just overly too sweet, so I moved along my selection.

My friend also ordered the Olive Oil and Lemon Custard ice cream because he was really intrigued by what that could possibly have to offer. Don't be alarmed by the Olive Oil in the name, it actually is extremely smooth and you could taste the sweetness of the custard harmonizing with the tartness of the Lemon curd. A surprisingly sweet choice of ice cream.

Overall, Salt & Straw really blew it out of the park for me. For the adventurous eater at heart and for someone who wants to satisfy your sweet tooth, Salt & Straw definitely does not disappoint and is well worth a 5 star rating for me for their creativity in flavors to their customer service throughout the whole process. A definite hyped up place that's well worth the hype!
author: Allison O.

description: Finally made it out to this place and it's everything and more. Ordered the Wildflower Honey with Ricotta Walnut Lace Cookies and was blown away. By far the best ice cream I've ever had, highly recommend it if your craving some :)
author: Roman L.

description:
Totally late, but so glad I finally visited the Salt & Straw location in SF. Having tried my first Salt & Straw in Portland, I totally fell in love with their ice cream and unique flavors.

First of all, you must get a waffle cone! You can smell them from a block away. The service here is great, they will come to you with samples of your choice while you're still waiting in line. There are a ton of classic SF ice cream options, as well as some seasonal ones that they'll change every once in a while.

Their roasted strawberry tres leches was sooo good! It was on the sweeter side, but it paired so well with the olive oil and lemon curd. This was a match made in heaven. I love that their ice creams are actually rich and creamy, which IMO, a lot of ice cream shops fail to deliver. 

Scoops here are more than generous. I was stuffed after eating two huge scoops of ice cream.

TIPS:
-There's plenty of street parking nearby the store, as well as a few blocks down
-If you want to grab a pint to-go, you can skip the lines
-Split scoops are 50 cents extra...might as well go for a double scoop!
author: Shirley H.

description:
This neighborhood ice cream store had a unique variety of flavors!

I had just eaten lunch, so I ordered a kid size of the sea salt and caramel ribbon. I loved the flavor. 

I also samples the olive oil lemon custard -- subtle lemon flavor and also carrot cake, which was one of the special limited edition flavors. It tastes just like carrot cake!

A cute place. I will return if in the Fillmore district!
author: Mitzi W.

description:
Salt & Straw.. You beauty! After my last visit to Portland, I became a fan of this place. I had tried their strawberry balsamic something something with black pepper. It still gives me a warm feeling when I think about it:-)

Coming back to the one in SFO. As expected, there was a huge line, which extended from their serving counter to around 20 folks outside. I went there around 4 pm on a Sunday. Time just flew as the people in front of me had a cute little dog that I couldn't resist petting or stop looking at. I realized that you could skip the line and directly go the billing counter IF you purchase the pints from the refrigerator. All you've to do is pick your boxes and move. 

I was impressed with their tasting portions.. so generous. I fell in love with their honey lavender flavor, so much in love that I licked the box empty in a couple of days and I am craving for it as I type this. 

This will always be one of my favorite ice cream places, mainly because of the amazing flavors they come up with. 

Oh, did I mention the waffle cone and how the entire shop was filled an aroma of freshly baked waffle cones?
author: Pratyusha R.

description:
I've been to the Salt & Straw in Portland and also in LA, so I was excited to come here.  

The service alone makes this place 4 stars; service is super friendly top notch. Don't be shy about trying a lot (or all) the flavors they offer.  Again, the servers are super friendly and they are willing to let you try them.  You'll probably have your fill after trying a lot of the flavors but the ice cream is still super delicious.  I still had room for a double scoop!

I enjoyed the lavender and coffee flavored ice-creeam.  $5 for 1 scoop and $7 for 2 scoops.  You won't be disappointed - give them a shot if you are in the area.
author: Mike T.

description:
I really appreciate the portion sizes especially given how pricey the ice cream is at this place but I think that was also my undoing the first time I came here. I had a ROASTED STRAWBERRY TRES LECHES and OLIVE OIL & LEMON CUSTARD double scoop in a cup. The Olive Oil ice cream did me in. I was enamored by it when sampling but soon realized as I was eating my scoop that it was probably only good in small doses at least for me. 

The amount of cake in the Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches scoop was a bit overwhelming. I would have liked to taste more of the strawberry vanilla jam instead. All of the options here that I've tried even the ostensibly simpler flavors were very rich, thick, and decadent. I think you have to be in the right kind of mood for this kind of ice cream. They handled my feeling quite ill after eating ice cream issue very well which I wasn't expecting and which is why I returned.    

My second visit was on a bright and sunny Saturday afternoon (quite hot by SF standards) and it ended a lot more pleasantly. I did not get sick this time and felt great after devouring the massive double scoop waffle cone I ended up getting. I surprised myself by the speed at which I consumed that thing. They do have a lot of good flavor combinations which made it hard to pick the scoops.  

The server who helped me was really nice about me wanting to try all the limited edition Farmer's Market Series flavors plus the Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons. You can apparently try however many flavors you want. They give you big spoonfuls for sampling which makes it easier to discern the different ingredients. I noticed how loud it was in the store. I really had to speak up and strain to listen to the server. 

Carrot Cake Batter & Hazelnut Praline - The carrot cake flavor was very strong and delicious. I like the addition of the hazelnuts. This one was very good. 
Freckled Chocolate Zucchini Bread - I love zucchini bread but I thought this wasn't as good as the carrot cake. It is lighter in flavor if you don't want something too strong.  
Chocolate Date Shake - This was another one I really enjoyed. I mistook the dark chocolate flakes as nuts. My plan to concentrate very hard on the flavor profiles backfired. I liked the texture a lot which can be attributed to the chocolate sheet and could taste a hint of dates.    
Green Fennel & Maple - This tasted mostly of maple syrup. I found it hard to distinguish the fennel. For this one, I would need more than a spoonful to catch all the flavors.
Eggplant Honey Custard - I ended up getting this. More below!  

SEA SALT WITH CARAMEL RIBBONS
This is Salt & Straw's signature flavor and I immediately understood why. It was SO good. I really enjoyed biting into the thick ice cream and getting mouthfuls of the caramel and salt and cream. The flavor added by the salt was just perfect. I love it when you can really taste the salt in sea salt caramel ice creams. And the hand-burned ribbons of caramel were simply glorious.  

EGGPLANT HONEY CUSTARD
I have a deep infatuation with eggplant, but I have never had it in dessert form which made me really anticipate this flavor. The ice cream was filled with beautiful chunks of caramelized eggplant. I really liked that you can actually see the eggplant and it wasn't just blended in and hidden from sight! I did think that the honey which was delicious in its own right kind of buried the flavor of the eggplant. 

The thing with these unorthodox flavors is there seems to always be an opposing, more traditional flavor that overpowers the unusual ingredient. I actually would have liked to taste a lot more of the eggplant just because it's so intriguing to have it in ice cream. That would have also perpetuated the feeling that there was at least something healthy about this massive double scoop I was eating.

The lesson here for me was don't let traumatic first experiences deter you from trying and loving all kinds of ice creams. I will likely come back for more seasonal adventures.
author: Lauren H.

description:
I've been here on a few occasions and I've never been disappointed. Their ice cream is fresh, rich and very creamy. They have a selection of standard flavors, flavors only available in San Francisco and monthly/seasonal flavors...it really makes sense to visit this place every-so-often since they always have something new. Some of my favorite stand-outs?

-Salted Walnut Honey Marshmallow
-Honey Rock and Road
-Gooey Chocolate Brownie

They can have long lines, but they move fairly quickly...customer service is incredible and you can sample anything.
author: Ken G.

description:
**I SCREAM FOR ICE CREAM!**

It seems as if all you have to do is wait around and before you know it popular eateries will just pop up in the Bay Area. S&S is no different. And it seems that SF is the hub for ice cream. Don't get me wrong: traveling is fun but it's nice to know that if you're ever craving for something, it's in your own backyard. I visited this SF location twice and although I've never been to the Portland location, I'm sure it's just as good if not better. With that said, I can't really compare, but I can say that the ice cream at this location is fresh and creamy. I love how some of the flavors mesh so well together even though reading them off the menu, you wouldn't think those flavor profiles would work. But that's why their the experts and you just let them do what they do best. 

-Ice cream- Aside from the usual flavors, the following were the limited edition flavors for July 2017 (the theme was berries!): goat cheese marionberry habanero, meyer lemon buttermilk and blueberry, birthday cake and blackberries, fresh cheese and strawberries and wild foraged berry sherbet. My cousin ordered the meyer lemon buttermilk and blueberry on a waffle cone. I tried it and it was absolutely amazing! My boyfriend chose the fresh cheese and strawberries on a sugar cone.
