It was really tasty! I mean you really can't go wrong with any of their flavors unless you're allergic or just dislike a certain ingredient. However, if it's the latter, I would at least give it a try because you never know. I ended up going with the honey lavender on a sugar cone. I love the taste of flowery ingredients whether it's rose, lavender, chrysanthemum, you name it. 

-Service- I think other than the ice cream itself being amazing (haven't tasted one I didn't like), the service is great! One person stays with you the entire time and you can taste test practically the whole menu if you wanted. The only qualm I have about that is it can make the wait time longer. I went here at nighttime on a weekday on both visits so I never waited any more than 30min, but I can see where it can be extended when multiple people ahead of you want to try lots of flavors. I would still encourage trying different flavors though, but maybe they can restrict sampling to 2-3 flavors. 

-Overall impression- 4.5 stars! I only knocked half a star for the wait time. But what can I expect when a beloved creamery takes up shop in a town where ice cream is a staple dessert? One thing is for sure, I will be back!
author: Brittany D.

description:
I went back here tonight (Friday) at around 8:30pm with a friend who has never had ice cream from here!

Even on a cold misty SF night, the line was still out of the door! We waited a little bit but it wasn't too bad. I liked that they had one person asking if we wanted to sample any flavors and the same person returned to take our order. It sure made the wait shorter!

I was feeling adventures so I sampled Olive Oil & Lemon Custard, which I didn't really like and I love everything lemon! It was too oily for me and the custard felt like a dollop of lemon curd. My friend tried Honey Lavender and Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache. She said the lavender wasn't too strong (a good thing) but the Almond Brittle was just too good not to get. 

For my simple palate, I got a scoop of Double Fold Vanilla. A scoop is like $5. It's expensive but the scoop is pretty large. I admit, I liked it more than the Freckled Woodblock Chocolate I got last time. However, I'm just not wowed by it. Hence, the rating stays the same...
author: Alice L.

description:
Salt & Straw always puts me in such a good mood!

Every location I've been to so far has had the greatest customer service. All the workers are extremely down to earth and accommodating. Since Salt & Straw is so popular there's usually a long line formed but don't be discouraged! It usually goes by quickly and workers usually offer samples while customers are waiting in line to keep us happy and make the process of ordering go by more quickly and smoothly.

I visited the Seattle location as well and I really like how each Salt & Straw location offers different monthly flavors that are tailored to local ingredients. For example the one in SF had a chocolate flavor made my dandelion chocolate, while the one in Seattle had flavors from Ellenos yogurt!

A favorite go-to flavor of mine from the classic menu is the Honey Lavender. However, I also like to try their limited-edition flavors as well.

*pro-tip would be to splurge $1.50 extra and get the waffle cone because it compliments the ice cream so well! Right when you walk in, you're immediately welcomed by the scent of fresh-made waffle cones. And if you think a cone will be too messy to eat, opt for the waffle cup. 

All the flavors here are unique and I haven't tried anything that I've disliked. So be adventurous and let your tastebuds explore! :)
author: Pariya N.

description:
Greedily looking for something cooler after my brunch in this neighborhood and I accidentally ran into S&S. There were not many people on a Friday early afternoon so I was able to grab my scoop right away.

Decided to go a bit lighter so ordered the honey lavender flavor in a cup. Yet I would definitely recommend getting the specialty flavors, which change on a monthly basis.

One ice cream a day keeps depression away!
author: Elaine H.

description:
Glad to see a Salt and Straw opened up here in bay. I've been a fan since the first time I went to Portland. The line was long! I had to wait about 30 minutes. If you want to avoid the line, grab a pint!

They have the same general classic flavors with a local twist. The coffee and chocolate used are from sightglass and dandelion chocolate. This was pretty cool to see since they are different in OR and LA.

Flavors on the Month. For July it was berries, berries, berries. I tried the Meyer Lemon Buttermilk with Blueberries. If you love lemon bars, this has your name on it. 

Don't forget to add a split scoop of something else for 50c more!
author: Michael C.

description:
Decided to give Salt and Straw in SF a try after trying it in Portland. I am impressed with not only it still blowing my mind, but the fact that the quality across its stores consistent. 

Decided to try some new flavors they don't have in Portland and a couple of seasonal flavors. The Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches tasted like a strawberry ice cream, but better. There were pieces of cake in there. This is a milder flavor compared to some of its seasonal ones. 

The Peach Vinegar Cobbler & Toasted Nutmeg was a pleasant surprise. It reminded me of some balsamic vinegar ice creams I've had before, but those cobbler pieces and nutmeg really sealed the deal. This again is a milder flavor.

Moving on to the stronger/bolder flavors are the seasonal ones. We tried both the Freckled Chocolate & Zucchini Bread and Carrot Cake Batter & Hazelnut Praline. These flavors reminded me of the holidays, probably because of the hazelnut and cinnamon flavors. The zucchini bread was the milder of the two flavors, but still a bold one. The Carrot Cake Batter was delicious. There were chunks of hazelnut so the carrot cake flavor wasn't overwhelming.
author: Samantha L.

description: Such an experience! We tried almost every flavor but went with the salted caramel and cookie dough. I regret getting something boring like cookie dough though. The waffle cone is INCREDIBLE and the salted caramel was for sure the best. A few other flavors i would recommend: honey lavender, arbequina olive oil (I'm serious! Try it!), and there was something like raspberry matcha and strawberry tres leches. Delicious and worth the wait in line! Employees are so nice!
author: Madeline B.

description:
Their waffle cone is great. Light crispy and tasty. Very thin and delicate -- pretty impressed that it holds it all together. 

Tried a bunch of the flavors and the bar for ice cream has increased a ton in the past few years so I could tell the difference. Though the vanilla was just right and that's what I selected. 

Luckily the line was not long at all. But the outside line is made even longer because inside there is another small section that takes 10 min extra. Worth a try!
author: Young Y.

description:
Finally had a chance to try out Salt & Straw. I was really excited for it because of all the hype. I ordered the Tasting Flight with 1. Salted, malted, chocolate chip cookie dough, 2. Sea salt with caramel ribbons, 3. Roasted strawberry tres leches, and 4. Honey Lavender.  All the flavors were unique and good. But, I wouldn't crave or purposely go to Salt and Straw. 

I definitely recommend getting the Tasting flights. It's really worth the price compare to the single scoops. You essentially get four scoops. 

The service was really good. I got to try many different flavors before deciding.
author: Shelley L.

description:
no i don't like sweets.
no i don't like desserts.

yes i like treating women who do like desserts to dessert. :p

sampled the OLIVE OIL bc wtf; it was creamy sweet n a little cold. not salty or "greasy" or anything. ::shrug::

got a half (2 scoop) milkshake of the ROOT BEER. no carbonation but i could almost taste carbonation. funny. mild sweetness thank gawd.

tried her STRAWBERRY COCONUT, quite sweet. also LAVENDER, very pronounced flavor.

wasn't a line out the door at night but still buzzing. limited seating grabbed up quickly.
author: Dan B.

description: I'm so happy I tried the SF location!! SO good! Got the malted chocolate chip cookie dough. That had huge chunks of cookie dough pieces, so perfect!! I also got the sightglass coffee cashew. Both were amazing. Cute location cause you can walk around and window shop.
author: Kirby P.

description:
When you're with someone special in the most amazing city around, where do you go? What do you do? Get ice cream at Salt & Straw of course!

A year ago when I was traveling around Oregon, I had the chance to stop by Salt & Straw - the one and only, the absolute favorite amongst PDX Portlandians. Boy, I was a HUGE fan of the quality of their ice cream as well as their boldness with choice of products. I mean, where else do you go to get good tasting FISH SAUCE ice cream. I was instantly sold and told myself that I'd become one of those fans that would wait forever for this ice cream if Salt & Straw opened up in the Bay Area.

Fast forward to a few months ago and Salt & Straw had FINALLY opened up in San Francisco's Pacific Heights. I actually had the opportunity to visit their pop-up shop at Off the Grid in Fort Mason before their storefront (YES, GO SFOTG!!) and had the same exact experience as I had back in Portland. I remember trying their...

...Strawberry sorbet (10/10). Absolutely creamy and sweet! This strawberry was amazing, but I wished I could taste the coriander more. It's a safe bet if you like strawberry.

...Apple Mayo (10/10). Can I rate this 11/10? Don't be turned off by the mayo because it makes this ice cream SO CREAMY and the apple flavor is SO delicious! This was my personal favorite.

And because of how great of an experience I had with them at Off the Grid, I decided to take my girlfriend to their store location on the best of days: National Ice Cream Day.

Salt & Straw is located on Fillmore Street in Pac Heights. I actually absolutely LOVE this location because Pacific Heights is a very peaceful area. There's usually no traffic at night, meaning no parking or no lines for food. We came here after eating at Tataki (worth a try!) and it was only about a 5 minute walk away. Of course, since it was National Ice Cream day, the line was hella long but we were able to get near the front after about 15 minutes (you can use this as your baseline?). Even though there were a lot of people, we were appreciative of how efficient the employees were; despite not being right at the counter yet, they made an effort to feed us samples and make sure we were served (soft served???). 

On July 16, 2017 (National Ice Cream Day), Salt & Straw didn't have that outrageous of a selection of flavors (booohoo), but there were some that stood out such as the Goat Cheese Habanero and the Olive Oil and Lemon Custard. Note: If you have never been to Salt & Straw before, they have 50% "normal flavors" that are here daily and 50% more experimental flavors - 100% wild most of the time. We ended up getting the Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches with Vanilla I believe?

First, I have to say that there's a reason people keep coming back to Salt & Straw and it may not be just the ice cream. We ordered ours with a cup, but the employee who took our order gave us a cone. We told her it was totally fine, but she was super insistent on giving us another order free of charge. We insisted it was okay, and so she ended up NOT CHARGING US AT ALL - even after I tried to force my way to the cashier. That, my friends, is excellent service; and apparently they do this often.

Now back to the ice cream - I thought the roasted strawberry was AMAZING! I loved how creamy it was. The strawberries were super fresh, and the touch of salt was perfect. It definitely tastes like the description: just like cake batter. I would definitely come again for this.

Overall, would I say Salt & Straw is the best ice cream EVER? Coming out of Salt & Straw for the third time, I still have the same feeling as the first: Nobody does bold flavors like Salt & Straw and their service, I feel, is rivaled only by a few. I would say that this ever-growing chain is maybe my top 2-3 favorite ice cream places in the world. I personally like Bi-Rite better, but don't let me stop you from trying this AMAZING place. I give Salt & Straw an "omg, I'd travel 2 hours for this."

Eat well and prosper!
author: Bryan W.

description:
I've been wanting to try Salt & Straw ever since my sister came back from her Portland trip and mentioned their ice cream... Long behold there's finally one in SF... And it's now my favorite ice cream spot in SF! 

Always wanted to have ice cream for breakfast?  Well now it's possible with their seasonal flavor, "pots of gold and rainbows" (lucky charms cereal infused into vanilla ice cream), and it was BOMBBB! The lucky charms' marhmallow-y flavor had an even presence in the vanilla ice cream and didn't add an overbearing texture. This has definitely been added as one of my new favorite flavors of ice cream. 

I also had a half scoop of the "chocolate caramel potato chip cupcake" ice cream. This flavor sounds a lot less weird than the it sounds. The potato chips aren't simply pieces of chips crushed into ice cream, as some might imagine. Instead, it's pretty sweet (from the chocolate and caramel it's dipped in) with a hint of saltiness. It adds a nice crunchy texture too.  

To top things off, I had some really great service from the Asian girl with a Porter hat. She graciously provided me with several samples until I was able to decide what I wanted.
author: Selena M.

description:
My friend and I are devoted fans of Salt and Straw and we have been to several locations, including the original store in Portland, Oregon. We came on a Wednesday night, and the lines were fairly long, but it moved fast so that our wait was only about 20 min. 

They always have interesting flavors, and during our recent visit, the seasonal flavors were mostly berry related. I decided on the tres leche cake roasted strawberry flavor and it was very good! I enjoyed the bits of cake in the ice cream and the strong, fresh strawberry flavor. 

To my surprise, some of the ice creams we had sampled were not as great as the ice cream at the other Salt and Straw locations. Some of the samples I tried had pieces of ice in them, making the ice cream seem not fresh. However, the staff was super nice and was patient with us when we wanted to try so many flavors. The staff also ensures large scoops, so if you're really craving ice cream coming in, Salt and Straw can definitely satisfy your ice cream needs. 

Overall, I highly recommend a trip and anexperience at Salt and Straw. Be sure to try their exotic flavors too!
author: Sandra S.

description:
I am a fan of the energy, the menu, and the staff. I appreciate the creative and rotating flavors and the plethora of take-home options. 
The homemade caramel is really good! My main point for not being enthusiastic about this is the ice chips that were within my ice cream (always a turn off), not as creamy as I generally like (more personal preference likely) and the price for a simple scoop is ~$5 which is a little pricey for something that's not really my taste. Would go again and try a few more flavors but first visit hasn't had me sold to wait in the 20-30 min line.
author: Natasha B.

description: The line moves quickly and it's worth the wait! When it's your turn, you can sample any and all their ice cream if you want! Flavors are creative and even if something sounds gross, it's worth just trying it -- you may be surprised!
author: Jeanette R.

description: Large scoops, interesting and strong flavors that rotate regularly. Even the vegan options taste great. The best ice cream in SF.
author: P M.

description:
I'm a die-hard Swenson's sticky peanut butter ice cream gal but Salt & Straw is tied for my favorite ice cream in the city! 

I love their unique & delicious flavor combinations and the ice cream itself is much softer and creamier than Bi-Rite-yay!
author: Rachel C.

description:
As far as ice cream places in SF go, this is on top of the hype. Lots of interesting, artisanal flavors. Peach cobbler and vinegar, bone marrow and black cherry, honey lavender, etc. 

They let you sample as much as you want, which definitely creates a back up in the line, but definitely well worth it. 

Their waffle cones are hand rolled, fresh off the waffle maker, it smells like heaven even outside the shop. They also do split scoops, so if you want to try two flavors, but don't want to eat two big scoops, there's an option for that. 

Me and my group of friends all got different flavors to try as much of their menu as possible. Will definitely be interested in coming back to try more and perhaps get some pints!

Was disappointed to see that they had run out of the California honey rocky road, but that gives me another reason to come back.
author: Sanz E.

description:
The best vegan gluten free ice cream that I have ever had 
Perfect ice cream without a brain freeze in SF weather
author: Vy L.

description:
With all the talk about a new ice cream spot competing with the staples of the city. It was about time to check it out. The store itself is small with some quirky signage and decor that shows it didn't originate from sf. 

I heard they had funky flavors but the flavors today weren't too off the wall. I had sea salt with caramel ribbons that reminded me of a toned down version of salted caramel but it was pretty good. The strawberry tres leches tasted more of a strawberry ice cream. The scoops were pretty good sized like the guy described tennis ball scoops as opposed to golf balls. 

Creamy and thick were the textures I would use to describe. At $3.50/scoop, quite reasonable.
author: James H.

description: SO SO SO many flavors. The flavors are eclectic combinations that are surprisingly good. Was told to go here by a friend who worked at the Salt and Straw in Portland and it was so worth it. Ordered the goat cheese marionberry habañero which was sweet but with distinct goat cheese notes and a little bit of a kick from the habañero. It was one of the seasonal flavors (they vary by month). Ice cream is creamy and soft. Wouldn't recommend the matcha blackberry or the flavors with full berries within them because the berries are still thawing from being frozen (frozen berries are not my personal preference). They're happy and willing to let you try any and every flavor. I tried the olive oil flavor (SO GOOD) and the strawberry tres leches flavor. They also make their own waffle cones! Line goes out the door but takes ~10 minutes and it's not too bad.
author: Jennifer L.

description: I was so bummed I didn't get to visit their mother store in Portland, but heard this opened up!  I don't really review on ice cream, but hot damn! This place is where it's at!  There was already a line outside the door at 8pm on a Sunday night.  You can order the pints and skip the lines, but I wanted to check out the Salted, Malted, Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough, Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches and Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache.  I can't even begin to describe the creaminess, sweetness with a pinch of salt melting in my mouth! Wow! Loaded with goodness.  Once you taste it you will crave this place.
author: KB B.

description:
I have always had a warm, special place in my heart for dessert and have almost never turned it down. My friend raves about this place and apparently has tried nearly every flavor. The line would indicate that it's a popular spot and worth the wait. I think I might have to disagree...

The environment: the shop is cute with a friendly and inviting atmosphere. 

The service: servers work efficiently and even ask those waiting if they'd like any samples so that they can be prepared to select a flavor by the time it's their turn. This system works!

The menu: substantial number of flavors plus a rotating menu of special seasonal flavors, all of which are unique. Prices are a smidgen higher than usual, but that's Pac Heights for ya. You can also skip the line by grabbing a pint from the freezer.

The flavors: I sampled bone marrow & smoked cherries (surprisingly bland for such an ingredient), peach crumble bars (very peachy), roasted strawberry tres leches (not lechy enough), almond brittle with salted ganache (delish), honey lavender (tastes like it would anywhere else), and salted honey marshmallow & walnuts (the final choice and a yummy one at that). In hindsight, I should have opted for the almond brittle, but when you're sampling so many flavors at once, the palette can get confused! Biggest loss in points was due to the portion. It was the dinkiest kid's scoop I had ever purchased and disproportionate to the price of $4.

The lowdown: cute place and great service, but the ice cream itself didn't knock my Rainbows (sandals) off. It wasn't bad in any way, it just seemed more hyped up than it delivered. It could also use an improvement in the size of the scoops. I noticed that some of the other customers had scoops that didn't quite fill out their waffle cones...I can't justify that cost for such measly portions.
author: Jenny W.

description:
The ice cream may be a bit expensive, but it is so worth it. When we came here on a Sunday afternoon, there was a line out the door and down the block. Even so, the 30 minute wait was worth it. 

Their ice cream flavors are so unique and innovative. There is both a standard selection and a monthly rotation selection. Single scoops are $5, double scoops are $7, and addition of a waffle cone is $1.25. You can also get a tasting flight (with 4 flavors I believe?) for $11.50, and pints are $11 (you can skip the line if you purchase a pint!)

We got a double scoop with almond brittle with salted ganache and honey lavender. Although the final price with tax was a bit on the steep side for ice cream ($9), they gave a ton of ice cream and the fresh, crunchy just-made warm waffle shell made it well worth it. The honey lavender had nice floral notes and tasted almost reminiscent of chai tea. The almond brittle with chocolate ganache, on the other hand, is probably the best ice cream I have ever tasted. It was creamy but crunchy, with bits of brittle and chocolate that gave it a lot of texture. Would highly recommend to anyone visiting SF!
author: Amy C.

description:
This place has been on my list for quite some time, and knowing how popular it is in Portland, I was excited to find out there was a location right nearby in SF. 

I expected the line to be long, and it definitely was. Not as long as I've seen Bi-rite's go, but long enough to have me think "hm this place is likely worth the wait". After only ~30 min, we made our way up to the front of the line and were able to finally sample the flavors!

They have their classic flavors, and then specialty's ones that cycle monthly. Anything "limited edition" makes me all the more inclined to try those flavors but I gotta say, the honey lavender and their roasted strawberry flavors won me over. I chose to "split" my scoop, so I can choose 2 flavors without the extra cost of another scoop ($7 for a double scoop, and only $.50 for splitting -- you know that Asian in me gotta go for the better deal!) and put it all in a waffle cone ($1.25). 

They also ask which flavor you prefer to put on top, which I think brings that extra touch to the quality of service :3 

After getting through about 75% of the cone though (polishing off the honey lavender) the roasted strawberry ice cream (which I had chosen to go on the bottom) got too overwhelming and a bit too sweet. I couldn't finish it... :( but overall would come again! 

Note: you definitely get what you paid for, in quantity and in quality!
author: Tina T.

description: Been to several locations and today I had the roasted strawberry tres leches and Berkeley olive oil. They were sooo good. Love their unique flavors. So delicious
author: Suley Z.

description:
One minute I'm shivering from SF's unpredictable winds.  Next I'm heating up from a glass of beer.  This calls for ice cream.

It was a good day indeed as we found VIP parking AND there was a short line.  The scoopers were young folks with lots of energy and you could tell they were happy to work there.  We sampled a few flavors and although all of them were different and good, we narrowed it down to two.

Olive Oil & Lemon Custard on Waffle Cone- my favorite so far.  At first I was hesitant about the olive oil being to pungent but it wasn't at all.  The flavors blended well together.  Waffle cone is a must
Sightglass Coffee & Dandelion Chocolate - The coffee was strong and the chocolate was subtle

Great addition to the area.  Good service
author: Linda N.

description: Great array of inventive flavors. Think "chef-driven" ice cream. I opted for the specials -- Tokyo peanut butter and jelly and duck crackling with cherry preserves. Both tasted true to name and I'd never seen anything like the latter flavor elsewhere. Salt & Straw focuses on "handmade and interesting" flavors and the quality and variety of flavors prove that point. I will say that the texture of the ice cream was not as smooth as I had hoped -- some bits were slightly icy or the mix-ins were tough. I'll probably opt for simpler flavors next time I visit, but I'll more likely wait in line at Humphrey Slocombe or Bi-Rite before I make my way back.
author: Edwina D.

description:
I've been to some of the other popular ice cream spots in SF, but they were all average and I didn't have a favorite...until I tried out Salt & Straw.

My friend and I walked over after getting drinks on Polk St around 9:30pm on a random (and not to mention chilly) Wed night, and I was shocked to see that there was still a pretty decent line at this time. The line wasn't quite to the corner but it was close. We probably waited for ~25 min or so before it was our turn to order.

I loved our server. I forgot her name but she was soooo patient and helpful. Since we had so much time to peruse the menu while standing in line, we knew exactly which flavors we wanted to try, and there were quite a few of them. But our server was super nice about it and didn't make us feel like she was trying to rush us in any way despite the long line behind us, which I cannot appreciate enough.

I ended up getting a single scoop in a cone with the Chocolate Gooey Brownie. I enjoy chocolate ice cream when it's not overly bitter, and here it's done perfectly right with the most delicious brownie chunks mixed in. I was in chocolate heaven. This was my favorite among all the flavors I tried, though another classic flavor (Sea Salt Caramel Ribbons) came close.

I personally am not a fan of coffee, but my friend tried it and he said it was the strongest tasting coffee ice cream he's ever had. Might be worth a try for all you caffeine aficionados out there!

Also watch out for the size, the scoops and cones here are ginormous! Don't say I didn't warn you. We were already full from dinner and drinks, and honestly it was a bit of a struggle to finish the whole thing. If I didn't love the chocolate brownie ice cream as much as I did, I might have only tried half as hard to finish it all.

Parking in this area is all street. I'm glad we walked over and didn't have to worry about parking, since I've had problems finding parking on Fillmore before.
author: Dianna H.

description: Waffle cone with roasted strawberry tres leches and coffee scoops and sprinkles. Roasted strawberry was super flavorful the jelly swirled throughout tasted like a fresh strawberry. Coffee was distinct and I think it was mixed with a chocolate of some kind which came through and didn't compete with the coffee.
author: Heather L.

description:
Wow! One  of rare times I write a review before posting photos first.  I welcome this Portland Oregon ice cream  shop to San Francisco and it is up to par with the other ice cream places already in SF. It's different by offering a wide selection of unique flavors and mixtures. You won't find boring ordinary flavors here.  The homemade texture is creamy and soft. The infusion of unique and specialized ingredients like using popcorn  butter from Roxie theater to make ice cream is pretty unique and stands out from other ice cream shops. 

When you first walk in, the aroma of fresh waffle cones being made fills the little take out shop that has short line forming this early Sunday Afternoon.  I could just inhale all day and get into a sugar waffle cone high. One board has SF classic flavors, second board had the rotating limited edition menu that uses ingredients that are meant to be thrown away, but they found flavors that work well together to eliminate waste (good job! ) and last two boards has Sundaes, floats, milkshake and even tasting flights! 

The scooper girl was bright and cherry and saw I was struggling with what flavors to choose and offered me to sample. It was nice sample size. I tasted two and went with their popular fan favorite Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches (Oxnard strawberries, salt, sweet cream,  cake pieces, and swirled with tres leches and strawberry vanilla jam) and the tasty  Olive Oil & Lemon Custard (Berkeley Olive Grove, cream, and homemade lemon curd. 
I splurged and ordered that fresh waffle cone for $1.25 and glad  I did. I was surprised the scoops were so big after I had my big lunch at WoodHouse, but I managed to finish that wholesome of sweet goodness!  Yummy  in my tummy. Ice cream ! 

I would like to return to try more flavors and if I happen to be in Portland or Los Angeles, I will look them up because the flavors are different as I am reading from their website.
author: Priscilla L.

description:
Seriously the best ice cream ever! I will go here anytime I'm in town or there is one around. I've been to the one in LA and I experienced the same outstanding customer service which is hard to come by. 
Of course the line was out the door, but always worth the wait. 
I tried more of their seasonal flavors this time around and learned the small cones are complimentary!
author: Nicole G.

description:
I've been running through the jungle
I've been running with the wolves
To get to you, to get to you
I've been down the darkest alleys
Saw the dark side of the moon
To get to you, to get to you

Seriously I would run through a jungle, (Maybe a slow skip. Running is kinda reaching.) befriend some wolves, (If I don't get eaten first.) and walk down some ghetto looking alleyways just for some good ice cream. Some people think it's way too cold in the Winter to eat anything frozen, but ice cream is just too good to skip an entire season for. Yes, it will go down your throat and spread the stinging cold throughout your stomach, veins, and arteries. However that creamy sweet taste on your tongue is totally priceless. In the end, it is worth it and no one ever regrets eating ice cream. 

This Salt & Straw shop is located on Fillmore Street in the Pacific Heights area of San Francisco. This is the first shop to open in the Bay Area. There's a second one in Hayes Valley which is a little bit bigger. There's a lot of street parking around; some with meters and if you park further around the residential areas, there's spaces without meters running. 

Salt & Straw is the super popular artisanal ice creamery from Portland, Oregon. They first opened shops in California in Los Angeles. They offer a variety of different flavors which people probably wouldn't think would work as ice cream. They also have different seasonal flavors each month. This month they have flavors like Butter Roasted Chestnut and Peppermint Cocoa for the holidays. I'm not that into the seasonal flavors so I got an Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache. The pieces of ganache were really big and bitter. It wasn't for me but I still finished it. The almond part was good. I will probably go with my usual flavors next time; Honey Lavender or Sightglass Coffee with Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate. The line is usually out the door, but it moves fast. The employees really know how to expedite. While we were in the queue, there we were already doing some sampling so that we would be ready to order asap. I'll be back when I'm in the area!
author: Julie W.

description:
The ice cream here is pretty bomb.com! Upon arriving at the shop, one can see the line to getting the ice cream wrapping around the shop. You can see the line from a block away, crossing the the street to the shop, I had to go a little ways around to the end of it to get my spot. The wait isn't too long, it might feel like an eternity, but the wait goes by quickly.

The shop has some of the standard flavors of ice cream. But it really specializes in the seasonal and abstract flavors. They have flavors that aren't too out of the ordinary, but you would be really surprised with that ice cream flavor combination. The ice cream itself is very smooth. The flavors work well with the cones. I really enjoy the waffle cones. The waffle cones are toasty and crispy and go well with the multiple scoops of silky smooth ice cream. Even with the long lines, I would totally wait in line on a hot day for some Salt and Straw's! Good ice cream with great company!
author: Brandon D.

description:
Wow! I hadn't had their ice cream since first tasting it in Portland a few years ago. I remember trying their salted caramel sea salt and it was the best of that flavor I've ever had. 

Flash forward, this is definitely a wonderful and much needed addition to the SF ice cream scene. The July special flavors were so dope! I tried them all! 

I ordered the cheese strawberry and bday cake + blackberry.

Their ice cream so is so creamy and not super sweet! The in house made waffle cone is crispy and buttery.
author: Shruti D.

description:
Hmmm. This is tricky. Got pints to take home when it first opened because the lines were down the block. You can walk in and get pints without waiting in line. The pints were delicious. The staff was exceedingly friendly and accommodating. However, I went back and got a cone of the roasted strawberry and tres leches and it was gooey and sticky and left me feeling disgusting. I'm just sticking with Three Twins from the grocery store I decided.

UPDATE:
OK so it is January and I just went back. There was no line so we tried several flavors. January 2018, there are vegan flavors for the flavors of the month and they are delicious. They have a strawberry coconut vegan flavor year round we also tried and you can always get that.  The vegan flavors also have gluten free brownies and cookies and my youngest was just diagnosed with celiacs abs my husband can't have dairy so we were very happy today. I think I'll stay away from the tres leches as I think it is just too much for me but I am definitely converted now.  Many delicious flavors and the vegan varieties are fantastic. My husband is happily digging into the pint tonight after years of no ice cream. My son is picky and he liked every vegan flavor too.  Begged me to buy pints.


The staff is consistently amazing. Always nice and efficient. I've been on several times with my kids as we live around the corner and I have always been impressed with the staff. Today the young man was excellent. We tried to many flavors and he patiently waited on us hand and foot with a big smile.
author: Nettie A.

description:
Excellent and creative flavors that tend towards neutral or savory and not excessively sweet. Nice people who let you try every flavor without judgment until you find the one(s) that are just right for you. 

No lines at 5pm on a Friday. Lines out the door by 730pm.
author: Judy C.

description: One of my favorite icecream places in SF! Love their interesting flavors! They always change it up to different seasonal flavors but my go to is honey lavender! So good!!
author: Theresa H.

description:
Awesome flavor combinations mixed with absolutely wonderful employees that smile, love their job, and can answer any questions you have leads to a super cool experience for me and my friends as well as a guaranteed future return from all of us! Salt and Straw was originally from Oregon but we are frikken absurdly happy that we now have one present in San Francisco. Thanks for considering us! They're usually open pretty late I would guess because we visited at 11PM on the night of 4th of July. It made a great end to a super cool night. Super cool. :) 

If you haven't been, you must be soon.
author: Murray N.

description:
Good ice cream but nothing worth going batshit over.

Plenty non-generic flavors, typical texture, friendly staff, generous AF tasting spoons. Fortunately lines are a few hrs shorter than the original in Portland because sf has got places to redistribute the hype lines every other block.
author: Tian Q.

description: It's good.  Like other Yelpers have noted, it's the new kid in a town that has great ice cream havens.  This one I think joins the lot.  The flavors I think are more limited and the ones they have are more subtle with deep flavors.  Pretty good stuff.
author: Ronny T.

description:
Pretty darn good! One of my new top ice cream shops in the city. I tried the salted malted chocolate chip cookie dough.. a mouthful right?! I thought so too, I had a hard time saying it. This was alright, a little bit too salty for my taste. I then tried the sea salt with caramel ribbons because I'm a huge fan of caramel. MA DAM. This was good, I wanted to try other flavors, but didn't want to go too crazy, so I stopped there and got a single scoop of the sea salt with caramel ribbons in a waffle cup. The waffle cup was so good! It was the perfect addition to my ice cream. It's a little pricey, but not too bad, worth!

I'll be back to try the other flavors!
author: Eva C.

description: I think by now we all know that salt & straw has amazing ice cream. It's personally my favorite ice cream in the whole city. However, I think what I truly love about getting ice cream there is that the staff is really remarkable. They are always pleasant no matter how many flavors you ask to try, and they give you their thoughts and share in your excitement about flavors. The whole ice cream eating experience is enhanced by them, which is what makes it taste even better. Also, do yourself a favor and make sure to try the strawberry tres leches and the salted, malted chocolate chip cookie dough. It will not disappoint!
author: Sonia S.

description: Wow. So I've had Salt & Straw on my "List" for a while and out of a plethora of ice cream spots I've been wanting to go to in San Francisco, I made this one a stop on my last trip. I got a small cup of the roasted strawberry tres leches ice cream (with rainbow sprinkles). I eat a lot of ice cream -- and I can say without hesitation that this is Top 5 for best ice cream I've ever had. I wish I had gotten more. It was so creamy, the strawberry flavor was outstanding, and the tres leches cake pieces just put it over the top. It's been two days and I'm STILL thinking about this ice cream so if you're ever in the area: GO HERE!
author: Tayler K.

description:
Who had ice cream for dinner? This gal.

I didn't even taste the ice cream yet and I was already wooed by the menu. Who wouldn't want to know what ribbons of caramel tastes like? Or what Elvis's birthday is all about? There are sundaes and scoops and cones. There's a classic menu and specials menu. It's a lot to take in.

You can bypass the line of taste testers if you have a pint in hand. It's good business strategy and it just keeps the line a little more fluid. Otherwise, the staff is happy to provide samples to your heart's delight.

My favorite (as if I've been here that often, but I feel so acquainted with the ice cream that I'm going on a limb here to call favorites) is the almond brittle and sightglass coffee. They're creamy concoctions bursting with flavor, sweet to taste of course, but just perfectly so. You can SMELL the ice cream, and together with the taste on your tongue, it's really undeniable how aromatic it is.

Clearly I'm smitten (or not harhar).
author: Cici T.

description:
My boyfriend and I went on a Thursday afternoon and luckily there was a small line! There's so many different unique flavors than your typical ice cream place! It ranged from Honey lavender to sea salt with caramel ribbons. We opted for the Honey Lavender with a waffle cone! 

The Honey lavender was a huge hit! It was the perfect amount of Honey and Lavender, it complimented each other well :) The waffle cones are made fresh and it was delicious! Best waffle cone I've had! 

Definitely worth the wait!
author: Katty X.

description: Trendy neighborhood ice cream joint with wonderful and unique flavors.  Greeted with a big friendly smile from Alexis offering samples and even giving his suggestions.  Good job Alexis thanks for taking care of us on our first visit. We will definitely be back for more!
author: M J.

description:
Finally was able to find time to come on a week day to check out what all the fuss is about. Boy oh boy was I impressed! From the store decor to the customer service to the ice cream--WOW! 

As it gets to your turn, someone actually walks out from behind the counter to greet you and help you with your order. You can sample as many of the flavors as you want and trust me, I sampled about half of their very extensive selection of unique and original flavor combinations. We decided on the flight which gives you one scoop each of four flavor choices. We got the Wild Foraged Berry Sherbet, Lavender Honey, Peach Vinegar Cobbler with Toasted Nutmeg, and Goat Cheese Marionberry Habanero. I loved every single one!!! 

If you come on a day where the line is wrapped around the corner and you just don't want to wait an hour for ice cream, you can go to the side to grab a pint and head straight to the cashier to pay. Worth the wait just to try all the flavors though!!! 

Street parking in this neighborhood is always tough but there is a little metered lot right across the street from Mollie Stones. Yes, you'll pass by Smitten on the way but don't stop there! Head to Salt and Straw for a scoop instead! This place is fantastic!
author: Betty R.

description:
What's not to love about Salt & Straw? They take the whole ice cream experience to a new level. 

First, waffle cone smell wafts from across the street, beckoning you inside. If you were trying to resist, it's game over. You have to indulge. 

Next, you walk in to a beautiful store (hopefully with a short line) and the flavors are unique and enticing. From Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches to Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache, the options can be overwhelming, but don't worry, the employees are super friendly and accommodating and will let you sample whatever you're curious to try. 

I chose the Rhubarb Crumple with Toast Anise. It was just the right amount of sweet with pieces of crumble inside the generous scoop - it tasted like pie! They have monthly flavors as well as classic SF flavors (with sightglass coffee and dandelion chocolate). 

I left very content, dreaming of coming back soon.
author: Shira W.

description:
I loved salt and straw when I was in Portland and I'm so glad that this shop finally opened up! Ive been here a few times since it's opened! Parking at night is actually pretty easy especially when you have dinner nearby! The shop is small and it has a grab and go kind of feel since there isn't much seating! I like how you can also grab pints to go and skip the lines if you know what you like! 

Probably the best part is the monthly seasonal menu changes! They are so creative and I have actually liked many of the seasonal ones! 

Top faves: olive oil and lemon custard, roasted strawberry tres leches, peach cobbler , honey lavender and salted honey marshmallow.

Seasonal faves: green apple mayo sherbert, cascara shrub with candied hibiscus, carmelized almond smores, rhubarb crumble with toasted anise, wildflower honey with ricotta lace cookies and sasparilla&a dandelion root beer float

I usually get a single scoop that split with two flavors and I also get a fresh waffle cone as well! It may get a bit pricy but it's totally worth it!

Total for 1: $7
author: Stella J.

description: I just love their ice cream. The staff was more than friendly and I've taken the freckled mint and the peach & vanilla bean (monthly specials). Both were delicious and the freshly baked waffle cone is to die for. Looking forward to my next visit.
author: Daniela S.

description:
4.5 stars. A fantastic addition to the ice cream scene in San Francisco. 

Pro: 

- unique and complex flavor. True to the names it represents and taste like real flavors with the best ingredients rather than artificial flavors. 

- you can try as many flavors as you want before getting your ice cream. I tried about 7 flavors before deciding 

Con: the consistency is a bit more on the stickier side. 

Tip: the line can be 45 minutes long. Come 15 minutes before it closes and usually there is no line. 

After trying almost all of the flavors over time, my favorites were honey lavender and matcha with black raspberry. Strawberry tres leche is solid as well. The honey lavender was fragrant, subtle, and elegant in flavor. The matcha ice cream was subtle in flavor with the sour tart accents from the black raspberry. The strawberry tres leche had chunks of strawberry and the flavor was exactly like the strawberries from the farmer's market (intense, sweet, sour, and raw).

The scoops are huge here. I usually get the kid size and it's more than enough. (They can do two flavors with the kid size).
author: Rebecca C.

description:
i got the salted honey marshmallow with walnuts. YUM. hubby got the salted one with caramel, which was just a bit too salty for me.

all of the ice cream is super rich. no surprise there, right? what really did it for me:

unique flavors!
WAFFLE CONE fresh pressed right there. now that's a way to a girl's heart. 

i'll be back to try the banana bread pudding flavor they have at the moment...
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Salt & Straw, I've been waiting for you (in a non creepy way).

If you aren't familiar with it, Salt & Straw comes from Portland (one of the best cities ever). It was always a must have every time I'd food trip there for the weekend. The lines were always worth the wait and the pints crammed into my freezer were rationed appropriately. After leaving Seattle, sadly, Portland food trips were no longer accessible for weekend getaways and I thought of Salt & Straw like a long lost love. 

Fast forward to the anticipation of opening day. Friend from Seattle and I blocked our work calendars off for a couple of hours for lunch and played hookie to brave the line and have ice cream for lunch. She too, feels like SF ice cream culture is lacking and we're both sooo excited Salt & Straw is our new go to. 

Now that it's here, there really is no competition in this city anymore. Salt & Straw is always a winner!

My only non complaint complaint is that the waffle cone is meh. However, I can't even tell you what my go to flavor is. Actually, I take that back. The lemon curd olive oil has been 1/2 split scoops the last few times I've been (since I'm obsessed with citrus and all). You can't go wrong though, they are all ahhhmazing especially with the generous scoop sizes. I usually split scoop so I can get more than one (duh!).

Anyways, if you haven't been you're legit missing out. It's fine if you don't believe me, keeps the line short ;)
author: Shereen A.

description:
I was in Pac Heights for a haircut with Addison and wandered around the streets per usual because being in SF gives me every excuse to get my cardio on walking up hills..  Only problem is I get distracted by things like food.  And when I could see a line and smell waffle cones, my temptation to stop in was too hard to resist.  What cardio?  I see Ice Cream.  

I pulled up my Yelp app and see the reviews and it was a done deal.  I convinced my friends to wait in line with me just so I could get my sweet tooth fix.  While waiting in line, I found that this place was from Portland and that they added interesting ingredients like mayo and vinegar to their flavors.  What?!   

I'm not one to be shy to ask for samples and the gal behind the counter made sure that we didn't feel guilty asking.   First thing I noticed was *real* silver spoons to sample the ice cream.  This was a first for me.  Usually Ice Cream joints use plastic spoons to throw away in the trash.  What a way to reduce waste and be classy!!  

It was after I tasted the SF Seasonal Flavors that I had made my decision..

Wildflower Honey with Ricotta Walnut Lace Cookies:  Super creamy, light taste of honey and the ricotta cheese made it super interesting.. The cookie bits were just enough to give it texture. Not super sweet which I appreciated.

Rhubarb Crumble with Toast Anise:  First off, I have no idea what Anise is.  But once I tried this flavor, I didn't care.. It was vanilla ice cream with Rhubarb jam swirled in giving it that perfect tartness I love to offset the sweet vanilla.. My mouth is watering just thinking about this one..  Think a la mode only the pie is already in the ice cream and not on the side.  Ahhhhh.

You must not let the line scare you.  Wait.. Try samples with the real silver spoons.  Be delighted.   Enjoy.
author: Lorie N.

description:
I have been to Portland, Oregon a half dozen times. But I have never visited or eaten at the Salt and Straw ice cream parlor. I know, I am a lousy and useless yelper; so don't rub it in. 

The newest Salt and Straw and first in the Bay area has only opened a month ago (April 14, 2017).   And what an impressive debut it was, with a line with ice cream-lovers stretching well beyond the block. 

After a 15 minute wait in line, I was looking at the available flavors on the menu. I decided to order a scoop of double-folded vanilla and a scoop of gooey chocolate brownie in a store-made waffle cone. A double-folded vanilla is basically the seed and the oil in the strand of bean and adds extra flavor in the vanilla ice cream. It is definitely a difference-maker. And the gooey chocolate brownie has chunks of brownies and drizzle of the chocolate sauce. The two scoops in a waffle-cone made my $8.50 treat a decadent one. 
For $11.00, I also took home of a pint of rhubarb crumble with anise for a later treat. This is a seasonal flavor and I love rhubarb too. 

I came here on a Monday afternoon, which the wait was not too bad. Assumingly the line and wait at other times can be much lengthier. 

San Francisco has done a great job of bringing some of the other cities' institution to the Bay. Like I mentioned in some of my other reviews, San Francisco still needs to bring Voodoo's Doughnuts, Killer Burgers and Pine State Biscuits here. And then I would never fly to Portland, Oregon.
author: Matt G.

description:
YUMMM. Call me easy if you wish, but all it takes to make me happy is ice cream!  

Here's my take on the flavors I sampled:

HONEY LAVENDER - tasted like flowers but it wasn't bad
COFFEE - pretty good but too salty. Chocolate chunks gave it a good consistency 
MOCK APPLE - Canned apples. Again, too salty 
STRAWBERRY - This was delicious!  Tasted like a strawberry cheesecake 

Came here at 7 on a Saturday night and the line wrapped around the building. The line moved decently quickly and we were in the front in about 20 minutes. The list of flavors were also taped to the side of the building so you can figure out what flavor you'd like to get as you're waiting in line. 

They're not stingy on the samples or on the scoops!   My bf and I sampled about 4 ice creams all together before finally deciding to share a single scoop. Their scoops were MASSIVE. It's basically two regular sized scoops and it was more than enough for the two of us to share. If you get a double, you're basically getting 4 small scoops. 

I thought a lot of their ice cream were too salty I know. Salt & Straw. I should expect it to be salty lol. But I'm more of a sweet treat gal, so I didn't really  enjoy salty ice cream.   If I'm in the area, I'll be back for some cones and strawberry ice cream, but this is never something I'll find myself craving.
author: Destynnie T.

description:
So disappointed I had to give this 2 star rating because I gave all Portland S&S locations 5 stars with no hesitation

I was so excited to hear of S&S coming to the bay area as my first time trying it was at Portland. Over there, lines out the door up until closing time of 11pm, in cold weather. It's THAT good

For those who've never been to S&S, they are very focused on the experience. They take your entire party and have a dedicated associate work with you to provide samples. You sample however many flavors you want, you can even sample the entire menu if you really wanted to. What this means is that the line builds up and moves slowly, just be prepared for this. Some people like this and think it's worth the trade off, some don't

So I asked to sample 2 flavors and the associate handed me the samples. I finished one, and before I put the second sample into my mouth, the he asked me, "is there anything else you'd like to try?" Well hmm.. maybe.. if you give me some time to finish this first sample and start the second sample. I felt like I was being rushed. What I would have liked to see is him giving me more time to sample, enjoy, and think about the flavor profile so I can decide if I like it or not. 

At the end, I got the sea salt caramel. When I got an entire scoop, I was able to see that the caramel to ice cream ratio was way off. absolutely way too high. The caramel should be enhancing the flavor of the ice cream, but it was the other way around. It looked pretty bad too, like i was eating a brown/white sludge. Not appetizing at all

This is a new location so I'm sure they're still figuring things out. I would like to come back some time after hearing some positive reviews from my friends so I can give this place a better rating
author: Jonathan T.

description: Found parking 8pm on same block so we decided to wait in line.  Line was out the door, but only about 5 min until we were indoor and sheltered from the evening SF wind.  It is worth the wait!  Their specialty flavors taste like it should be a meal - sweet yet the flavor profile is reminiscent of curry or duck confit.  It's strange yet interestingly appealing.  Their classics flavors are simply good ice cream upped one level with a "je ne sais quoi".  No wonder they have lines out the door.  We are so coming back!
author: Mimi E.

description:
OVERALL: So excited this Portland fave is now in SF!
 
THE WAIT: Long! The line was out the door on a Saturday at 11am. It was about 30-45 minutes til we got to the front.
 
THE SERVICE: Really nice, even with the long line they allowed several samples (maybe contributing to the long wait). They were ok with my dog being in there (and a couple others!).
 
THE FOOD: 
Loved the Olive Oil & Lemon Custard and Salted Honey Marshmallow & Walnuts! They have such intriguing flavors, it's hard to decide.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
SO. MANY. FLAVORS!  And not just that; they all were delicious!

Backdrop:  One of my friends from out of town visited and I somehow convinced her to take an Uber to Fillmore and try out this spot after dinner in May.  

Venue: inside had a quaint feel to it (maybe it was the light making the interior glow yellow).  There aren't many seats inside, so be prepared to stand / walk outside while eating your ice cream.  Also be prepared for 1) long lines and 2) long periods of wait time.  The reason is because (as explained below) there are so many interesting flavors to try and most people ended up tasting multiple.  My friend and I got there around 8:15 probably waited for 25 min?

Ice cream pickings:  like I said, there are sooooo many flavors to taste / choose from, which can be overwhelming for the indecisive mind.  You have a few classics like vanilla, sea salt caramel, and chocolate, but there are some pretty wacky flavors (ie honey lavender, olive oil and lemon, flower sherbert, etc.).  My friend and I probably ended up tasting 10 flavors total before making up our minds.  

Taste: my friend went with the olive oil and lemon ice cream, which I surprisingly found super refreshing.  The ice cream itself wasn't too sweet (olive-oil flavored), but the strips of lemon custard were all that was needed to bring both sweetness and acidity to the ice cream.

As with other ice cream shops, I judge based on their simple flavors.  As much as I loved the honey lavender (where you could actually taste the lavender) and the salted honey marshmellow + walnuts (great texture and the salt is a great cleanser to the overall sweetness), I ordered their plain Double Fold Vanilla in a waffle cone (~$5.50). Waffle cone was crispy but not burnt and still had a bit of chewiness you associate with a waffle.  The ice cream is to die for.  The vanilla was a bit more creamy than other places I've been too, but the vanilla flavor comes through very well and wasn't too sweet, how I like it.  Thank god I ordered a kid-sized scooped- I might have passed out with a bigger scoop.

Tips:
- Be prepared to wait for a while in line
- Don't judge people for taking forever deciding what they want to order... you're gonna have a tough time deciding what you want yourself
- TASTE!!  You never know if you'll like something, even if it sounds kinda weird / gross
- If you have a small stomach or are coming for dessert after a meal, consider a kid-sized portion- the ice cream here tends to run a little rich so a smaller size might do your stomach good and prevent you from entering a food coma
author: Audrey H.

description:
Make sure to taste  as many flavors as your curiosity desires--the staff here is friendly and want you to be happy with your order.

1 star gets bumped off because the interior is too sterile and not cozy to match the ice cream's sensuousness.

Ras El Hanout is a flavor you might not guess would make it on the menu of an ice cream parlor. Imagine Moroccan spices swirled with pickled rose and salt... hard to, right? It's beyond belief. Yet, the flavor is very straightforward, very "normal", and very delicious. The same experience with other items on the menu.

One further note, do the split scoop to be totally satisfied and not totally overfed.
author: John G.

description:
Waited about an hour to get ice cream! Not gonna lie, as we were heading out, an older couple asked my sister and I if we had waited in line and if it was worth the wait, and... I couldn't say yes. I've been to the original Salt & Straw in Portland and loooved it. A group of my friends from church wanted to stop by after lunch to try the new SF branch. We had great company but overall the hour wait kinda lessened the experience for me. 

PROS
+Staff is friendly. Good & happy vibes all around.
+Can take your time sampling as many flavors as you like! 
+DELICIOUS FLAVORS! My favs are the Sea Salt & Caramel Ribbons and Honey Lavender. Also Sightglass Coffee. Can't go wrong with coffee ice cream. 
+Get the split scoop (+.50 cents) and you can get two flavors for the size of one scoop!
+Scoops are HUGE!

CONS
-Line moves really slowly since everyone is sampling dozens of flavors. Literally. 

I'll come back once the novelty dies down.
author: Grace J.

description:
There isn't a more San Francisco thing to do than waiting in line on a chilly night for some ice cream. 

It was about a 50 minute wait for a Thursday night around 8:40pm (the line ended at the corner) 
When we left around 9:40 (they close at 10pm) the line got helllla longer (way past the corner)(https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?

What I appreicated is the workers were friendly and generous with the samples. (3 samples only please - people waiting). 

I had TWO FULL SCOOP ON A WAFFLE CONE (RHUBARD CRUMBLE w/TOASTED ANISE) and (WILDFLOWER HONEY w/RICOTTA WALNUT LACE COOKIE) and there were thick chunks of rhubard, very creamy ice cream, pricey but yeah, delicious. 

**PROTIP for FIRST TIMERS**
**. Bypass the line buy going strait inside towards the right of the store, there's a little gift shop area (t shirts, mugs, candies, carmels, etc) as well a cooler of ice cream. It's $11 for a pint vs $5 for a scoop in a cup. The register is to the left of the massive line of people waiting to sample and order.  

**MENU (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=huZtSNqsCTEmpWi24dbP4Q&userid=pDfL8xt8F8ls0-kQIG_ADg)

Happy that S&S finally came down from Portland. I'd say it's worth the hype if you aren't in a rush.
author: Earl G.

description:
My annual trip to Portland is never complete without a taste of Pear and Blue Cheese from Salt and Straw (too bad this classic is only in Portland).

A beautiful sunshine weekend to get Salt and Straw, despite the horde of crowd sampling every flavors and holding up the line. 

Top flavors to put on my sugar cone. Yes, I had TRIPLE SCOOP OF ICE CREAM!!!

1) Rhubarb Crumble with Toast Anise

2) Raspberry Liqueur & Edible Flowers Sorbet

3) Honey Lavender


Other worthy flavors to try:

- Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches

- Olive Oil & Lemon Custard


I gave props to the nice girl scooping my ice cream and trying her best to make it not drop. Thank you!!

I really hope you give one of my favorite ice cream place a try. Cheers!

The simple things in life.
author: Owie N.

description: Great, original flavors, but didn't have the mouthfeel of other places in SF, namely Mitchells
author: Nihar P.

description:
My 72nd Grand Opening review!

While I arrived in San Francisco yesterday on 4/29/2017, this newest ice cream shop located at Fillmore Street that has everyone is talking & hyping about it for days! It's called, "Salt & Straw." Opened since mid-April 2017, Salt & Straw serves the customers from young to old to taste their interesting and irresistible handmade ice creams at any time despite the massive popularity fan base while waiting in a single line every day and night! The atmosphere is very laid back and active as I welcomed there. The concept is much modern and contemporary filled with well known vintage designs and cleaner interior space!

The employees here are doing an excellent job for making the customers like me a sensational service due to their busiest environment. No cons at all!

Now onto the treat! Despite that I got waited in line for nearly an hour, I decided to order a pint of ice cream (costs $11) instead, so I ordered a pint sized ice cream flavor of "Double Fold Vanilla." As I ate it, that ice cream tasted sensational! It's much flavorful for the vanilla and the creamy texture is much smoother and easier to release. Not bad at all!

Parking at Salt & Straw can be quite challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street parking if it's available. If the lines are getting much longer with the longest waiting time, you can park at the nearby parking garage too. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

To conclude, Salt & Straw is the most amazing and spectacular national ice cream shop that I've ever experienced the most! I'll be back next time in the near future to try their other flavors around before the business hours open! A must visit! My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description:
Came here on the recommendation of a friend. I am trying to make a tour of all the best ice cream shops in the city. Super friendly and helpful staff. They tell every  customer that they can try as many flavors as they want. This is the first ice cream place that I've been to where they actually make it a point to come out and say that. 

I tried a ton of flavors. Many of them were quite good. I had a hard time choosing. I tried so many flavors that I only had room for a single scoop. I ended up with the Birthday cake Boysenberry. It is one of their special July flavors. I got it with what was perhaps the best waffle cone that I've ever had! 

So, come here, try a ton of flavors, pick your favorite one or two, and get the waffle cone!
author: Sean A.

description: A must when you are in the city. The flavors are not your regular kind. The combination of flavors is just beyond words. Make sure you get the big waffle.  Staff is friendly.
author: Paola K.

description:
Wowee, a Salt & Straw in my hometown!

The hype is real.

I fell in love with Salt & Straw back in Portland 2014. It was probably the game-changing ice cream of the day - Bi-Rite was around in SF, but was already getting overplayed. At the time, it was super refreshing to try something new with such exotic and bold flavors! I was sad when I flew back to SF knowing there wasn't a Salt & Straw in SF. Then, that fall I moved to LA. Turns out, so did Salt & Straw! My ice cream dream came true! It was a great 2 years in LA and then once again the tables turned. I moved back to SF, and now Salt & Straw has followed me once again!!!

This ice cream shop has ~10 classic flavors, and ~10 monthly specialty flavors that switch out every month. What I mean by classic is that they stay at the ice cream shop forever, and never switch out. They're basically the same flavors that they have in Portland, LA, and SF. However, they make slightly changes, for instance for the coffee flavor, they use Sightlcass (local SF coffee shop) instead of Stumptown (Portland coffee shop). What makes their ice cream shop stand out compared to others is their monthly specialty flavors, which are forever changing. This is a great and bad thing. You may find the best flavor of your life in the monthly special section, but it may disappear forever after the 30th!

My favorite classic flavor is the caramel & sea salt ribbons. Can't go wrong with that one! The other amazing one is the roasted strawberry tres leches. Yums! I'd have to say that they have pretty bold flavors too, and I can see why some people would get turned off by them. For instance, not at this particular ice cream place, but in LA for November, they had Thanksgiving themed ice cream flavors, which were savory. It was a little bizarre, but IMO a fun experience.

Service is so very friendly! I did come here on a weekday at 11am when they opened, and we waited maybe 20 minutes in line, which was super frustrating (only 2 workers there). However, we came a weekday night around 9pm, and the line was around the corner, and took about the same amount of time since they had more workers. They let you try as many flavors as you want, which is super nice. They don't make you feel bad if you try more than 2. 

Scoops are on the expensive side, like 4.50/5 per scoop, which is always why it's better to opt for the double scoop for $7! If you buy a pint, they let you skip the line. That's a super nice benefit. The pints are $11 though...on the expensive side, but hey, this is delicious gourmet ice cream!!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I have now tried the Fillmore location and the location in WeHo and I love this place! My favorite flavor is the Sea Salt + Caramel Ribbons. At this point, it's probably better to go on off peak hours because every time I've walked past this place around 7-8pm the line is around the corner. I can tell you I'm not that dedicated to ice cream and I will walk down two more blocks to Smitten. 

I still like Smitten just as much but the flavors are more interesting at Salt & Straw versus Smitten. You also get more ice cream at S&S.
author: Adrianna L.

description:
The line is a bitch but it is so worth it if you have nothing else better to do. We went on a Saturday night around 9pm and the line was out the door around the corner to the end of bus stop. They had a lot of people working that night so it took about 45 minutes. Still long but not as bad as it had been apparently. The shop is really cute with cute knick knacks and snacks for sales. Also pro tip: They have pints of all their current flavors for $11 and you can skip the line and just pick them up buy them so if you don't have time, I recommend doing that. If you have the time, definitely wait in line because they let you try as many flavors as you want! My bf and I tried the Strawberry Tres Leches, Chocolate Brownie, and Salted Caramel. I ended up going with Strawberry and my bf did the chocolate brownie, both were delicious!

I would definitely come back but probably opt to skip the line and get a pint until the hype dies down a bit.
author: Alex S.

description:
Salt & Straw is now in my city and I couldn't be happier! I've been a fan ever since my first visit to Portland years ago and never thought they would open up shop here since we are definitely not lacking in ice cream options. Their honey lavender was life-changing, so of course I've had Salt & Straw bookmarked and knew I had to come as soon as I could. 

After having dinner at Umami Burger and doing some shopping on Union Street on a warm Saturday evening, we walked up Fillmore and could smell the fresh cones from a couple blocks away. There was a bit of a line wrapped around the corner but it wasn't too bad. What struck me was how diverse the crowd was - young, old, couples, and families. 

The 45-minute wait flew by quickly and before we knew it, we were greeted by an employee who offered us as many samples as we wanted to try. Many people were quite literally trying everything, which is most likely the cause for the long wait. We opted for the split single scoop in cups since we were still a bit full from dinner. We were really happy with our choices and can't wait to come back in a few weeks to see what new flavors will be on their monthly menu.

If you're in a rush, you can always skip the line and pick up one of their pints to enjoy at home!

My current rank:
1. TIE - Salt & Straw and Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous
2. Bi Rite
3. Garden Creamery
4. ShakeDown (in the Tenderloin...super underrated!)
5. TIE - Humphry Slocombe and Smitten
author: Olivia V.

description:
Salt & Straw is probably my favorite ice cream shop. I know, that's a blasphemous statement considering how much I love Bi-Rite, but after trying their creamy and locally-infused flavor creations in both LA and Portland, I was excited to see what they had to offer in the new SF location. I knew the wait would be long, especially shortly after the grand opening - we ended a little over an hour on a Sunday. 

Prices are notably more expensive than your typical ice cream shop. Single scoops will run $5, double scoops will run $7, split flavors will add on an extra $0.50 and those fresh waffle cones that you smell will tack on $1.25. But the premium ice cream appeals because of the locally-sourced ingredients and limited-time flavors of the month. Classic flavors at this location include Sightglass coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate. I ended up getting the salted honey marshmallow & walnuts and was not disappointed. You can also sample the flavors between committing, but I recommend going with a group as to not slow the process down (they give you a big spoonful, enough for 2-3 people to try). If you also feel like skipping the line and taking a pint home, there's a separate line on the left to grab and go.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Blechhhh way too sweet.  Another trendy expensive ice cream store that has to come up with crazy flavors and a marketing plan to overcharge for ice cream to pay for the expensive city rents and rising min wage.  1st there was Coldstone, then Smitten, and now this.  What happened to all the yogurt stores like Red Mango.  San Francisco is going to trend itself to death.  I miss the old Baskin Robbins which was actually across the street from this store decades ago.  Yes the lines are long, but this is just another trendy thing.  San Francisco has always been a leader in ice cream with Swensen's , Mitchells, Double Rainbow and even  It's-It.

Came here with nephew and niece because they hated the flavors at Smitten around the corner.  They did not like these either, but we got some and they didnt like it.  As is the case with these small batch players, there is a lack of consistency and the creative flavors are just interesting to make me curious but honestly it is like a fancy restaurant that does the complex things innovatively (Lavender) and is just okay on the basic stuff (Double Fold Vanilla).  I get how this place caters to the 20-somethings who want the next cool thing, but the kids all look at this basic dessert and cringe.  Who wants flowers in their ice cream?

If you think I know nothing, I grew up scooping Double Rainbow ice cream, my mother opened the authentic Gelato store from Italy back in the 90s in the Cannery and had high candy stores for over 2 decades that started one of SF's first great chocolatiers.

I'd rather head to Daly City and go to Baskin Robbins or Ben & Jerrys for cheaper ice cream that does the good stuff right and innovates for the long-term.
author: Erik H.

description:
FINALLY! IT'S HERE! SALT AND STRAW IS OPEN, IN THE BAY AREA!!! 

So yeah def expect a long line- even up until closing time.  I came around 10:30pm, just 30 min left until closing and there was still a wait. BUT the employees are super kind there! Very patient with customers and Lord knows I bet they deal with all types of people and personalities who are picky with their ice cream flavors.  Honestly though, it's only because they offer so many good ones and you just don't know what to pick. 
Their samples are generous too so you really get the full flavor experience. Awesome. But once you try a couple or 5, you'll probably have a hard time deciding which flavor you want and may end up just getting a flight (4 kid sized flavors) or something. HAHA jk. 
Pricey but worth the quality ice cream you're getting.

Visit and be amazed. Leave happy! :)
author: Tiffany Z.

description:
So stroked one finally opened up in the city. All the flavors are really unique so its really hard to pick just one. You can spend a good amount of time just sampling the flavors. I sampled only 3 flavors Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache, Peach Vinegar Cobbler with Toasted Nutmeg and Salted Honey Marshmallow & Walnuts. The peach cobbler was my final choice but all 3 are very good. I got the kid size because I had a pretty heavy meal before hand but man that kid size scoop was tiny and for $4 I expected a little more. 

Every month they have new limited flavors. This month (May) had a lot of flowery flavors, which I didn't really care for. When I went to the Portland location their flavors seem more interesting than the ones here. I thought this location was okay for ice cream but it is a bit pricy if you ask me.
author: Andrew T.

description:
Yes!!! Salt & Straw made it to SF! I went to the one in Portland and absolutely loved their ice cream. My wait time was only about 15 minutes around 2 something p.m. on a Sunday. I think the line was shorter than usual as opposed to the one in Portland because maybe peeps don't know how phenomenal the ice cream here is yet. Shhhhh...

Line moved very quickly and you can try as much flavors as you'd like! After all, you put in the wait time. Service is very friendly and they encourage you to try the different flavors.

I got a split scoop on a cone in the flavors Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons and in Rhubarb Crumble with Toast Anise (seasonal flavor)... so so good!!! 

Parking can be hard to find, but it's SF. Free street parking in the PAC Heights area on Sundays from what I saw. The PAC Heights area that Salt & Straw is located in is also very hip with stores like MAC, Benefit, Papyrus, and Athletica there to name a few.
author: Lin S.

description:
As a former resident and now visitor to SF, I was stoked to hear the city had opened a Salt & Straw location! I've heard SO many great things and was hyped up to give it a try. 

On a chilly Friday night, the line was out the door and around the corner, but as a group of 4 we gave it a try anyways. 

Many of the flavors sounded wild; I sampled the Fresh Cheese & Strawberries unsure at the beginning but it was delicious. My go to flavor is always a coffee based flavor, so I ended up going with that. It was delicious, but for all the hype I was jut slightly disappointed. Definitely worth it to try all the samples and hopefully find an even better flavor next time.
author: Suzy G.

description: I bookmarked them when I found a picture of their ice cream on yelp. I was excited to hear about them opening a branch in SF. I didn't get to visit until after a few months after opening day. It was just okay for me. The flavors were creative but overall everything was too sweet for me. Mind you, I have a healthy sweet tooth! The freshly baked waffle cones will lure you in like Hansel and Gretel. I even went a second time to see if it was an anomaly but nope the second time confirmed there would be no more future visits.
author: April L.

description:
Mmm I'm already drooling thinking about Salt & Straw. I'm so glad they finally opened in SF, so now I don't have to make the trip to LA or Portland. 
 
The menu of seasonal flavors is very unique and changes often. I came in around Thanksgiving season last year at the LA location and was surprised they had mashed potatoes and turkey stuffing ice cream! Even though it sounds strange, it tasted good. The ice cream is always creamy. However, I noticed that recently this location has more "ice flakes" in the ice cream, which can mean it's not as fresh. My favorites from the normal menu are chocolate gooey brownie, lavender, sea salt and caramel ribbons! Make sure to get it in the fresh waffle cone (+1.25) because it's the best cone ever. It's crunchy and sweet, which complements the ice cream well. The downside is the lines may wrap around the store, but it usually goes by pretty fast.
author: Michelle F.

description: Sooo I might be the only person who thinks this ice cream is meh. It's not because the ingredients aren't interesting or the texture isn't perfect - the flavors simply don't appeal to my taste buds. I find the flavor combos to be weird. I don't love vinegar and there were a few vinegar + sweet flavor combos. My top faves in the bay area are still Mitchell's and Bi-Rite.
author: Emily Y.

description:
Kind of a miss for me. I tried a single scoop of their Caramelized Almond Smores, and as much as I tried to enjoy the entire experience, the taste was pretty one dimensional. Nothing super exciting - tastes exactly how it sounds. Caramelized almonds in a vanilla base, lacking in the Smores flavor and texture department. Consistently sweet throughout. I wish they added in granules of salt or something to give the ice cream a pop of flavor, but overall it fell flat. 

Wish I'd tried the salted honey marshmallow with walnuts or the strawberry tres leches flavors!
author: Patricia Z.

description:
I loved Salt & Straw the first time I tried it in Portland and went back every single day I was there. It was that good, and I'm so glad it finally made its long-anticipated arrival in San Francisco.

I had intended to wait until the Hayes Valley location opened to benefit from shorter lines, but I'm glad I didn't. I stopped in yesterday on a sunny afternoon, and I was blown away (again) by their super original, delicious, and fun flavors. I got to try a handful of flavors, and we eventually settled on a double scoop of the roasted strawberry tres leches from the classic menu and the wildflower honey with ricotta walnut lace cookies from the May specials. They went together beautifully. :)

Beware, the scoops are huge--order accordingly.
