author: Kelly R.

description:
The ice cream here is great!!! They have vegan options and lots of great favors! I got the vegan strawberry and honey lavender. I tasted a lot of the other flavors as well and really liked them. The ice cream isn't too sweet unlike how some other places can be. The staff Is really friendly and nice! 
There is some nice counter seating as well but not that many spots, only about 7 seats. The big perk is that they open until 11 when most others close at 10!
author: Andrea W.

description:
Date & Time:  Friday April 14, 2017 @ 9:30pm
Wait Time:  I Hour
Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  Couples & Groups in Moto Jackets, Striped Joie Dresses & Ankle Boots
Decor:  Cute Ice Cream Shop w/ Limited Counter Seating
Service:  Enthusiastic, Friendly, Warm
Devour:  Apple Mayo, Strawberry Tres Leches
Mediocre:  Almond S'mores
Skip:  Freckled WoodBlocked Chocolate
Total:  $11.65
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
I'm a super basic b*tch when it comes to ice cream: Vanilla please! But, when I heard that Portland's finest ice cream shop serving experimental flavors was opening a location in San Francisco, I had to put aside those basic b*tch tendencies and live on the wild side...which these days isn't much. 

"I'll take a double gin & tonic, please!" Yah, I'm a snooze fest these days. 

Salt & Straw has 12 Classic flavors that's available year round: 
*Sea Salt w/ caramel ribbons
*Almond Brittle w/ salted ganache
*Double Fold Vanilla
*Chocolate Gooey Brownie
*Freckled Woodblock Chocolate
*Honey Lavender
*Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches
*Peach Vinegar Cobbler w/ toasted nutmeg
*Sightglass Coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate
*Olive Oil & Lemon Custard
*Salted Honey Marshmallow & Walnuts
*Ternaga Baobab Juice & Coconut (Vegan)

They also have 5 Limited Edition San Francisco flavors (rotates monthly). I love that they use locally sourced and organic ingredients for their SF flavors. For April, they have the following flavors: 
*Cinnamon Ancho & Cajeta
*Caramelized Almond S'mores
*Cascara Shrub w/ candied hibiscus
*Green Apple Mayo Sherbet
*Strawberry Coriander Leaf Sorbet (Vegan)

Single scoop: $5, double scoop: $7, kid's scoop: $4, tasting flight (4 flavors): $11.50. There's also grab and go pints: $11 if you want to skip the line. 

The super nice employee walked me though her favorite flavors, giving me a sample of each one. You're more than welcome to sample as many flavors as you want but please be mindful of the line. 

While the samples I tried were all good, I was living on the wild side today so ordered a Double Scoop: Green Apple Mayo & Peach Vinegar Cobbler w/ toasted nutmeg ($7 + $1.25 waffle cone): http://bit.ly/2ocFyNn.

Mayo? Vinegar? 

Yah, I know you're giving me the stank eye right now but these flavors were amazingly unique. Not only are they creative, the flavors work harmoniously and are delicious. I overheard there will be a bone marrow flavor in the future?! Can't wait for that...

The green apple mayo was like a vanilla custard with apple sauce - creamy and really refreshing. The Peach Vinegar Cobbler was wonderfully creamy, tart, and sweet with a nice nuttiness from the toasted nutmeg and good crunch from the crumble. 

And, with the sweet aroma of freshly made waffle cones wafting in the air, you better order your ice cream in a waffle cone for good measure.  

Aside from their uniquely delicious small batch, handmade ice cream, the staff is incredibly and genuinely nice...every one of them. One of the owners, Tyler made his way down the line introducing himself and answering questions about their various ice cream flavors. He even talked about where they sourced their ingredients and the background of those purveyors. The other owner, Kim thanked everyone in line and passed out her favorite caramels from Portland. Loved all the positive vibes and way to create customer loyalty. 

There's only 5 window counter seats so it's more of a to-go ice cream shop. 

ShakeDown "was" my favorite ice cream shop in SF (I'm one of the few who isn't crazy in love with Bi-Rite, Humphry Slocombe, or Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous) until today...

Salt & Straw has completely won me (and I'm sure many others) over with their ice cream quality, uniqueness, and top-notch service. No wonder they have such rave reviews for their Portland and SoCal locations.

Yes, the hype is real and the line is probably going to be crazy on the weekends (but they're pretty efficient so don't worry)...

I was waiting for my Lyft to get back to work and was enjoying my ice cream cone when a little girl was pulling her mom's shirt asking to try Salt & Straw's ice cream. Her mom said, "No, honey...the line is too long." 

The little one immediately gave me the evil eye.

Yup. *Ice Cream Envy*

I would have gladly shared but cooties...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Pros: Refreshing flavors, vegan options, excellent customer service 
Cons: long wait time and limited seating 

[The shop/Service] 
Love the interior design of this shop, but wish there was more seating. Granted, we came on a Friday night after Off the Grid so there was a pretty long line that rounded the corner. When we finally had our turn to pick out our flavors, the service was amazing. Our server was kind and patient (my boyfriend and I are super indecisive when it comes to flavors), she let us sample so many different flavors! 

[The ice cream] 
My boyfriend and I ended up sharing an ice cream flight which comes with 4 different flavors. It a really good investment if you're the type of person who doesn't want to commit to just one flavor. There was a generous amount in each scoop and it came on a really cute wooden panel with 4 cute bowls placed on it.  // 11.50 

-Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons: perfect mix of smooth and creamy with salty and sweet. We really enjoyed this flavor because we love salted caramel ice creams. 

-Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches: This one was my absolute favorite (and I also heard was their top seller). I LOVE the combination of strawberry ice cream combined with the tres leches cake. Decadently delicious!

-Rainbow Flower Sherbert: I wasn't sure if I was going to like this one since I usually don't like flower flavored things, but this one is an exception! The three different colors equated to honey lavender, orange blossom, and cherry hibiscus flavors and I really enjoyed them all! Each flavor was a fantastic surprise dancing on the tip of my tongue. 

-Wildflower Honey with Ricotta Walnut Lace Cookies: I want to say that I liked this one a lot, however initially it was my favorite till I got tired of it after a few bites. Could be that I'm not a fan of lemon hints to my ice cream. But it was still tasty nonetheless. 

Overall, the ice cream flight was a pleasant experience. It was a tad bit too crowded going on a Friday night so maybe an off night/time would be better.
author: Emily T.

description:
When you can't visit Portland (yet) so they bring Portland to you. 

I am so ecstatic that another ice cream eatery carrying honey lavender ice cream has made their way to San Francisco. 

Boyfriend and I wanted to try either Smitten or Salt and Straw. I instantly gravitated towards Salt and Straw because of their honey lavender ice cream.  

We got there around 6pm and there was a line wrapped around the building. yikes. BUT I'll do anything for some lavender ice cream so we waited even though it was a cold and windy evening. 

My boyfriend got the strawberry tres de leche which is basically a strawberry shortcake. He was upset because he loves strawberry ice cream but hates it when there is cake in it. Oops. Oh well. I really enjoyed it. It was very sweet though but satisfied my sweettooth. 

And of course, I got their honey lavender. OMG the lavender flavor is so strong which I LOVE. It was perfectly sweet. 

I got the sugar cone which I instantly regretted because it leaks. There is hole on the bottom. My boyfriend got the waffle cone and he had no leakage. 

We both got one scoop which was a perfect amount for dessert.
author: Yi Xian R.

description:
Had been anticipating the opening of Salt & Straw for quite a while, and it is finally in SF! After having their ice cream for the first time in Portland, we went back another time during our short visit, and then one of their LA locations. The line wasn't too bad on Friday nights, about 15 minute wait if coming early evenings, though the line grew quite a bit around 8pm. They were pretty efficient with their process from trying out flavors to ordering. I tried a few flavors, and usually committed to a split scoop ($0.5 more) of one sweet and one fruity/neutral flavor.

Flavors I've had as split scoop: honey lavender & caramelized almond s'mores - really liked the honey lavender, which was light yet flavorful and balanced well with other heavier flavors. Another time I had roasted strawberry tres leches & almond brittle with salted ganache. Strawberry flavor was the one I went back to their Portland location twice, but I was a bit disappointed by the SF flavor probably from the heavy sweetness. Other flavors I tried but did not get were overall heavier than I'd like. Would get honey lavender again! And try out other many flavors. They have seasonal flavors that change on a monthly basis with interesting unexpected ingredients, I was a bit scared to try but definitely something I'd consider next time :) Waffle cone was also fresh from the iron!

One thing I wanted to mention was their ice cream came a bit melted every time, wished it could be harder as I remembered other locations did. Not sure if it's their style, or some logistics to be worked out. Will be back for their variety of flavors and value (more ice cream per dollar compared to other SF ice cream shops) !
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
My favorite ice cream!!!  Salt and straw is my go to when I'm craving ice cream after dinner.  There's usually a line here, but it's really manageable and goes by pretty quick.  The service here is no different than any of the other Salt and Straws I've been too - everyone is super friendly and wants to make sure their customers are satisfied.  If it's your first time, definitely feel free to sample as many of their unique flavors as you want, and they'll serve you happily. 

Some of my favorite ice creams here are the Sea Salt w/ Caramel Ribbons, and the Honey Lavender.  They also have rotating limited edition flavors each month!  If you can't decide between two flavors, they also let you split a scoop into 2 different flavors, which is what I typically do.  

I highly recommend that you check this place out if you're ever around one.  When I had my first bite of Salt and Straw in LA a year ago, I knew I would never buy ice cream from my grocery store ever again.
author: Tim L.

description:
Believe the hype, the lines are a bit insane (can easily be 30+ mins on the weekends) since their SF opening a few weeks ago but is it worth it?  Yes!!  

The Mr. waited in the car while I patiently waited in the line that wrapped around the corner.  It helps that the menu of the regular classic favorites (offered all year around) and seasonal flavors (rotates monthly) are posted on the windows.  You can get an idea of what you will like to taste before reaching the counter.  If you are in a rush and cannot wait, consider buying their prepacked pints.  You can bypass the entire line and head right up to the counter off to the side, the same goes along with all their packaged goodies off to the side wall (cute display btw).

Quality ingredients sourced by local farmers in the area, I am so happy Salt & Straw made their way to SF.  Every bite is packed with fresh flavors and chunky toppings.  Before deciding on my 2 flavors for my double scoop ($7), I tried a few samples of both their classic (Almond Brittle w/ Salted Ganache and Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches) and  seasonal flavors (Caramelized Almond S'mores and Green Apple Mayo).  All 4 samples were so tasty, it was hard to decide.  Had there been more seating space, I probably would have dragged the Mr. in to get a tasting flight ($11.50) instead but it was quite busy for a Saturday afternoon.  It just gives me a good reason to come back again with him to try out more flavors. :)

I ultimately decided on a double scoop of the Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches and Chocolate Gooey Brownie.  The two went together very well and the lightness of the chocolate did not overpower the strawberries.  The homemade waffle cones (+$1.25) was calling my name but since I was sharing, I opted for a cup instead.  Next time, I will get a double all to myself.

Thank you Portland for bringing such yummy goodness to SF.  I am excited to see more locations pop up around the city, heard Hayes Valley is next!
author: Janetto L.

description:
Found this gem on yelp- but would have found it eventually with the smell of waffle greeting us from the street. All the flavors are out of the box- but keep your mind open and taste the whole menu if you have to!
I ordered the honey lavender with the almond cluster with salted gonache. And my neice ordered a chocolate shake.

 I got my order right away but then we waited, and waited for the shake. After 5 minutes I asked the cashier how long do shakes take. She told me they take a little longer with them- but it should be right up. I waited another 5-7 minutes, and I finally see a worker pouring the shake into a cup, then walk away. Okay? 

I approached the cashier again- and pointed out the shake asking if that was mine. She walked over to ask someone, but somehow got sucked into doing something else and I waited ANOTHER 5 minutes until the brought me the shake. By this time, I was expecting this to be the best shake ever. But I took a sip and it was average. My niece wasn't too happy about the 15+ minute wait either. Plus the chocolate gonache in my almond cluster was over salted! I had to pick out the huge pieces because it was too much. But the honey lavender was delicious.
They need to give customers a heads up about the wait for the shakes- and also not overly salt the chocolate.
author: Mariela S.

description:
Worth the wait! I was stuck in line for about 30 minutes on a rainy day, but that should be an indicator of how great the place is!

I recommend the split scoop, for an extra $0.50, if you can't finish 2 large scoops but still want to sample 2 flavors! The Honey Lavender is heavenly! I love the Honey Lavender at Bi-Rite (still do!) and Salt & Straw does it justice in a whole different way. The floral scent is strong, but not overpowering nor overly sweet. I will be skipping the line and grabbing a pint of that to-go next time! I am also looking forward to getting a scoop of the Sea Salt w/ Caramel Ribbons flavor on my next visit. The ice cream here is super duper creamy, exactly the way I like my ice cream!

This is more of a to-go place as the interior is small. People wanting to taste test everything is what keeps the line moving at a somewhat slow pace, but I can't really blame them with all the unique flavors the place offers! I thought the cone tasted stale, so I'd probably just opt for a cup the next time. Take public transportation here as parking is ridiculously difficult. Just a note that they do not have a restroom here!
author: Kristi T.

description:
The people who work here are great and the line was not as painful as I thought.  40 people deep and it took about 30 minutes.

Felt bad, because I DEFINITELY held up the line when they were processing my order: splits of the flight, typically 4, but with a mere $0.50 extra, you get double the flavors!  I always would rather have less volume and more variety.  

Favorites:
-cinnamon ancho & cajeta, uniquely savory (SF exclusive)
-cascara shrub w/candied hibiscus, this is coffee with a botanical twist (SF exclusive)
-caramelized almond s'mores, if I had to choose one, it would be this one, decadent and so smooth (SF exclusive)

Others:
-honey lavender, very good and fragrant
-olive oil lemon, flavors were not grassy or pronounced, no citrus at all
-terenga baobab juice & coconut (v), good, nice and tart, a tad too sweet
-roasted strawberry tres leches, SUPER sweet, but a crowd favorite
-Sightglass coffee, single origin Dandelion Chocolate, I didn't like the combination, like java on it's own, my personal preference

Tried a taste of the sea salt w/caramel ribbons, would recommend, very creamy and a good balance, but it's not something you want a lot of.

Also got a waffle cone to 'crumble' into my flights for $1.25.  Other toppings are: hazelnuts, sprinkles, hot fudge, caramel, whipped cream and salt.

I lean towards firmer and colder, like to savor my sweets slowly, this stuff turns into a puddle fast, I guess it helps them move people out of the shop.  

If you don't want to wait in the queue, grab pints from the fridge and check out to your left at the square payment registers.  

Conclusion: stick with the SF exclusive flavors.  Flavors in general were a little muted.  The flight is totally shareable - it was too much for me.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
This is my favorite ice-cream place. I know that there's a lot of hype around Sal & Straw and sometimes the wait time is just really long, but I've never been disappointed. I love their unique take on traditional flavors as well as their seasonal flavors that keep changing.

The staff are super courteous and allow you to sample as many flavors as you like. Once you're ready, you have three options and they are (in increasing order of size) 1. Kid scoop 2. Single Scoop 3. Double Scoop. For the single scoop, you also have the option to split one scoop between two flavors. The single scoop is usually a very generous quantity of ice cream and if I'm feeling full, I go for a kid size scoop. Finally, if you are in a hurry and want to skip the line, you can walk straight into the store, grab a pint and take it home. Note that they may not have all their recent flavors as pints.

Overall, you can't go wrong with Salt & Straw no matter which location or city you choose!
author: Aditya V.

description:
Came here for my birthday since we had dinner at jtown nearby and we haven't tried the new place yet. Have always loved ice cream and searching for the newest and best. Came to try their popular flavours and ended up with the strawberry and salted caramel.

The servers were really nice and let us try lots of flavours but none of which really stood out for some reason. Both got waffle cone which was really good. Unfortunately the ice cream wasn't screaming for me to come back again. It's worth the try given the reviews and everyone has a diff. Taste and liking in texture and flavour. Garden creamery has been the new favourite so far topping off the long champ of Mitchell's. Try those out if you you're an ice cream lover.
author: Carmen L.

description:
The former Evolution Fresh space has been radically transformed. There are now a few seats, so the focus is ice cream to go. Local artisan food products are for sale on the right of the shop, which is a nice touch.

Customer service was friendly, patient (long line on opening weekend!) and knowledgeable. The flavors are creative and unusual. The tasting flight, as other yelpers mentioned, is a great deal to taste a variety of flavors. The servers also let you try all the flavors in the case. 

Highlights for me were cinnamon ancho & cajeta, cascara shrub with candied hibiscus and honey lavender. Check out their limited edition flavors, which change monthly and are created with local artisan ingredients. I'll return to try new flavors. Salt & Straw is a great addition to the neighborhood!
author: Carol W.

description:
Another SF snack, another long line. I swear people in this city just stand in line all day. Not to say it's not worth it! This ice cream place was really nice about sampling! I was really excited to try some of their weird Halloween flavors, but they did not meet expectation. The one I thought was coolest was one with blood pudding in it. I like blood pudding in soups, so thought it'd be interesting to have it ice cream, but I couldn't tell it was there at all, and it was instead masked with some pumpkin spice type flavors - my least favorite!

Anyway, I ended up getting my boring default, honey lavender, and it was super tasty. Very creamy, not too sweet, and almost savory somehow, and the lavender was pretty strong, which is important. The space is tiny and crowded and I hear the recently opened up another location in SF. Hopefully that reduces the line a bit!
author: Kensey W.

description: Came here with my family and felt like it was okay. I felt like it did not have the same touch as the Portland locations, but this will suffice. The line was decent, but you can skip it if you are planning on buying the pre-packed ones in the freezer. They do have a small section to purchase merchandise. The flavors here are unique. I love their waffle cones because it is housemade and tastes really good. You can sample before you purchase. I highly recommend you try their house specials. I do have an issue, which is parking. Parking is street parking and I don't like that it's deep in the city. I'll be back soon if I am ever in the area, but I will not be going out of my way.
author: Danika P.

description:
This place has finally reached Bay Area and San Francisco has been blessed to have it. Salt and Straw is a family owned business made with local and fresh ingredients. I've always wanted to try their ice cream but since it was so far, I really couldn't grab a hold of that till today. It's around 5 in the evening and the line was around the corner which makes sense since it's grand opening day. Waited an hour before I got to try their ice cream and it was worth it. The flavor I was most excited about was their honey lavender(seen it all the time on Instagram). Honey lavender is amazing, it tastes like an earl grey but with slight hints of sweetness with each bite. I ended up with a single scoop($5) with a waffle cone(+$1.25). The waffle cone is huge so you really get your money worth here including the big scoop of ice cream. 

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
The workers are really nice despite the hectic demand for ice cream. You can try as many flavors as you want but I tried to keep it under five since the line was way too long. If you don't want to wait, you can walk in & grab a pint and pay. This is how you skip the line, the down side is that you don't know which flavor is good(unless you had Salt & Straw before). 

Recommend? 
Heck ya! The workers are nice and trying their best to accommodate to your taste buds so you can leave happy. Plus they rotate their special San Francisco flavors every month so come once a month to see what they have!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Came here with a friend after dinner. He recommended it. There were multiple flavors, and they had interesting yet decent ones such as turkey, mash potatoes, cranberries, etc. for thanksgiving. Had a spoon of their famous sweet yams. Was delicious. But I wanted a fruit base ice cream, which I selected their strawberries. Was hecka good. Smooth tasting. Silky texture. Creamery. Enjoyed it thoroughly. 

Rating
Ice Cream: 4
Price: 3
Ambience: 3
Service: 4
Overall: 4

Would come back for sure.
author: James S.

description:
Ice cream review.

Flavor variety - 5/5
Flavor uniqueness - 5/5
Taste - 5/5
Texture - 5/5

Especially good flavors:
Peach vinegar cobbler + Toasted nutmeg
Roasted strawberry tres leches
Cinnamon ancho & Cajeta

Other flavors tried:
Olive oil + Lemon custard
Honey lavendar
Almond brittle + Salted ganache
Salted honey marshmellow + Walnuts
Caramelized almond smores
Cascara shrub + Candied hibiscus

Overall, "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
Woohoo! Ice cream date! The line wasn't that long - maybe ~20 minutes on a gloomy SF Sunday. Portland is one of my favorite places and Salt & Straw is one of my favorite spots there. I'm so happy some real competition has entered the SF ice cream scene.

The employees were super friendly and offered us many samples. The Honey Lavender that everyone raves about is indeed delicious. We also tried the delicious Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches, Sightglass Coffee & Dandelion Chocolate, and Olive Oil & Lemon Custard. I decided to stay true to myself and go for the Peach Vinegar Cobbler with Toasted Nutmeg. The vinegary flavor was just perfect.

$5 isn't cheap but it was a huge scoop!
author: Yi Z.

description:
Pricing: 
1 scoop: $5
Double: $7
Kids: $4
Tasting flight (includes 4 flavors): $11.50
Pint: $11

I first fell in love with Salt & Straw in Portland. I made a visit there every day of my vacation and then mourned the fact that my new favorite ice cream shop was so far from the Bay Area. Well, it looks like the mourning days are over! I made the trek up to here on a Monday afternoon and there was a 10 minute line. I heard it was crazy long over the weekend though. What makes them so magical? An amazingly creative menu utilizing local ingredients that's perfectly executed. They have a few year round items, but most of their menu appears to rotate with the seasons. These are unique flavors you won't find anywhere else. Take Cascara shrub with candied hibiscus or olive oil & lemon custard as an example. Their flavors may sound wacky, and yet they oddly work. The texture is flawless. 

I ordered an ice cream flight and got: Cinnamon Ancho & Cajeta 
Carmelized Almond S'mores
Sightglass Coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate 
Salted Honey Marshmallow and Walnuts. 
Loved all of it.

For those of you with dietary restrictions, they also have vegan offerings. Watch out Bi-Rite, there may be a new ice cream king in town!
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Yes! Finally got to try Salt & Straw when it wasn't crowded and was impressed. They have a huge selection of interesting flavors and even have seasonal holiday flavors. (peppermint cocoa? YUM!) The overall quality of ice cream is very good. 

I ended up getting the sea salt and caramel ribbon flavor, great for you salted caramel fans. I like the flavors that aren't overwhelmingly sweet so this was perfect. 

$5 for a single scoop sounds expensive but you won't regret it for premium ice cream. Service here is great (at least when it was slow) and encourage samples.
author: Brian G.

description:
Salt & Straw is pretty legendary in Oregon and I was very excited to try the new location on Fillmore. Parking is street parking. We came on a Monday afternoon and there was still a line outside the door. It doesn't really move that fast because everyone is trying to sample the ice cream. Once you get inside the door, you can smell the wonderful fresh waffle cones they make.

Once we got to the front of the line, the super friendly worker gave us all the samples we wanted and was very informative of the flavors they offered. We got honey lavender, sightglass coffee, salted honey marshmallow, and roasted strawberries tres leches. Everything was very tasty and unique. Get the two scoops in a waffle cone (although they are HUGE and can be shared).

Seasonal ice cream flavors are available all year around so I can't wait to come back once in a while to try new flavors!
author: Michael T.

description:
Dropped by early afternoon on the Monday following their opening weekend. It was gloomy and sprinkling but we couldn't pass up on the chance to try their ice cream when their line wasn't as intense (only about 6 people). We have a kid now and if there's a line somewhere that requires waits longer than a few minutes - forget it. 

The shop was cute and had an old school diner appeal to it which I found to be refreshing since I expected them to have the usual predictable hipster vibe. The gal who helped me was extremely friendly and threw a bunch of samples at us but again, we have a baby with us so there's not too much time spent humming and ha-ing, analyzing flavors on our end. Some I liked more than others but I felt like most of these flavors available that day I've been there and done that. Personally, I didn't find the Freckled Woodblock Chocolate to be very appealing. I know they have a Bone Marrow and Cherries (although personally not my cup of tea) available so their flavors available that day seemed a bit basic. In all, creamy ice cream texture, not too sweet, flavors aren't in your face bold but pleasant, even someone with a palate can appreciate.

I'll be checking out their flavors of the day if I'm in the area again but when I do and if its outside of the weekday work hours, I'll probably have to opt for their pre packed pints.
author: Esther A.

description:
Before I begin, I must confess that Salt & Straw is arguably my favorite ice cream place of all time, BUT this only applies to the Portland stores...

Funny enough, I actually tried this location first and I wasn't really a fan - all of the other top ice cream shops in SF easily tops this one. Then I went to Portland and that flew out the window. To be fair, this location still has the same standard selection with the additional seasonal menu, but to me it doesn't taste the same. 

My favorites would definitely be: 
1) Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache
2) Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches
3) Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons

As always, the service is spectacular so they'll definitely work with you to get you something you like. 

Note, their single scoops are pretty large (the waffle cone is not your standard sized cone)
author: Wiseley F.

description:
Here's my pro tip: skip the line and buy the pint. Even if you think you don't need a pint of ice cream, the pint is $11 and a scoop is $5... so if you were going to go with someone, might as well get the pint. 

Salt and Straw has been all the hype lately, and I'm not sure I entirely think it's justified. I came on a Friday night after dinner which was a woeful mistake -- the wait was about 20 min long which to be fair, is generally tolerable, but meh, all I wanted was some ice cream. 

Where I think Salt and Straw really exceeds is being able to combine some really crazy ingredients together to come up with pretty decent flavors. Since I also had to wait so long, I unabashedly tried several flavors before landing on one of the seasonal strawberry sorbets, which I know, is a sorbet and not ice cream, but it tasted the best to me and I figured seasonal is better than a regular ice cream. 

In general the ice cream tasted good, but it wasn't as good as some places where I've just had my mind blown when I tried it. It's pricey but the portion size is truly massive, so I think the price is actually fairly reasonable. 

To be clear, I don't think it's bad ice cream, but I think I might just be too simple and prefer cleaner flavors rather than the complexity of what they're able to do. I did try the triple folded vanilla and while it was rich and creamy, it wasn't something I was dying to have more of. Could still be worth buying a pint here if you ever want to bring dessert to a dinner party? Nice novelty.
author: Jasmine X.

description: If you like ice cream you have got to hit up Salt & Straw! They've got the most innovative flavors you will ever find. For example, this location recently did a "Guest Chef Collaboration Series", and I got their 'Tokyo PB&J' flavor, which consists of ingredients like toasted rice, white soy sauce, and whiskey soaked strawberries. So dope! Their customer service is also always on point. So if you're in the area, make sure you stop by and indulge your sweet tooth here. You won't regret it!
author: Ian P.

description:
WOW, absolutely love Salt & Straw... always excited to be within range of the shop on Fillmore, and the more recent addition on Hayes.

Easy to see why there are lines, besides the terrific ice cream itself, they take as personal of an approach to ice cream as I've ever seen.  The great people behind the counter warrant five-stars in itself.

Among their regularly offered flavors, Salt & Straw is awesome at creating unique seasonal flavors, along with others that feature noteworthy ingredients (the likes of Dandelion Chocolate, Sightglass Coffee, and others).  That said, after so many visits, the Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons has me in its grips.  By itself, it is perfection.  However, the waffle cone itself is a must and deserving of special mention -- while it looks as you might expect, it too is perfect in every way.  Venture to say I enjoy the waffle cone itself as much as the ice cream every time!
author: Dan C.

description:
LOVE the LA location so had to stop by SF one!
+ line went by pretty quick
+ friendly employees who let you sample everything
- flavors not as unique..not the same classics
- small location so not much seating
P.S i recommend kids cone - great size if you don't want too much icecream/don't have a sweet tooth
author: Mahima D.

description:
Tried: coffee and chocolate

Definitely my favorite ice cream in SF, and well worth the wait. The coffee and chocolate was delicious, rich, and better combined than any two flavors I've had separate. Personally, I don't enjoy it when my ice cream is too creamy, and I think Salt & Straw struck the perfect balance. Will 200% be back, whenever I'm remotely close by!
author: Hannah H.

description:
Salt and Straw is easily in my top 3 favorite ice cream places! They have one of the most interesting selection of flavors which seem to be crafted on a monthly basis! For a group the option to get a flight of 4 flavors is no brained! But it might be difficult to find a seat to enjoy said flight.

The line goes out the door and it is quite the wait, but if you're chill'n with friends the anticipation will make it all worth :)
author: Dion L.

description:
While the line at Salt & Straw might seem daunting, the ice cream is soo so worth it!! 

I got in line on a recent Friday night and I'm so glad I waited it out because I ended up having the best ice cream scoop I've had in a long time! I got the Salted Honey Marshmallow & Walnuts - it was truly incredible. I tasted a few other flavors prior to making my decision and each one was A+. I'd recommend getting your ice cream in a Salt & Straw cone - you'll understand when you smell the delicious cones from a block away. 

I will definitely return to Salt & Straw! Although, maybe next time I'll switch up the dinner/dessert order to avoid long lines!
author: Katie C.

description:
I was excited for a new ice cream place to open in town to go along with the incredible options SF has like bi-rite, Humphrey slocombe, and smitten. 

Good location, pleasant atmosphere, and great customer service.

Unfortunately, the most important thing, the ice cream was lacking. I tried 4 or 5 flavored and found them all to be over sweetened and gooey consistency. I settled on the almond ganache flavor. I couldn't make it through my whole scoop. Way too sweet. Syrupy like. Unappealing texture. 

Thankfully a lot better options in town.
author: Ryan B.

description:
So badly want to give this location a 5 star review like my other Salt and Straw reviews in Portland but there were just a few minor things that would have made this experience perfect! Since this spot is fairly new, there was a super long line - it took 45 minutes for us to get to the front. Half way we discovered that you can skip the line and buy a pint. We wish there was a sign for this outside! 

The staff is super friendly and generous with the large sampling spoons and huge scoops of ice cream. I got a single scoop which looked like a double! So much ice cream. The staff was kind enough to give my dog a vegan scoop of ice cream too for free!

My only minor negatives: longggg line, the 50 cent charge for a split scoop (2 flavors) and the expensive charge for a waffle cone (Oregon only charges 75 cents I believe, but this spot charges $1.50)
author: Tiffany T.

description:
YES.

I love salt and straw. They have some interesting seasonal flavors, but the classics are the best. I ended up getting the chocolate and strawberry. 

Also, you can split scoops which is the best part of this place. For 50 cents more, you can get two scoops instead of one! 

Protip: split single scoops!
author: Nina Y.

description:
For a chain and for their grand opening they did a good job at keeping the lines at bey.  Might of also been that everyone thought it was closed on Easter Sunday. Only two people in front of us which is plenty of time skim through menu, sampled several but here are the ones I stuck with, the honey lavender, sea salt & caramel ribbons, cinnamon ancho & cajeta and the roasted strawberry tres leches 

Let me break down how each tasted, hopefully I can give an accurate description

The honey lavender at this location does not have the creaminess of Bi-rite version in the Mission Dolores, different but still delicious

Sea salt & caramel ribbons - oddly i'm all for super sweet ice cream but this one was hard to avoid, the crisp saltiness of the sea salt and mix of caramel meshed well, not super sweet, just slight sweet with harsh saltiness, must try

Cinnamon ancho & Cajeta - suppose to be similar to churros but with a kick, did not taste that with this flavor, more of a cinnamon taste with caramel mix, so looking up the description ancho is suppose to be a mild spice and cajeta is suppose to be goats caramel, honestly I just tasted the semi sweetness of churro flavor and little of the caramel

Roasted strawberry tres leches - strong flavor of strawberry semi ripe not super sweet, bits of strawberry meshed into the ice cream

Also sampled the double fold vanilla - vanilla is always good to compare it, there is your cheap vanilla ice cream from the store that offers a generic brand, then there is the dryers brand, this would be better then the dryers brand

Also sampled the Teranga Boabab juice and coconut, I just called it the boba haha, one of the more sweeter flavors I have had, imma have to pass on this one for next time

Definitely a must try if in the area, I do recommend coming and sampling all the flavors

Ice cream ***** wow
Price $$
Service ***** smiles and helpful
Ambiance **** clean, modern, light hardwood, chalk boards, very limited seating
author: Clarence A.

description:
Ice cream: 4/5
Service: 3.5/5
Ambiance: 4/5
Overall: I'd be back but the speed can be improved.

Adding some more color...

Ice cream:

*What I have found is that for all of the flavors I've tried between here and Portland is that all are pretty unique.  However, they all have one thing in common and that is strong and sometimes overpowering flavors.  In my opinion, the overpowering almost degrades the flavor itself.  The flavor I got was the least offensive of the multitude of flavors I did try. 

Almond brittle - good flavor for sure but the chocolate bits were a bit over powering.

Service:  friendly staff but definitely a slow process.  I think if there was a menu that explained all the flavors rather than having each customer having to inquire that would be helpful.

Ambiance:  small shop to sit around so it's more a pick up and go place.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
So good! So worth the calories 
Carrot cake , Caramel Ribbon, Strawberry Tres Leches & Coffee with pralines are my fave!
author: Charity S.

description:
After hearing my friends rave on and on about the creative/mind-blowing/omg-worthy flavors at Salt & Straw, I finally decided to give this trendy ice cream place a try. Even though I popped in around 12:15pm on a Sunday afternoon, there was no line thanks to the breezy 50 degree weather. For an ice cream shop, the employees weren't the happiest bunch, but they got the job done. I got three samples, so I can't really complain. 

I tried Dandelion's Bean to Bar S'mores (February flavor), Compartes Chocolate's Coney Island (February flavor: vanilla ice cream with waffle cone pieces and red, blue, and yellow chocolate chunks), and Sightglass Coffee & Simple Origin Dandelion Chocolate (classic flavor). If you like to eat with your eyes (or you're looking for the instaworthy flavor), make sure to check out the flavors online ahead of time because the tubs of ice cream aren't visible to customers.

I decided on a single scoop of Compartes Chocolate's Coney Island in a cup with a sugar cone on the side for $5. In case you were wondering, no, the cone did not cost extra... $5 is the price of a single scoop. If you're craving a waffle cone though, it will cost you a little extra. 

Personally, $5 for a not-so-massive single scoop is meh, but if you like ice cream with mixed in bits, it's worth a try!
author: Leah T.

description: Came here with some friends during a late-night after dinner & found this place quite packed more than I could have imagined. Certainly for good reason though! This ice cream place is known not only for ordinary flavors, but also for limited edition flavors that rotate regularly (seasonal). Was really quite surprised at their offering in regards to how many flavors were available for purchase. Ordered a waffle cone with the following: almond brittle with salted ganache, sea salt with caramel ribbons, roasted strawberry tres leches, and sightglass coffee/single origin dandelion chocolate and all of the were quite good. Note: there are two lines, one for normal ordering & the other if you are just taking items to go. Also, don't hesitate to try any flavors that interest you as you might find unexpected ones that you think you wouldn't like beforehand!
author: Jack M.

description: Best mix of Sweets and Savory Ice Cream in SF!! Also, if you want to beat the line, just buy a pint of your favorites
author: Daniel W.

description:
YES! after visiting Portland a few years back, I am so happy Salt & Straw is here in SF! They always have a unique variety of flavors, and the texture of their ice cream is super creamy.

Line wasn't too bad on a Friday night around 9pm. Mind you it was 50 degrees out, but that ain't stopping anyone.

My favorite is the beautifully purple Honey Lavender. Service is great - they're super friendly and don't mind letting you sample a bunch of flavors. Price is $5 for a single scoop, so if you're not in the mood to indulge, opt for the kids scoop for $4.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Just as amazing as Portland locations and Honey Lavender is still my most favorite flavor of the batch. They do come up with some creative seasonal flavors that can be a hit or miss at times.
author: Vanessa S.

description: It was my first time here but heard and saw awesome things, so I had to try it!  I had the almond brittle with salted Carmel ganache...mic drop!  What else is need to be said!  It was sooo good!  And it is great that they collaborated with one of San Francisco's chocolate company Dandelion.  I can't wait to try more yummy goodness!  Also forget the calories and go full ice cream waffle cone!  Just do it, even though life is too short get the cone!  And the whip cream!  He'll get the cherry too!
author: Mary B.

description: I loved our unexpected ice cream stop while in sf! I enjoyed some exotic flavors while my kids and husband loved their salted Carmel and chocolate choices. I hope to visit again sometime! Their was a line but it moved quick.
author: Carissa G.

description:
I found out about this spot after watching wahlies blogs and when I heard they were opening one in San Francisco, I had to see what the hype was about. Today was that day!

This salt & straw location is at a great spot right on Fillmore street. Customer service was A1, worked fast and help give everyone the opportunity to try any flavors first before buying. 

I went in wanting to get roasted strawberry or the honey lavender flavor and ended up with the slight glass coffee dandelion chocolate flavor and my friend got honey lavender. The roasted strawberry was alright, but the two best flavor I think are honey lavender and slightglass coffee. Honey lavender is definitely the best in my opinion because not a lot of places offer that flavor which makes it a flavor to die for! Me and my friend got 1 scoop each and each scoop is $5 each and double scoop are $7.

Definitely going to come back here again to see what other crazy monthly flavors they will come up with! Hopefully the lines will die down later on. Because this is the 2nd week they been open so far and we had to wait 40-50 mins today.
author: Christopher G.

description:
I'm so excited that Salt & Straw finally opened in San Francisco! I first tried their ice cream in Portland at the original location, and have to admit I liked it better up north. However, the ice cream here still doesn't disappoint and if you have 30-45 minutes to kill, go for an unforgettable scoop of ice cream! 4/5 stars for this location given the wait time and the expensive prices for ice cream. I can admit I'm crazy for ice cream to tolerate waiting 45 minutes at 9:00pm on a windy night in SF. 

[Scoops]
Highly recommend the honey lavender! This is my favorite flavor by far. There are hints of a tea flavor, but also subtle tastes of honey. I would recommend a single scoop. I love ice cream, but the double scoop was a lot of ice cream (it was like $8). It felt like I was eating a whole carton. I also tried the brownie flavor. That one was filling and on the sweet side, so it's definitely wiser to just have that flavor by itself. My eyes are too big for my stomach. 

Welcome to SF, Salt & Straw!
author: Alice Z.

description:
We first had Salt & Straw when we went to Portland a few years ago for one of our anniversary celebration trips. Our friend highly highly recommended this ice-cream shop (we ended up going to all 3 locations in Portland because that's how good it was!), so, needless to say, we were SUPER excited when we found out that they started opening all these new locations in California!

We rarely go to the city unless we have a good reason to, and Salt & Straw was definitely more than enough to convince us to make a special trip north! The wait was crazy long but SOOOOO worth it! They let you sample as many flavors as you want and they give VERY generous servings of deliciousness! I can eat this all day long everyday (if I can figure out a way to not gain weight/get fat)!
author: Cathy W.

description:
Ice cream is really good! 
I went with a group of friends and we all got different flavors. I got the honey lavender. If you like the flowery taste of lavender, you would like it (my friend didn't, so he doesn't recommend). 

I would go again, but go before 6pm on weekend. I went on a Sunday, and we made it before the line got long.
author: Kiyomi K.

description:
There are some things that you just shouldn't put into ice cream.  

Like mayonnaise.  Hah, I'm joking, the apple mayo flavor at Salt and Straw is actually pretty good!  Out of all the ice cream joints in SF, Salt and Straw probably has the craziest flavor combinations.  Not all of them work, but I gotta respect them for putting that stuff out there.  Sometimes you hit gold, like the goat cheese and olive brittle I had in LA.  The good and simultaneously bad side is that each city has its own exclusive flavors, even when it comes to the flavors regularly on the menu.  It's fun to try new flavors in new cities, but I'm only in LA so many times out of the year and I need my goat cheese ice cream!

This location is on the smaller side, but we did manage to find a seat at the bar.  The line can get a little long sometimes so best to be prepared.  

The one thing I have against Salt and Straw is the prices are so high!  For such a small amount of ice cream!!  Maybe I've just had stingy scoopers in the past, but I tend to get waaay more ice cream for $6 at Garden Creamery or Mr. & Mrs.

Tips and Tricks
-Share an ice cream flight with a friend if you just can't decide on 1 or 2 flavors!
author: Jessica L.

description:
I was so pleased when I heard Salt & Straw would be coming to SF.  It was one of our favorite stops while in Portland.

This one is located close to Japantown in SF.  I like that, as in Portland, you are encouraged to sample as much as you like.  This is great because the ice cream is not the cheapest, so take advantage to make sure you get something you like.

Favorite flavors on this visit were the coconut jam with chocolate crispy rice and the roasted strawberry tres leches.  If you are trying to cut some calories take advantage of the split scoops.
author: Brent T.

description:
It was a really hot day in San Francisco so we decided to get ice cream. We had already gone to Bi-Rite and Smitten before, so we decided to try something new today. The store's pretty big and has small bar seating areas. 

As soon as we walked in we were SMACKED by the delicious smell of waffle cones and ice cream, with the menus situated at the front door, as well as a main menu. The menu was extensive - with seasonal February flavors and regular flavors. The line was super short and if you're just buying a pint you can skip the line. 

I got two scoops, the Black Sesame and the Chocolate (sorry i can't remember the exact names). This is only for the Black Sesame - there's too much caramel at the bottom, it was sticking to my teeth and congealed together. The black sesame brittle and the chocolate were actually really good. The servers were really helpful and welcoming - just super nice, chill people.

My friend decided on the honey lavender and the strawberry tres leche, and the honey lavender was so fricken good; the flavor of the lavender really came through and balanced well with the sweetness of the honey.

Three stars because of the caramel and the overpriced ice cream - but also it's San Francisco, so I don't know what I was expecting.
author: Lily H.

description:
Here's how you can get 4 scoops and a waffle cone for less than $10:

Order a double scoop (2 full scoops for $7), split scoop it (turns those 2 full scoops into 4 kid scoops for an extra $0.50), add a waffle cone (extra $1.25).

One split double scoop = 4 kid-scoop-sized flavors for $7.50. Add that waffle cone to make $8.75.

Perfect portions at a perfect price for 2. WINNING.

Reading Vivian S's review while waiting in line was really helpful because she clarified that the $11.50 tasting flight is 4 kid scoops. Naturally, I began churning cogs to figure out a more cost-efficient way of getting more flavors for less money (2 split single scoops = $11, 2 double scoops = $14). 1 split double scoop was the answer, and I chose to leave my 2 scoops in a cup while my boyfriend placed his 2 scoops in a waffle cone. Yes, the kid scoops are smaller than the full scoops, but the full scoops are already huge. I would say it's 2.25" diameter versus 2.75-3" diameter for the kid scoop versus the full scoop, and 2 kid scoops was already too much for me. I ended up scooping my second kid scoop from my cup and plopping it on top of my boyfriend's scoops, which appeased his initial disappointment in how meager his 2 kid scoops looked in his big ol' waffle cone. Size doesn't always matter, gosh.

Preference for the flavors we sampled/committed to:
1) Freckled chocolate zucchini bread (farmers market series, and 1 of 2 flavors I ordered). They take their freckled woodblock chocolate and throw in chunks of yummy zucchini bread and spices like cinnamon, clove, and nutmeg. This is a good flavor to eat in a cup because the zucchini bread acts as the starch to balance the sweetness from the ice cream.
2) Peach vinegar cobbler with toasted nutmeg (classic, and 1 of 2 flavors my boyfriend ordered). Salted vanilla ice cream with clumps of peach jam that complement the nutmeg crumble. This is a decadent flavor, so get it in a cone.
3) Roasted strawberry tres leches (classic, and 1 of 2 flavors I ordered). Vanilla ice cream with clumps of strawberry jam. Rich and creamy, so get it in a cone (yes, it was a bit overwhelming when I ate it solo in my cup).
4) Carrot cake batter & hazelnut praline (farmers market series). Carrot cake and candied hazelnuts? Brilliant.
5) Freckled woodblock chocolate (classic, and 1 of 2 flavors my boyfriend ordered). A solid vanilla ice cream sprinkled with chocolate explosions. Works in a cup or cone.
6) Green fennel and maple (farmers market series). A complicated but enjoyable flavor.
7) Eggplant honey custard (farmers market series). I wanted to love it, but I didn't.
8) Olive Oil & Lemon Custard (classic). Citrusy and creamy, but something was off.

Unique flavors, quality ice cream, great customer service, and affordable when ordered the right way ;)
author: Adele F.

description:
Yay! I was super excited when I heard there was a Salt and Straw opening in SF as I tried the one in Portland and loved all the unique flavors. Of course, the line here was just as long, but we wait patiently late at night for our ice cream. I got the Roxie, which is like kettle corn popcorn flavor with popcorn that is actually from the Roxie Theater. I also got the chocolate gooey brownie and it's pretty much as delicious as it sounds.

Overall, it was long lines but good quality ice cream. Expect to pay good quality money for your scoops too though.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Highlights
- Right across the street from Le Medditerranee, my local favorite Mediterranean restaurant. The PERFECT spot for dessert right after dinner!
- Flavors are unique with locally sourced ingredients and a rotating list of seasonal flavors each month, which is really neat and your taste buds will be hit with a surprise in comparison to the basic/classic flavors they may be used to. I absolutely love trying new and unique flavors, so it's definitely what keeps me coming back.
- Salt and straw's ice creams are creamy, rich, hearty and satisfying. No sorbet's or refreshing type of ice creams here.
- They sell pints that you can easily grab and go, and most importantly, skip the line to go straight to the register. In-n-out, my kinda thing, but the inner fat kid in me always wants to try all the seasonal or flavors I haven't tried, so I suck it up and wait in line. :) 
- Seating comprises of stools along the windows
- When sampling flavors they use metal spoons and I found out there is a hole underneath the ice cream glass counter made just for dropping in dirty spoons. Who knew?!
- My latest indulgence for the month of Feb seasonal flavor is NeoCocoa's Black Sesame Brittle & Brown Sugar. This was absolutely amazing and the pairing of black sesame brittle over a chocolate ice cream is delicious. 

Improvements
- Line can get long especially on weekends. Weekday evenings are recommended, you'll get to skip the line or only have to wait a little bit. 
- Been to the Hayes location and this one is pretty much comparable as they offer the same flavors and size/space is about the same. 
- Pricer like the hipster and local ice cream shops in SF, but they use locally sourced ingredients and it's quality. 

Tips
- Parking may be hard during peak lunch and dinner, especially on weekends due to the all the retail shops and restaurants along this street. Weekday evenings are great, since metered parking is free.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Salt and Straw is delicious, no doubt. Flavors are creative and fun and the staff is super nice. The ice cream is deliciously creamy and I would hands-down recommend their sea-salt caramel. It leans towards the sweeter side than some ice cream shops in the city but it is by far the most inventive. Fennel and eggplant in ice cream? Only at salt and straw... But... is it worth the line? Probably not. Is it worth the price? Ehh... I'd like it to be a bit cheaper. 

But it's absolutely worth trying once at least! Very high quality ice cream for sure.

However, my heart still belongs to Bi-Rite :) Nothing beats Bi-Rite honey lavender and Dolores.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Last month, I was feeling ice cream one evening and was in the Fillmore area when I remembered there was a relatively new ice cream store that opened in the area. Seems like there is always some kind of line when I stop by. But that day I really felt like getting ice cream so I lined up and stared at the pamphlet to decide what I wanted to get. My eyes naturally wandered over to the holiday flavors section and I sort of knew I was going to go for a seasonal flavor. 

When I got to the front of the line, I was able to sample a couple of the flavors before deciding to what to get. I appreciate the great service and patience from the staff as they wait for me to decide what flavor I wanted. I sampled some of the holiday flavors and the regular flavors and finally decided to go for the Apple Brandy & Pecan Pie ice cream in a cone. However, if the holiday flavors weren't in the store, I would have most likely gone for the Olive Oil & Lemon Custard since it had a very fresh taste. 

Now I must say that it is hard to disappoint me with ice cream, and I don't think that I've ever had a bad ice cream, but I must give this store a five, just because of the great service and the excellent ice cream there. I'm always a fan of establishments that innovate and come up with new flavors of ice cream to serve, and it was a pleasure sampling their unique flavors. I highly recommend this place to anyone who wants ice cream for dessert after their meal, as they seem to have a flavor for everyone, whether it be something normal or special.
author: Nelson X.

description: Came here on a Sunday afternoon with friends during the Cherry Blossom Festival. The line was out the door, around the corner! It was a bit of a wait but it went by faster than expected. (Maybe 20 minute wait?) It may have been either my first time or second time but either way it was amazing. The workers there was nice and there's interesting flavors to try.  They have monthly flavors for you to try and I got to sample taste few of them. I ended up getting the Roasted Strawberry tres leche! It was super yummy!! I ended up getting it in a sugar cone and my total was $5 scoop. Overall, I had a great time and I definitely come back again to try other flavors!
author: Monica W.

description:
Best ice cream in the Bay Area!  Yes there was a line (I hate lines) but it went very quickly and it was so worth every minute of wait time!

So many interesting sounding flavors it's hard to choose so try a couple free samples to help narrow it down. I tried the Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache - rich, creamy and not too sweet vanilla-based with chocolate brownie-like bits. And the Rhubarb Crumble with Toasted Anise which was a great mix of flavors, none dominating the other. I was expecting the anise flavor to be too strong but it blended perfectly.

Can't wait to go back and try all the flavors.
author: Rose B.

description:
I'll preface this review by saying I don't generally like sugary things. I eat cake out of politeness to the birthday boy/girl. I get boba with 0-25% sweetness. I almost never order dessert.

I didn't think I'd ever like ice cream as much as I do Salt and Straw ice cream. I love that they have limited edition flavors every month. The staff at the Fillmore location are always so friendly, I never feel bad sampling the entire monthly menu.

What keeps me coming back is the Olive Oil flavor, which thankfully is a classic that's always available. It tastes like a light vanilla ice cream, but much less sugary, with an aftertaste of olive oil--yum! It's a good flavor to get by itself, or with another heavier flavor for balance. I also like the Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches, and the Honey Lavender.

If you're not one to wait in line for 30-45 minutes for ice cream, you can get pints to go and bypass the line. They have the monthly special flavors available in these pints too, so you don't necessarily miss anything if you just pick up a tub to go.
author: Yuki P.

description:
YES!!! I no longer need to drive down to Portland for my favorite ice cream! Salt & Straw's ice cream is a very rich and creamy (containing at least 17% butterfat) and they take a lot of time to ensure that as much air as possible is gone from the mix. This results in very smooth ice cream without ice crystals that so many other places have. The ice cream isn't too hard or too soft--it doesn't take a lot of effort to eat.

While Salt & Straw has a number of more common ice cream flavors like vanilla, Gooey Chocolate Brownie, and Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons, I actually prefer the more unique, savory options. The Olive Oil & Lemon Custard is a great example of interesting flavors that work very well together in an ice cream. The lemon flavor is sweet, while the olive oil gives it a great depth and finishes off cleanly. My favorite of all the current flavors is actually the Peach Vinegar Cobbler with Toasted Nutmeg; the flavors both stand alone in the scoop and meld together harmoniously.

If you think that the San Francisco location of Salt & Straw is just going to feature ice creams exported from Portland, think again. All of the ice creams are made locally in small batches, and most of them are even tailored around local produce and vendors. For example:

- The Olive Oil and Lemon Custard features oil from Berkeley Olive Grove.
- The Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches uses Oxnard strawberries.
- The Salted Honey Marshmallow & Walnut uses walnuts from Ferry Building favorite Alfieri Farms and SF Bay Wildflower Honey from Marshall Farms.

The service was also phenomenal. Despite the hoard of people, the girl I ordered with took her time with me, offering to let me try a sample of each of the flavors (which I happily took advantage of) and explained a bit of how they make the ice creams and each of the flavors. I have never, ever had that kind of generous, focused service in an ice cream parlor before.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Delicious ice cream, but expensive & extremely small portions. Take a look at all the photos of the single scoop.

While you're in line, they will come up to you and share with you some samples. Go nuts! Try 'em all! 

The vegan, dairy-free options were both delectable:
- Orange sorbet with edible flowers: light and refreshing
- Roasted strawberry coconut: creamy & sweet, but don't really taste the roast. This tastes EXACTLY like the coconut milk strawberry ice cream from Trader Joe's (you can buy two pints with the price of a scoop)
author: Steven W.

description:
Le bf and I were in the area and decided to stop in today around 6:30pm. There were only 2 people in line ahead of us! The line moved kinda slow, but understandable once we got to the counter. They allowed you to try as many samples as you wanted. 

There was a menu of their staple flavors and another for their monthly flavors. The only typical flavor they had was vanilla. The rest were very unique. Between the 2 of us, we tried 7 flavors. It seemed like I couldn't find a flavor I actually enjoyed. Each flavor seemed to have something I didn't like. I ended up with a season flavor (sarsaparilla and root beer float) and le bf had the salted caramel. We both ordered the kids scoop so our grand total was $8. 

Good location, interior and unique flavors. However, it did feel like with some of the flavors that they were trying too hard.
author: Carolyn Z.

description: I first tried Salt & Straw in Portland, and am glad to see it made its way to SF. Not all flavors found in Portland can be found here though. There are many unique flavors including farmers market series. I sampled a few and went with the honey lavender. It was smooth and fragrant. A scoop is pricey at $5, so it's a good thing I don't live anywhere near here!
author: Helen H.

description:
"Honey Lavender " is my favorite flavor.  The hints of lavender are subtle which makes the ice cream delicious! 

Salt & Straw is the ultimate destination for high quality ice cream, made with organic local ingredients.  They have fun monthly flavors. 

The only feedback I have is, most of times this location has only two people working and they play different roles from cashiers, ice cream expert sharing with costumers samples of ice cream, and ice cream handlers. This becomes an issue when they encounter that person that pays a visit to "taste" the flavors of the month and some more... the line grows by the second and the service comes to a stall and costumers turned away due to the long wait. Perhaps a better system or larger staff will make this the ultimate ice cream experience. 

Overall... This is the destination for "the best ice cream in town"
author: Brenda Z.

description: Very delicious ice cream! I eat this when it's still cold outside. My to go flavor is the salted caramel ribbons. Love the balance between saltiness and sweet. Don't let the long line deter you from trying this place out. It moves by really quick!
author: Sui N.

description:
Salt & Straw IS hype but the hype IS real. 

The quirky flavors they have don't disappoint as weird as it sounds. Olive oil sounds odd, but it's actually not bad as the flavor is smooth with subtle olive tastes. In addition to quirky flavors, they have pretty standard flavors for the general audience. It's not so basic when they add in a few twists and turns. Just recently, I had their Sightglass Coffee & Dandelion Chocolate flavor. Best coffee + Best chocolate, WHUT?!?! Sold. 

However, of the many times I've had Salt & Straw, my favorite goes to their fresh cheese and strawberries. It's literally like a cheesecake. I appreciate the real strawberries they incorporate inside. Not a fan of strawberry? Try this similar flavor: Meyer Lemon Buttermilk & Blackberries. HOLY FREAKING DELICIOUS. 

Whatever flavor you get, you'll be in safe hands. Please make sure to do yourself a favor by getting their fresh waffle cone. BY far the best waffle cone.
author: Fiona L.

description: My first time here. The line moved quickly and the employees were more than happy to offer samples. I ended up getting a waffle cone with a double scoop of salted, malted chocolate chip cookie dough and chocolate gooey brownie. Ended up driving back for a third scoop because it was TOO good!!
author: Melissa B.

description:
Finalllly!~ A Salt & Straw in the Bay Area! I'm so very very very happppy! Ice scream with joy and delight to have this wonderful crafty ice creamery nearby. Thank you! Thank you! Thank you!
Stopped by on a Tuesday night around 10pm after dinner, and my friends and I were greeted by an about 30 minute wait line out the door. The wait wasn't bad with some good friends and good conversation. Upon entering the store, you can find neat merchandise to your right including some shirts, stickers, magnets, ice cream scoopers, mugs and more! Very neat. Very neat. When you near towards the front of the ice cream refrigerators, you are greeted by an enthusiastic worker who seems more than happy to provide you with samples. Then, you give them your order and they create your masterpiece! Wahooo~ Yay for spectacular service even during busy hours!! 
Generally, I enjoy lavender flavored things, but for some reason, the Lavender Honey that Tuesday was a tad too sweet for me. Perhaps it was the honey. But it wasn't my favorite. I also sampled the Caramel, Roasted Strawberry and Marshmallow with Walnuts. I thoroughly enjoyed the Roasted Strawberry and Marshamallow flavors! They were jam packed with lovely, flavorful delights. I also appreciated the fact that they source some of their seasonal flavors from local farmers markets and businesses! Made the entire place feel special to the community! I LOVE IT. In the end, I ended up getting the Sight Glass Coffee with Dandelion Chocolate ice cream flavor which was DELICIOUSSSSSS and rich! I'm craving for it so badly currently as I am typing this. BUT, not that they should change the recipe or anything, but I would appreciate the coffee flavor to be a bit more prominent than the chocolate flavor because I looooooooveee me a good coffee ice cream. You can't go wrong with Dandelion Chocolate though. *sigh* I'm in lavvvvv~
author: Kim N.

description:
How to Spend Your 40 Minutes at Salt & Straw:

1) Wonder if the line would be shorter elsewhere but decide nah, it's a holiday. #NationalIceCreamDay #AwYeah

2) Suggest getting pints to avoid the line. Be denied. (I wasn't going to eat them ALL by myself. Not in one sitting anyway. Yes, I'm sure. Pretty sure. Ok fine it's a toss up. Why you all up in my business?)

3) Wish you had headphones to tune out the mind numbing conversation behind you.

4) Read the posted menus to decide what to get. Change your mind two minutes later. Do this 12 times.

5) Refrain from bear hugging the lovely lady who helped us with samples and ordering.

6) Demolish hefty "single" scoop of your new ice cream l'amour, Peach Vinegar Cobbler. Realize that there is no chocolate in it. Run to avoid getting struck by lightning.

7) Be doubly disappointed by the Brownie Sundae. Not only was it totally forgotten, it didn't have much in the way of brownies. #BiRiteBrownieSundaeForLife Decline the gracious offer of a comped drink for the snafu.

8) Read about Salt & Straw's cool partnerships with La Cocina and other Bay Area businesses.

9) Notes to Self: Skip the waffle cone. #SmittenConesOrBust  Skip the line and get pints instead. Peach Vinegar Cobbler and Strawberry Tres Leches cake (for me) and the surprisingly tart Meyer Lemon Blueberry (for he).
author: Amy C.

description:
45 min in line to try these special, unique flavors. Granted it was national ice cream day!

They do have tons of very unique flavors and they change thier monthly specials so you never know what next month will bring.

I tried a cheese habanero (exact name not sure) flavor and wow, what a kick. U like spice try this.

I got fresh cheese with strawberries...taste like strawberry cheesecake. Yum! We also got birthday cake. It was pretty good, but probably not something I would get again.

They have ice cream flights but it can only be done if your staying. Which is nearly impossible because they have very limited seating and if its like how it was when I was there...its packed! So seating is nearly impossible. Great idea if it was more possible. 

You can sample the flavors so try them before deciding.
author: Corabelle G.

description: Man was this place busy on Saturday evening. This place has been on my radar since some friends of mine talked about it being from SoCal. I had also seen Wanugee's pic and was even more curious. Well we went and it was all it hyped up about. The line only took us 30-40 minutes, but it moved fast. Great flavors and innovative flavors like Olive oil Lemon Custard , or Eggplant,  Sightglass Coffee with chocolate dandelions?! I had the Roasted Strawberry with Tres Leches and the Gooey Brownie ice cream on a Waffle cone. The place had 1 pint Shakes and pints Togo too. They even had Ice Cream flights for only $11. I loved the fact that they let you sample before you order your scoops. There are little scoops if want a smaller size. I am definitely a fan.
author: Robert R.

description: Such an amazing ice cream experience. This is probably one of the best ice cream shops I've been to. It's a little pricey but the ice cream is really good quality. Go during the week to miss the busy lines if possible.
author: Cynthia R.

description:
Date: September 20, 2017
Time: mid afternoon

What they got right:
Nice decor
Real tasting spoons
Curious flavors such as bone marrow & sour cherry
Vegan options

Needs improvement:
Seating 

I asked LG for suggestions on where to try that's new & hip and he suggested Salt & Straw. Our server was friendly, funny and very patient as we browsed through the intriguing flavors such as lavendar honey, bone marrow & sour cherry and roasted strawberry and coconut. I was surprised that we were handed regular tasting spoons and not the plastic ones I expected.

LG ordered a scoop of the bone marrow & sour cherry, which was very tasty! I ordered the vegan roasted strawberry and coconut (made with coconut milk) which was delicious and lightly creamy. I was surprised at the texture.

I will definitely be back!
author: Kimi K.

description:
Absolutely wonderful. I missed out on trying Salt and Straw when I went to Portland, but I'm so glad I got the chance to try it here in SF! 

I came here with a friend on a weekday afternoon and didn't even have to wait in LINE! Also, if you want to buy a pint of ice cream, you can skip the line. They have a sign inside that says: Let's get straight to the pint. I totally appreciated the pun! I think it made my day!

I tried the freckled chocolate zucchini bread, and it was wonderful. They have a very extensive list of limited edition FLAVORS and classic ones too. Their limited edition ones are very creative and include others like green fennel and maple, and eggplant honey custard, which I definitely want to go back and try. But their ice cream is very creamy and flavorful, yet not too overwhelming. Also, I didn't even find the zucchini bread flavor too sweet or rich. It was a perfect balance. I also tried their vanilla flavor, which they call double fold vanilla. It was the most perfect vanilla ice cream I've ever tasted.

The CONE was perfect. It was crispy and crunchy. It was a sweet waffle cone that perfectly complemented the ice cream!

SERVICE was friendly. It may not be the fastest, as they let you sample flavors. But they also put up with you sampling and waiting for you to decide on a flavor. The employee also made sure that the flavors my friend and I sampled were nut free or peanut free, as we both have nut ALLERGIES. We really appreciated the extra effort this employee took to double check!
author: Julie L.

description:
TLDR: I loved it and how no idea why

I hate Portland. BUT i have to say the best things to come out of that lame place are salt&straw and blue star donuts! A true gem in the rough!

The people working here are homies next level for real. they hook it up with samples for days without judging you! 

Their flavors are weird but be adventurous. Trust and try that's the motto here.

Oh if you're in to the entire artsy hipster look you can get beanies and trucker hats here that'll make you super trendy.
author: Samraaj B.

description:
As a former Portlander, I was so excited when Salt & Straw arrived in San Francisco earlier this year, especially since we tend to get left in the dust when it comes to popular food joints expanding out of their home states (I'm looking at you, Blue Star. LA and Tokyo before us, really?). And coming here, I really do feel like I'm back in good ol' PDX. There's always been something a little magical about peering in those windows to see the bright interior, like a Portland version of Edward Hopper's iconic painting, Nighthawks. Your eye is drawn to the orange and white awning, making you momentarily forget you're in the bougie wasteland that is Pacific Heights.

I've been here twice on weekday nights, and the place was packed both times, but lines moved relatively quickly. It's a small store compared to most Portland locations, and so the crowdedness bothered me more than anything, but it wasn't worse than any other foodie hotspot.

As for the product - I always tell people that the best ice cream I've ever eaten was a seasonal flavor from Salt & Straw made with turkey stock. I looked forward to finally getting to try it again after four years, but they were already on to offering winter holiday flavors. It was November 29, and I'd thought the flavors would last through the month; guess not.

Though I was disappointed - a bit salty, you might say - I ended up happy with my choice of Apple Brandy & Pecan Pie. A bit of a misnomer, the two flavors combined gave it more of an apple pie taste, but that was more than fine with me.

I also appreciated the staff working to accommodate my family of five. They moved us to a separate counter to taste and order, which really helped our Salt & Straw newbies not get too overwhelmed and hold up the line.

A tip: Salt & Straw's ice cream reportedly contains 7% more fat than regular ice cream, and consequently is extremely rich. Their scoops are also quite generous, so I'd recommend getting a kid's size unless you're really in the mood to indulge.
author: Maya K.

description: First time here.  First time there wasn't a line so I thought I give them a try.  Tons of neat flavors and since I couldn't decide on the strawberry or peach, they gave me a sample. I chose the strawberry instead of the peach as it tasted really rich.  Very clean and neatly products displayed.  The reason for the 3 is the waiting to pay for your ice cream.  I watched and saw that who helped you would also be ringing up your purchase.  I saw people eating most of their ice cream while waiting in line to pay.  If I would be in a rush I did not want to finish my ice cream before I left the establishment.  Guess they do this to show customer service?  Instead of serving you and you go to the cashier to pay?  Of course this was my first visit.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Salt & Straw doesn't disappoint no matter what city it opens in. I am a big fan of this place, and I've been to every single one of their locations in Portland, LA, and now San Francisco. I love it. I always try different flavors, and sometimes I change it up, but time after time I get the freckled woodblock chocolate. It's the perfect blend of saltiness, high quality chocolate, and creaminess. They use the best ingredients that are sourced locally no matter what city they're in, and the ice cream is so high quality. 

I love that they have such random and unique flavors for each month. They definitely aren't afraid to try anything! I used to go every single month when I lived in LA to test the new flavors - I am committed to Salt & Straw. It's worth the hype, even though you do end up paying almost $10 for a scoop of ice cream. Sometimes I end up getting the whole pint for $11 and eating it on the go because I don't want to wait in line and end up getting the freckled woodblock chocolate again.
author: Steph V.

description:
Overview: Salt & Straw is a high-end artisan ice cream shop chain that found its way into San Francisco and is giving Smitten a run for its money. This location is on the corner of Filmore and California, just down the hill from the California Pacific Medical Center and just a block up Fillmore from Pizzeria Delfina.

The Ice Cream: A double scoop is $7 and a waffle cone is $1.25. Even for San Francisco that's expensive but thankfully you get some of the most inventive ice cream flavors I've ever tried. Lemon olive oil, Sightglass+Dandelion mocha, eggplant, zucchini bread, fennel, etc. It's ALL amazing. Who knew that zucchini bread chunks would work well in ice cream??

The Service: Patient, friendly, and fast - it's as good as it gets for ice cream service.

Conclusions: This place is an awful value, has long lines, and parking in Pac Heights is fairly frustrating, but ****** Salt & Straw makes some of the best complex avant-garde ice cream in San Francisco with a smile. I would have given it 5-stars hands down if the prices were more reasonable.
author: Andrew H.

description:
My family and I caught the timing during a rare moment when the line was not out of the door... But after trying the ice cream I would gladly wait in a line out the door and around the corner!

Their flavors are so unique and the quality is top-notch! With so many tempting flavors it was quite hard to choose. I sampled (and forgive me if I don't remember the official flavor names):

- Wildflower honey with walnuts (seasonal)
- Honey lavender
- Sea salt with caramel ribbons
- Berkeley Olive oil something or other

All four of the above were MIND BENDINGLY GOOD. I did not know what to expect with the unique flavors but I was not disappointed in the least.
