I ended up getting a scoop of Honey lavender and a scoop of the olive oil one in a waffle cup... (Side note: the waffle was so fresh and delicious! One of the best I've ever had)

My dad got the Black olive and goat cheese one... I tried a little spoonful and it was probably one of the most DISGUSTING things I've ever put into my mouth. Almost died. But I hate olives with a passion so that's why. My dad loves olives and he raved and raved about his flavor choice so that's that for you.

Overall this is definitely my new favorite ice cream spot in the Bay Area! I live in San Jose, but it's definitely worth driving up to the city to hangout out for the day in order to come back here. If you lived closer, shame on you... Put your phone down and go get ice cream.
author: Christian F.

description:
Trendy and delicious ice cream shop. They have new flavors every month. This month , they had all chocolate based flavors because of Valentine's day. There's so many flavors it can be overwhelming, but all of them sound so good. The worker was friendly and patient as my bf and I tried the flavors. 

I was only planning to get a single scoop but there were so many good flavors. The worker saw me struggling and he told me that they offer a split single, where you can get two smaller scoops. So I got the honey lavender and the olive grove olive oil, really tasty. 

You can skip the line if you just want to buy pints of ice cream. And they have merchandise that you can buy, like hats and t-shirts and mugs.
author: Theresa D.

description:
After waiting in line for over an hour at the OG location in Portland, I was stoked to hear that Salt & Straw was coming to SF!

We arrived on a Saturday afternoon around 3:30pm, and the line was wrapped around the block. The line looked super daunting but decided to wait it out. They give menus out in line so you can check out the available flavors and have an idea of what you want to try when you get to the front. I was shocked it only took 30 minutes from when we got in line to when we got our ice cream, especially compared to how long I waited at the Portland location.

I was pleasantly surprised at how efficient of a system they have here. It's a bit hard to explain, but instead of waiting until you get to the counter to get samples, an employee comes up to you in line and asks what flavors you want to try, brings you the samples, then scoops your ice cream. So, by the time you get to the actual ice cream counter you already have your scoops and are ready to pay. Once again hard to explain, but it helped the line move SO much faster than having a huge crowd at the ice cream counter.

I got a split scoop with the sea salt caramel (a classic in my book) and some chocolate one with flakes of chocolate in it too. The sea salt caramel is delicious, but super rich so I definitely wouldn't be able to finish an entire scoop of it on my own. I commend them for their innovative flavors, but damn all the Halloween ones were SO WEIRD (Chocolate covered crickets? Gray sherbet?). None of them even sounded slightly appealing, but that's just me.

Salt & Straw has great ice cream, so definitely would recommend trying this place out at least once if you're in the area!
author: Tracy C.

description:
I was a fan of Salt & Straw when I went to Portland, where the ice cream shop originated, but do not care as much for the San Francisco flavors.  I appreciate that Salt & Straw tries to use local ingredients and hence the different flavors from city to city, but I am not as impressed with what it came up with for this city.  The Bone Marrow & Smoked Cherries flavor is unique, which is what I usually associate Salt & Straw with.  The Honey Lavender flavor is delicious, but I have had this at several other ice cream shops.  My son had the Double-Fold Vanilla which is good, but I have also had this at other places.

1 star off: Roasted Strawberry and Tres Leches just tastes like regular strawberry ice cream with some white cake mixed in...no tres leches flavor.
1 star off: Olive Oil and Lemon Custard just tastes like lemon...no olive oil flavor.

Staff is pretty open to giving samples, so be sure to try before you buy to avoid spending $5-$7 on a cone you only *moderately* like!
author: Ally W.

description:
This is a great go to ice cream parlor in the area. Conveniently located on the corner of Fillmore! 

Expect a line out the door. I went at about 8 PM last night and it was about a 20-30 minute wait. Worth the wait? Sure. But don't expect to get assistance until the ice cream serving area, which is a given. 

The ice cream is a bit overpriced. 2 scoops of ice cream on a waffle cone is about $7. The ice cream however is very delicious! Be prepared for a bit more of a salty sweet taste in any of the ice cream flavors you choose. It is not over bearing with salt, but it is more prominent than most other ice creams. 

The customer service is outstanding though! They are great at making sure you are helped once you get to the ice cream serving station and make sure you try all ice creams you are interested in. 

There is also new monthly flavors offered. Although I have not tried any of these, there are also those available to try and buy.
author: Michael T.

description:
Okay let me say that I'm not usually one to go crazy over ice cream joints. I'll grab a pint of Ben & Jerry's from Safeway and be content. But seeing how there's always a line whenever I pass by Salt & Straw and hearing multiple friends rave about how great it was when they had it in Portland and how excited they were for it to open in SF, I had to give it a try. 

The line was still out the door when I visited around 10pm on a Tuesday night. The line moved kind of slow, but I'm guessing that's because they allow you to sample as many ice cream flavors as you want. What I liked most about Salt & Straw are their extremely unique flavors. Even their "classic ice cream flavors" are unlike anything I've seen elsewhere. They also have special flavors that change monthly. I noticed at the bottom of the menu it says: "We created these ice creams just for you, we hope you love them just as much as we do " Like how cute is that!?!? Anyway, we get to the front and the lady that helped us out was so pleasant and served our ice cream with a smile. Props to her for great customer service at 10pm with a line out the door! She was able to answer all the questions that we had about the flavors and the menu. I ended up getting a split scoop (+0.50) with roasted strawberry tres leches and birthday cake with blackberries. My boyfriend also got the strawberry and peach vinegar cobbler - which was surprisingly delicious! The ice creams were incredibly creamy and the flavors were rich. 

Overall 5 star experience here at Salt & Straw and I can't wait to come back and see what new flavors are in store!
author: Cecille W.

description:
Omg yes so glad that there's a salt&straw in the city. Tried this when I was in Portland and just loved how they have awesome flavors. Came on a Friday night and the line was long. But definitely worth the wait, about 30 mins. 

I love how they have such unique flavors. Some of the flavors sound odd, but are surprisingly pretty good. They have seasonal flavors that they rotate out. They are super nice about letting you try any of their flavors out. The highlight of my previous trip was trying out their critters ice cream which actually had bugs in it. It tasted good but I couldn't get over the bugs factor. 

You can't go wrong with any of their flavors. I ended up getting a split scoop with honey lavender and honey walnut marshmallow. If you are just too indecisive, you can never go wrong with vanilla, which they do it just perfectly. Also must get it with their waffle cone. So delicious and crunchy with the right hint of sweetness. Plus I can never resist when I'm smelling the aroma of the waffle cone for the 30 mins I'm in line.
author: Wendy L.

description: Service is attentive and they even ask if you are allergic to anything. There are standard classic flavors and seasonal specials. Cones are fresh as if they just made it. Will return if I am ever in the area.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I'm from the PNW so I love me some Salt & Straw. I've been to 2 of the Portland locations and loved it. Like those locations, this one had a line but that's to be expected.

I was overwhelmed so I asked the lady working to show me her favorites.

My girlfriend and I split a tasting flight of:
-Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons: I liked it but my friend thought it was just ok
-Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache: the better of the two heavier ones
-Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches: my favorite of the flight! Comes with a nice ribbon of strawberry jam. Mmmm! 
-A seasonal berry sorbet: delicious and a nice refreshing end. 

I love Salt & Straw but the reason I didn't give this 5 stars like I did the other locations is because it doesn't have the really zany flavors like Jasmine Rice, Kimchi and Gravy. We even had one with fish sauce in it in Portland! They weren't all winners but tryin the crazy flavors is part of the experience! I noticed they are currently featuring a Green Fennel & Maple and Eggplant Honey Custard so I'll have to be back for that.

4.5 stars...gotta stay loyal to my PNW ice cream. ;)
author: Ninette C.

description:
Overhyped and too long of a wait. I will say when you think of Portland and LA, ice cream isn't one of their specialties. Yes, there are some great places there, but when it comes to SF there are many more unique and delicious places. Is Salt and Straw better than Bi-rite, Mitchell's, Mr. And Mrs Miscellaneous, Humprhy Slocombe, just to name a few. 

Yes they do have some vegan flavors but other shops like Garden Creamery have more to choose from and a unique churro cone that they only offer on Saturdays for a couple of hours.  There is usually a line at this new location, although it is not as long as when they first opened. What makes the wait so bad is that customers want to try literally every flavor. Not trying to be rude but limit yourself to 2-3 samples at most and please save the rest of us some time. You're waiting in line so long that you have enough time to look at the menu.
author: Justin Y.

description:
I truly believe this is the best ice cream in SF right now.  It's definitely better than Humphry Slocombe, Bi-Rite, and Mr. & Mrs Miscellaneous in terms of both quality and creativity (and thankfully has much better hours than Mr. & Mrs Miscellaneous, whose hours make it impossible to visit even if I wanted to).  I think Mitchell's is a close second, but I preferred what I ate here in the end.  

I went on a weeknight on a whim after smelling the delicious waffle cones from across the street, so the line wasn't terrible.  The "servers" would actually meet people in line to ask them what they'd like to sample and then start readying their orders as they waited to get to the front of the line and pay.  

In July 2017, I sampled (a) Birthday Cake & Blackberries (seasonal), (b) Chocolate Gooey Brownie, and (c) Freckled Woodblock Chocolate.  (A) was pretty good but I wasn't sold on the blackberries.  (C) was also good, and I love Woodblock Chocolate.  Buuuuttttt (B) was just ridiculously good.  So chocolate-y.  I ordered a scoop on their DELICIOUS homemade waffle cone and was a VERY happy camper.

I'm really not a huge ice cream fan, guys.  I go to ice cream shops around the city because it's my boyfriend's favorite dessert.  But this ice cream REALLY impressed me.  I look forward to coming back......though definitely not in prime time.  I've driven past and seen those lines....and ain't no ice cream worth that to me!
author: Tay H.

description:
Even with SF's ice cream scene where liquid nitrogen and small batch are the norm, I was ecstatic when Portland's beloved Salt & Straw opened its first SF shop. Given their legendary reputation and the mind-blowing array of creative flavors based on local vendors, I don't think that raving about it like the S&S fangirl I am will be very helpful, so I'll write my review FAQ style.

1. How does it compare to the Portland locations?
Of course, it's not exactly the same, but of course, a local S&S beats going all the way to Portland. 
(-) As expected, the space and available seating are smaller, and it's a tad more expensive (though this accounts for the fact that tax is included in the price). 
(-) The first time I went, my biggest gripe was the fact that my ice cream melted so quickly... I literally had to run outside to take my storefront picture and then eat it immediately afterwards (oh, Instagram problems). It's partially my own fault for getting a double scoop in a regular cone; this is a great excuse to splurge extra for that housemade waffle cone.
(-) I did prefer the Portland version of some flavors. I thought the combination with lemon custard made the SF shop's olive oil ice cream too thick and rich, and I found the Sightglass with Dandelion chocolate to be somewhat underwhelming because the coffee taste was so mild.
(+) The staff are just as cheerful and generous with sampling as in Portland, and I've been able to try nearly all the flavors without any problem when I go during non-peak times. 

2. What's all the hype?
TL;DR The wait is worth it.
(+) When each flavor sounds like a poem and each description sounds like a novel, you know you're onto something P: They put a lot of thought into carefully blending an array of ingredients. Sometimes it creates a distinct ambiance (like grandma's rhubarb crumble with toast anise), a twist on comfort food (caramelized almond s'mores), a fine dining esque concoction (peach cobbler with toasted nutmeg), an exotic surprise (cascara shrub with candied hibiscus), or a curveball that will blow up your social media (raspberry liqueur with edible flowers). 
(+) I love how chunky their ice cream is--there's so much stuff in each scoop, it's halfway to a sundae in itself. A lot of them have a ton of cake/crumble/cookie embedded right in the ice cream and is swirled. For example, their SF classic roasted strawberry tres leches incorporates roasted strawberries, sweet cream, tres leches cake with condensed milk, and strawberry vanilla jam o.O This is mind-blowingly awesome considering how other places charge you extra for each sprinkle of a topping or drizzle of sauce. 
(+) They do a great job of featuting local businesses. Sightglass, local farms, Ferry Building goods. You almost feel as though you can sample the Bay from this ice cream shop. 
(-) Long lines are nothing new for ice cream in SF, so I do suggest going earlier in the day so that you can take your sweet time (pun intended) with samples.
author: Edna C.

description: So happy they brought this to California! I've been the one in Portland and taste exactly like it! Parking suck as it's in sf, on a busy street. Be prepared to wait in line, as the line usually wraps around the building. But rest assure the line moves pretty quickly. You can taste flavors before you order. I'm always exited about the unique ones. Since it's summer they has summer flavors. I got the honey lavender, if you like floral you will like this one and strawberry balsamic. Each month there are new and unique flavors that gets changed out. Can't wait to try this months flavors!
author: Sochietta K.

description:
This place is worth the wait, or rather, come at a time when there is no line!

Both times I have been here there has been no line, both on a weekday and at night! Ironically, both times, after I got my ice cream, the line magically went out the door!

Staff lets you try any and all flavors before you decide, they really do encourage you to try so you can get the flavor you want.

It is a tad pricey but the portions are big. Actually, it is cheaper to get a pre-packed pint! 

You can also get a flight of ice cream, comes in a couple flavors for you to try them all.
author: Elijah B.

description:
I had been to Salt & Straw in LA and Portland a few times before visiting the new San Francisco location so we knew to anticipate a wait. On our first visit we got super lucky, it was a weeknight shortly after they opened this location and we only had 5 people in front of us. The second time we stopped by we had maybe 10 people in front of us. I mention both lines and how many people there were because for whatever reason the wait was still around 20 minutes. The organization/work ethic behind the counter was pretty lacking. Hopefully this was just because they had recently opened and the training was not finished. 

All of that said, it was awesome to see Salt & Straw open in the Bay Area right by one of my husbands favorite pizza shops. The ice cream was delicious as expected. For whatever reason both visits my brownie ice cream was pretty melty, as in when they handed me the cup it was already melting so that was kind of a bummer. I'd say the safest bet is pick up a pint to go, you can skip the line and freeze it yourself!
author: Britt C.

description: I don't get it.   Outrageously  expensive for mediocre ice cream.   Obviously many disagree.   I would take Haagen Daz over this any time...
author: Bleep S.

description:
Salt & Straw is my usual ice cream place in San Francisco. I love the Honey Lavender ice cream at Salt & Straw. The place has usually around a 30 minute wait. But it is definitely worth it!!
Staff is really friendly and helpful. Make sure to taste a couple of flavors before deciding on one. Giving this place a 5 star rating no doubt.
author: Elie A.

description: I am very stingy in giving any place 5 stars. But I surrender and have to give it to this place for their consistently great service and fabulous quality ice cream. I have been here many times and each time it seems all the employees enjoy their jobs through the way they interact with you. I enjoyed their matcha with black raspberry and birthday cake with blackberries the last time I visited. Rich and creamy with lots of real fruit!
author: Brian C.

description: My 800 review.  Woohoo. Unique flavors like bone marrow and smoked cherries.  Summer flavors which they ran out of was strawberries and coconut.   I tried chocolate gooey brownie.   My flavor was freckled woodblock chocolate (dark) and honey lavender. Next time i would try sightglass coffee with dandelion chocolate.   $5.00 for single cone, 50 cents for added flavor.  Sugar cone was my favorite since it was really crunchy.  Waffle cone was $1.50 more.  Double is $7.00.  Try all the flavors you want. Go at 10:00 pm with free parking and fewer  people.  We took 20 minutes to get through the line.  Ice cream was melting fast on this warm night.  I can't imagine waiting during the day in the heat when there was a heat wave.
author: Helen L.

description:
The first time I had Salt & Straw was in Portland, so I was very excited to find that their SF location is up and running. 

So far, I've had the strawberry tres leches and the peach vinegar cobbler. They are so delicious!! Tres leches is my favorite cake, and topping it with Oxnard strawberries just adds a freshness to it. (I used to live in Oxnard, and am very biased when I say Oxnard strawberries are the best).  The peach vinegar had the right amount of bite to it, a good balance between the subtle peach. 

Seasonal flavors change, and the line can get very, very long. But they're efficient in getting orders and don't rush you when you're sampling flavors. 

There's bar seating inside, and free water. They also sell other food items like chocolates and jams. 

Next time I go, I'm getting a flight!
author: Vira P.

description:
This is the one ice cream shop I will always line up for, SoCal or NorCal, rain or grossly hot humid SF weather. After loving their WeHo and Venice locations, I wanted to introduce it to my Berkeley friend who ended up loving it! 


Selection: Like all their other locations, they have plenty of interesting and funky flavors. My friend tried the goat cheese with habanero, and almost choked and cried, but it was an experience. I already did my goat cheese time in LA, so I stuck to more traditional options, like their roasted strawberry and their flavor-of-the-month birthday cake.

Service: we sampled many flavors, but our person was patient and smiling the entire time! She ended up recommending two flavors for my friend, the honey lavender and salted marshmallow. 

Pricing: Always on the pricier end, but it's a nice treat. It came out to almost $14 for two single split scoop waffle cones. Split scoop is highly recommended! It's like 2 scoops for the price of 1.25 scoops.
author: Olivia C.

description:
I'll cut to the chase, Portland is better!

Salt and caramel swirl was way too salty.

The coffee and chocolate had very little coffee and way too much sugar!

Line was long but it moved at a pretty fast clip.

All the samples were melting when served and this was on a cold foggy san francisco night.

Waffle cones were fresh but leaked. Portland's did not leak.

That said, the ice cream was good, but it wasnt as good as Portland's Salt and Straw.

Sorry Salt and Straw, I'll still take Bi-Rite as the SF gold standard.
author: Jason C.

description:
Went here after a hefty dinner with friends this evening.
Ice cream was excellent.
The strawberry takes the cake.
One of us ordered the honey marshmallow and walnut was pretty good too!
author: Mary N.

description:
Salt & Straw is Portland's version of our Humphrey Slocombe.  I'm glad to see that they expanded to our neck of the woods.  

They typically have some staples when it comes to specific flavors and also those that are local to SF.  My favorite?  Chocolate gooey brownie.  Yum!!!  

What I wish they had?  Some classic PDX flavors also.  I was a huge fan of their pear and blue cheese but sad to see that they don't offer that here.  

They have definitely worked out their kinks and got the line movement down.  Someone typically approaches you to offer some samples.  Don't be afraid to try a few until you find what you're looking for.  They also have pints available without having to wait in line.  

3.5 stars rounded up to 4.
author: Jen W.

description: This place is worth the wait!!!! Flavors are spot on. The strawberry tres leches is the perfect blend of creamy milky sweet ice cream. Their sea salt and caramel is the best I've ever tasted hands down. They offer as many samples as needed so you won't regret getting a flavor you may dislike. Definitely coming back to this. It's a bit pricey but again worth it.
author: Martine D.

description:
Oh yeah, I'm hooked on this place. Glad I can walk to it from work because it makes me feel I have earned it. 
Excellent service as the "soda Jerk" talked me through a few choices and gave me tastes. I wanted to stay all day but the line behind me made me feel rushed. Pity. 
But, I had a small Roasted Strawberry with coconut in a sugar cone. It was magical! I felt so many people watching me with envy as I strolled the street with my treat.
author: Ladi H.

description: Frickkkkkk me up! All the flavors are great, but I recommend trying the monthly specials since they're limited. The people who work here must love their jobs because they're so inviting and patient (and I ask for lots of samples. like, lots.) The line is always long, but always worth it. These people are doing good things!
author: Cody J.

description:
I actually did not understand the big hype.
First experienced their ice cream at Museum of Ice Cream. The sample was awesome.  So off to the shop.  Huge line.  Menu was very limited to most things being vanilla based. I'm a big chocolate lover so I was disappointed.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Salt & Straw has unlimited tastings, which is awesome! (And so rare in the Bay Area these days). I tried the gooey brownie, salted honey marshmallow, strawberry tres leches, peach cobbler, and carrot cake batter (on the special menu). I ended up going with a split scoop of gooey brownie & salted honey marshmallow. My only complaint is that I wish they could've put the 2 scoops side by side in the cone so I could get both flavors together, because they paired so well (and were both delicious!). My brother got the strawberry tres leches which was also pretty solid. The peach cobbler and carrot cake batter had actual pieces of cobbler/cake in them! Not the soggy gross kind that happens when other people try, but actually the right consistency for what they were. Huge props for being able to pull that off. 

Overall, I'll definitely come back (when there's a relatively short line) and try some of the more experimental flavors (fennel, zucchini bread, etc.). While they do a great job of making quality ice cream, I think some of their flavors fall slightly short, which is the only reason they're not getting all 5 stars.
author: Kavita P.

description:
Hmmmm, it was OK.  I had the Lavender honey ice cream on a sugar cone and it was good, but nothing out of this world  I guess after trying other spots (Smitten and Humphrey's) I didn't see what the hype was all about Salt & Straw.

Maybe I need to try some other flavor?? ‍.  I'm just glad there wasn't a long wait, otherwise I would have been a bit more disappointed
author: Rosa G.

description:
Ice cream is good (dense and creamy) but the flavors are too exotic for my palate and consist of items like strawberry dulce de leche, lavender, etc.

This place would also be 4 stars if the wait was not as long. The line typically extends out the door and when it hits around there is ~30 min, which is very long for ice cream.

The indoor vibe is really cool though. I can also see why people love this place given the creativity in flavors.

Tip: Second floor of Sightglass sells Salt and Straw ice cream without the wait!
author: Amy G.

description:
After having their waffle cone I can't stop thinking about it and I can't get waffle cones anywhere else because it just doesn't compare it's crispy and sweet. 
Their ice creas are all wonderful even their unusual flavors are worth trying every once in while. I even drive all the way to San Francisco several times a year just to get them. I wish they would open one in East Bay. The line is long but for me it's worth it you can avoid long lines if you go mid day
author: Esther M.

description:
I tried this ice cream shop at the Los Angeles location, and I loved their unique flavors there! So happy they opened in SAN Francisco. The line is always long.. because just amazing ice cream. 
Check for their monthly flavors! 
Currently.. my favorite is their classic strawberry tres leeches! Amazing.
author: Nicole T.

description: Love their variety of flavors and how unique they are. Staff was also super friendly. They line was a little long since everyone is trying their unique flavors but it's worth the wait if you have the time.
author: Michelle P.

description: This place was so awesome! I had never been but my friends had visited their location in Southern California and said we had to stop there during our trip. Boy were they right! I'm vegan so my ice cream options are usually pretty limited but I was pleasantly surprised to see three different options for me and none of which were sorbet (which is usually my only option). The line was long but it moved super fast because the staff was killer! The guy helping our group was really attentive and they bring you samples while you wait in line so that was awesome. They also don't use those little baby plastic spoons they use metal ones for samples which was a huge plus in my book because you know like #savetheplanet or whatva lol. I got a split scoop which is basically like getting two full scoops of ice cream for only fifty cents more than a single scoop. Me and all my friends were more than happy with our ice cream, I will definitely be back!
author: Kaelee M.

description: The portions here are so generous and the service is so efficient. We were waiting for Pizzeria Delfina a few blocks down. Dropped our name then went back here; just had to skip the post-dinner rush. The seasonal fresh cheese and strawberries was great. I think the best part that I liked about it was that the ice cream wasn't overwhelmingly sweet. Definitely would go back... and indeed I did, right after dinner, lol. Two friends didn't make it to the first trip so after dinner we went back. This time, got another seasonal berries sherbet, which really hit the spot. Waffle cone is the way to go btw! The line, post-dinner, was crazy, but it surprisingly moves fast.
author: James N.

description: A-maz-ing!! The flavors of ice cream are so creative and delicious! There was a long line but it was worth the wait! You can taste as many flavors as you want before you make your decision. Try something new and you'll be pleasantly surprised!
author: Amy B.

description:
I got a scoop of the strawberry and I just kinda didn't like it. It was pretty creamy and good consistency, but the flavor didn't pop/stand out to me. It had a strawberry jam infused into the ice cream which was cool, but the scoop just didn't hit my ice cream craving. I also tried a bunch of other ones trying to figure out which one I preferred but consistently I felt that none of the flavors popped out to me.

The wait wasn't bad for a Saturday afternoon, about 15-20 minutes. Service was super friendly and the person serving us was really nice and patient with us as we were trying to figure out which flavor to get.

But just based off the ice cream, I don't think I would return to this ice cream spot given the other places SF has to offer.
author: Mimi T.

description: This is such a unique place! They have some interesting flavors but I went with a normal chocolate brownie flavored scoop. It was soooo rich and so chocolatey. It is kind of overpriced but I'm glad I came here
author: Cristina S.

description:
My new favorite ice cream place. I actually came here because I saw they had an ice cream flavor with marshmallow. It might of been their salted honey marshmallow & walnuts flavor, but just the word marshmallow caught my eye.  
When I got there, I noticed a line. The wait wasn't long at all but I didn't mind waiting because when I looked at the menu they had so many good choices, I didn't know what to get. I was debating between their honey marshmallow and raspberry liqueur & edible flower sorbet. I decided to get the raspberry liqueur flavor because of the edible flowers and I believe this flavor is only here for this month (correct me if I'm wrong). It was $5 for a single scoop. I quickly took a few pictures of this ice cream before it fell into my Daiso bag (it doesn't stick well to the cone). But  I quickly scooped it back up into the bowl they gave me and ate it all. It was so delicious and refreshing. The edible flowers in my ice cream was really cool to see too. I wished at that moment I had a whole bucket full of that ice cream. 
The next time I decided to come here I tried their honey marshmallow flavor. I sadly did not enjoy it as much as I thought I would. I think it's because of the walnuts. I really regret not getting the raspberry liqueur and edible flowers sorbet again. But I can't wait to come back again to try some new flavors or get the edible flower sorbet if they still have it. I also really wanna try their fresh waffle cone next time.
author: Kristin H.

description:
If folks have time and money to spend 30+ minutes of their day to line up for $5 ice cream you know we're living in 2017. I personally dig their creativity and their flavors (with the Salted Caramel being one of my favorites) but Salt & Straw should come up with a better way to handle the crowds. At the end of the day there is such a long wait because they allow unlimited tastings per persons - which now maybe plays in their favor but they'll certainly lose business over time as people get fed up with the wait. 

There's always "good old" Smitten around the corner where you can spend your $5 on two scoops, with less time in line.
author: Sebastian F.

description: Salt & Straw! Comeeee throughhhhhh! Finally the first location in nor cal. Everything about this place is on point. I'm a sucker for ice cream shops that have unique flavors. My personal favorite is the something marshmallows. Great, friendly service.
author: John N.

description:
Finally got to try the renown Salt & Straw over the weekend. I'm just going to cut to the chase so here we go ...

I have to give it up to the lovely girl who helped my friends and I taste-test practically ALL of their flavors. LOL I'M SORRY I'M THAT SUPERFLUOUS PERSON who literally wants to try everything -- I'm sorry that I want to be completely satisfied with my purchase, even if it is ""just"" ice cream !! My friend said I missed out on some of their limited edition flavors, but for the month of July I believe their theme is "BERRIES BERRIES BERRIES!". Unfortunately although I did try their plethora of unique and accurate flavors, none of them stuck out to me ! I'm not one to be SUPER picky about my ice cream flavor or anything, but no flavor at the time stuck out and made me feel like I HAD to get it. I eventually just settled with getting Honey Lavender cause I had felt obligated to get a scoop after trying out so many flavors. I actually was happy I settled with it because I thought the flavor was well done here ! It didn't taste soapy or anything compared to honey lavender that I've tried at other places.

I really do have to send positive vibes to the girl who was more than happy to keep giving me samples and reassuring me that it was okay.

Although $5 might sound a tad pricey for a scoop of ice cream, low and behold that scoop of ice cream is WORTH IT because it's the size of a tennis ball ! They also pack ice cream into the cone so you have to take that into account as well. If you get the kids scoop, it's compared to the size of a golf ball. +1 for the crunchy and yummy sugar cone, and another +1 for the huge delicious looking waffle cone (I think it's an additional $1ish ?)

Regarding the line, my friends and I were fortunate that we didn't have to wait because we came a bit after 11AM ... yes that's right, 11AM in the morning LOL ... (we had an early brunch okay)

I can totally see why Salt & Straw is so popular with their many locations and definitely think it's worth a visit to any ice cream or sweet tooth lover, but you already knew that.
author: Jackie H.

description: The ice cream is hands down amazing. Vegan options along with amazing homemade ice cream. Would definitely recommend. Worth the price.
author: Melissa V.

description: I'm glad I brought my roommate here and we were able to check it off the list. I was very impressed with the flavor choices; they had Dandelion chocolate and other local twists into their ice cream. The line was long but the workers were quick and efficient. We weren't rushed when it was our turn which I appreciated. I wish there were more seating though! The strawberry Tres Leches was amazing and the Salted Malted Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough was good. Many of the flavors are not typical so it makes them unique. Many of them also have the word salted in them. I recommend trying :)
author: Elizabeth G.

description: You smell the delicious waffle cones when you walk by, and of course you have to stop inside.  There was a small line with annoying people who took forever to order and wanted to sample everything. I'm usually pretty polite, and I try to move quickly when there's a line. These people didn't get the memo. Anyhow, I quickly browsed the menu and decided on a seasonal flavor: Meyer lemon with blueberries. It was so creamy and fresh! It's a bit expensive: $5.00 for a single scoop, but absolutely worth it for the quality of the ice cream.
author: Ha D.

description:
The line is ridiculously long, especially on a hot day. Came here yesterday and grabbed 2 pints. If you're only getting the pints, you can skip the line. The only downside is if you've never been here, you can't get a sample so you won't know what to get. I took a risk and got the olive oil + lemon custard and the roasted strawberry tres leches.

I thought the lemon was going to be strong and sour but surprisingly it wasn't. I love, love the roasted strawberry. I love all unique flavors here. Can't wait to  come back and try the other flavors.
author: Caitlin P.

description:
Just as delicious as the Portland locations! 

We waited in line for what seemed like forever. It was wrapped around the corner of the building. When we finally got to the counter we sampled several flavors and chose our favorites:

Sightglass Coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate - AMAZING! The coffee and butter toffee flavors are very present and absolutely divine together. I was seriously on an ice cream high!

Seasonal May Flavors:
Sarasparilla & Dandelion Root Beer Float - Light root beer float flavor and went well with the coffee. I have no clue what sarasparilla is... will Google later! 

Wildflower Honey with Ricotta Walnut Lace Cookies - Honey lemon ice cream! Even though this is a seasonal May flavor, I could have sworn we've had this before in Portland. It's very good and it reminds me of the Three Twins Lemon Cookie flavor.  

As other Yelpers have mentioned, the ice cream is expensive and once you add in a waffle cone it kind of starts making you see red when you think about how much money you spent on it... However, I really enjoy the ice cream here and am willing to spend a little more once in a while! I feel that way about all food really! To each her/his own.   

Parking around this area was horrendous on Sunday afternoon after Bay to Breakers. I'm sure it's pretty bad any weekend though with all the cute shops and restaurants that line this street, so good luck with that! The bf drove around while we waited in line to order.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
This place is new - It usually has lines out the door - I had a weekday off from work, and was in the neighborhood so I stopped in to try it.  They let you try any flavor - but how many can you try before you are officially a douche bag? My number was to try 3 flavors - but I bet there are people who try many more than that.

I settled on the Salted Honey Marshmallow & Walnuts - I also upgraded to the waffle cone. Pretty pricy at $6+.  But quite good. Too bad you can't get 2 smaller scoops for the same price - You CAN of course get two scoops but they is a big upcharge for it. 

Here is what I would LOVE to see here: if they developed some kind of fun sampler bowl and they let you get small scoops of maybe 6 flavors for say $8.  But I'm sure the workers would HATE it.
author: Amy W.

description:
Try as many samples as you possibly can! The employees are really friendly and helpful. My brother is allergic to nuts so they went above and beyond by opening a new batch of ice cream for him to sample that hadn't touched nuts. 

I had a split of the honey lavender and olive oil + lemon. It was seriously the best thing of my week!
author: Sharan B.

description:
My friend and I stopped by here for lunch thinking we would only "check it out" and maybe try samples, but we each ended up trying so many (amazing) flavors and a single scoop ice cream each! I tried the honey lavender and the freckled mint TCHO-colate chip ice cream, and ended up getting the latter cause I wanted something minty/refreshing. But my goodness, the honey lavender was amazing! I would definitely get that next time I go, but both are so amazing. The service was really great and the workers were so friendly and welcoming to us trying so many flavors. Definitely check this place out when even when you're strolling around, or even on a very full post-meal belly, we were both able to finish our ice creams really well and happily. One of my new favorite places to check out in San Francisco. 

(I have tried the original one in Portland, Oregon; they have some different items on the menu, but either way, very delicious and not too heavy!)
author: Joanne L.

description: Seriously come for the limited edition flavors lol I'm a ice cream eating machine lol...there could be a long line but it usually moves quick, also if you just want pints you can skip the line and head over to the massive freezer...also do yourself a favor and get a double scoop lol
author: jonathan h.

description:
Salt and Straw is my favorite ice cream franchise in the entire world. When I moved to SF from LA, I was more than a little sad that I wouldn't be able to get it as much as I wanted. Fortunately, this new one opened here! 

This isn't the biggest Salt and Straw I've visited, but it's also not the smallest. That being said, there's not a whole lot of seating. Because there's so much constant foot traffic through the shop, they can't have too many people hanging out inside. It's more of a grab and go spot.

There will definitely be a long line and a bit of a wait when you visit, so be sure to give yourself some time. A good way to skip the lines is to grab a pint (or more!) from the freezer and go straight to the cashier. That's my usual procedure, unless I'm out with friends and we want to enjoy a conversation over some cones.

The ice cream is incredible. I've not tasted a flavor I didn't like. My favorite is the honey lavender. The prices for Salt and Straw are definitely on the more expensive side, but I fully believe it's more than worth the price.
author: Daniel M.

description:
It's pretty good! They have so many unique flavours such as wildflower honey w/ ricotta lace walnut cookies | raspberry w/edible flowers sorbet| strawberry tres lèches | sightglass coffee & single origin dandelion chocolate... to name a few. 

Many of their flavours are unique to SF and they incorporate those SF staples like sightglass coffee and dandelion chocolate! The first two flavours mentioned above were monthly so get them before they're gone!

Getting the flight of ice cream was the best way to get the best of every world. And picking the flavours was like an art--

+ wildflower honey with ricotta lace walnut cookies: deliciously creamy with tiny cookie pieces, I recommend! 

+ raspberry liqueur with edible flowers sorbet (vegan): an excellent balance to all the other creamy, milky flavours. It was one of my friends favorite but like all the flavours I don't know if I would be satisfied (insert Hamilton joke here) or could finish a lone scoop. 

+ roasted strawberry très lèches: standard strawberry ice cream with yummy crumbly tres lèches pièces but sort of a let down. 

+ sightglass coffee with single origin dandelion chocolate: my FAVORITE combining my addiction to caffeine and the coco, not too chocolatey or sweet. You may have seen the dandelion chocolate tasting room on Valencia near the 16th street side or their giant brick factory that's actually on 16th, and their chocolate is amazing! There are also tiny dark bits that seem like coffee grinds that show how authentic the coffee incorporation is! 

Like many ice cream shops they let you try flavours and from the ones I tried I'd definitely be back to get a scoop or another flight of the peach vinegar (???) cobbler or rhubarb crumble (may only)!

To be honest I've had better quality ice cream, from smitten's to bi-rite but the name and the flavours make salt & straw one of those places you should try! Also the parking isn't terribly difficult because I managed to see a few open street spots but I'd imagine that on a weekend it would be near impossible. I also didn't know that meters are ridiculously expensive... but that's the area for you!
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
The best ice cream in the world came to SF from Portland!! I'm by no means a huge ice cream fan but LOVED Salt and Straw when I visited Portland and love that it finally came to SF. The Almond brittle is my to-go but it seems like they've been out of it lately which is a huge bummer. Thus, the strawberry tres leches. A very good alternative. 


The workers there are super friendly and welcoming. They can basically let you try every single flavor on the menu if you wanted to. I brought my dog with me one day and everyone gushed over how adorable she was and offered to give her a scoop of their dairy free ice cream! Needless to say that she loved it and finished it in 90 seconds :)
author: Kristina D.

description: Homemade Ice Cream at its finest! They are not your normal flavors which is one of the reasons I like it so much. The combinations they have are different yet rich in flavor! The staff is super friendly and will let you sample as many flavors as you like. The waffle cones are made fresh right in the shop and are light yet crunchy. Overall a very good experience and would definitely go back for more!!!
author: Anthony V.

description: I hear many good thing about this establishment, so when in San Fran I decide I must try. Building seems to be undergoing some renovation so exterior is partly obscured by scaffolding. You can tell this is right place by line going out the door. Line is long and kind of slow moving, but building smells good. When you get to front, you can start to try sample. Their featured flavors are somehow vegan, I guess they don't make with dairy? I try one of them and it taste interesting. Anyway I try many sample before deciding on 2 scoop- almond brittle and chocolate brownie in waffle cone. Total come to about $9. Almond brittle is probably best ice cream I ever consume, chocolate brownie tasty but a little rich for me. We walk around neighborhood and enjoy ice cream. Potsticker licks up ice cream that drops as it melts. Will return!
author: Zheng T.

description:
Great Ice Cream.
Great selection of flavors.
I enjoy that they switch some of the flavors up by having seasonal flavors, all locally sources (i.e. honey from Berkeley or coffee from local business).
I also enjoy that they have some quirky items that you wouldn't find at normal locations.

My friend and I waited a good 30 minutes, in line, to get to the front.
There were a bunch of people that skipped the line, grabbed a pint, and paid. Great option for those who don't care about uploading ice cream cone selfies to their social media accounts.
I got honey lavender ice cream... pretty bomb.
The lady that served me was super friendly, bubbly (but not in a way that made us feel hostage to an unwanted conversation), and gave my friend and I, since and double scoops that appeared bigger than some of the other servers.
BOOM. Win.

I like this place a lot.
Probably would visit again if I had the time to wait and was in the Fillmore area.
author: Kevin W.

description: Be careful you don't get stuck behind people who want to sample every single flavor or you'll be waiting in line for quite a long time. the sales associate can see you are ready to order and just ignores you letting the people in front of you sample every single flavor... not all of us have 20 minutes to wait in line.
author: Jessica M.

description:
When I heard Salt & Straw had a bay area location, boy was I stoked to come through.

Quality here is on par with the rest of the locations in Oregon. You know what else SF's location shares with it's Northern sisters? THE LONG LINEEES. Expect to wait here if you're visiting after sunsets, or post dinner. 

However, worth the wait of course! I love Salt & Straw's courage in promoting new, outlandish flavor combinations that you wouldn't find anywhere else. When I heard of olive oil ice cream, I must admit, I scoffed and was skeptical. Trying it in shop made me realize that you should chase your dreams, because olive oil ice cream is a surprisingly good thing, so anything is possible. 

Came out with a 2 scoops, the almond brittle on the bottom and the meyer blueberry lemon on the top. They were two distinct flavors that were completely different from each other but met the mark on both of my tastes, fruity and or classic. The aroma of the cones lured me in, and I had to treat myself and grab it too.

A unique medley of flavors here. Come thru!
author: Bonnie T.

description:
This is my 3rd Salt & Straw location and I love it as much as ever. While it's not the best ice cream ever in every aspect it definitely wins in innovation. And don't get me wrong, their whacky flavors work! Bonus points for the amazingly friendly service! The only downside is lines can be long, parking in the area is awful, and it's definitely pricy (paid almost $10 between tip, the waffle cone, split scoop, and double scoop).

Depending on which Salt & Straws you go to the basic menu will be different (LA vs SF vs Portland). And of course you have the seasonal options too! For May the theme is flowers. Some of the more interesting options offered during my visit include: salted honey marshmallow, strawberry tres leches, peach vinegar cobbler w/ nutmeg, teranga baobab juice & coconut, rhubarb crumble w/ toasted anise, and Sarsaparilla and Dandelion root beer float. 

I tried all these and they were all delicious! You're welcome to try as many as you want and definitely go for it (though be mindful of the line).

Overall I love Salt & Straw and I can't wait for their new Hayes Valley location to open.
author: Vivian C.

description: Hands down one of the best icecreams in the US! I tried the chocolate gooey brownie and it is mind-blowing! I have never enjoyed chocolate ice so much EVER! I could not put my spoon to rest. The flavors are innovative and look so tempting that you'd want to eat them all!
author: Mugdha T.

description: Very happy that I finally visited. The person who scooped my ice cream was super kind- she even gave me a sample of another flavor after scooping my order. I had the coffee and brownie chocolate flavors. Would recommend.
author: Sarah S.

description:
The line was a little long even on a Friday night, 50 mins before closing, but it went quickly. Loved the flavors, the girl behind the counter was patient even tho I tried like 1/2 of all the flavors on the classic menu. She even offered a flavor from their June recycled food menu -I love that idea! 

The sea salt with caramel ribbons was creamy, lusciously sweet, and a tad of salt -my fave! The strawberry was yummy. The peach was good too, with the crust and peach you can see. Honey lavender you can clearly taste the lavender. Marshmallow was a bit sweeter than I like. Olive oil with lemon was good too. The Roxy Road tastes like popcorn, reusing old popcorn from Roxy theater, flavorful but texture was a little soft. I went with the sea salt and honey lavender!

Generous portions and I loved the option of splitting a scoop between two flavors for $0.50 extra - totally worth it to get two flavors in one without being over filling. I saw people with two scoops in a waffle cone and that looked a little too much.. You probably can substitute a full meal with that!! 

Ps. You can skip the line if you get the pint ($11)!
author: Mimi L.

description:
Originating from Portland, the quality, flavor, and service are the reasons why there is a consistently long line here, even in the morning.  People literally get ice cream in a waffle cone for breakfast--it's that good.

Feel free to taste any of their interesting flavors with their metal spoonfuls happily provided by welcoming staff.

They have seasonal flavors that change each month, as well as their permanent flavors.  My favorite was the Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches.  I'm usually a fan of coffee/chocolate type ice cream, but this fruity strawberry flavor was soooo good.  Easily the best strawberry ice cream I've ever had in my life.  More like strawberry shortcake.

$4 kid scoop (but too small), $5 single scoop, $7 double scoop, $11 pint (grab and go to forego the line), $1.25 waffle cone, $.5 split scoop for max flavor representation.  Sugar cone or cup included in scoop price.

Easily beats Smitten down the block--though I prefer Smitten's waffle cone.
author: Vanessa O.

description: Today I open to you salt & straw for me. It is was so nice and warm place. The employees was so friendly. I tried the salty ice cream first time!!!it was soo delicious and I tried the berry sherbet ice cream too.
author: Sofya K.

description:
A Portland transplant that I've been so desperately waiting to come here. On a recent trip to Portland I had ventured to their website and noticed how they were opening a store in SF, couldn't be happier.

Similar to the Portland lines, there's been a line every recent time I've gone, probably around 15-20 minutes. They're still fairly efficient considering all the flavors you get to try. The staple flavors are great (Sea Salt Caramel, Sightglass Coffee), but the monthly flavors are what take the cake. My favorite flavor by far is the Pots of Gold, but we'll have to wait to see when that comes back.

Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area. Although there's Smitten down the street, nothing beats Salt & Straw!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Wait time: 30 mins on a Sunday afternoon
What we tried (in order of my absolute favorite flavors to my dam you still good flavors): 

-ROASTED STRAWBERRY TRES LECHES: Uhm. Why have I never seen roasted strawberries before? Oh that's right, because no one else has ever been as amazing and awesome enough to think of doing it. The strawberry flavor is intense from the roasted strawberries and straw/vanilla jam that swirls through it. Definitely my favorite flavor out of the other ones (even though everything is great)
-PEACH VINEGAR COBBLER: Everything's just peachy here, especially with this ice cream that was so creamy, but had some crunchy bits of biscuit for that whole cobbler effect.  
-HONEY LAVENDER: Floral but balanced with the sweetness from the honey, this one is also a must get (or at least a must try!)
-OLIVE OIL & LEMON CUSTARD: I love this combo of flavors! The tanginess from the lemon cuts through all that creaminess
-ALMOND BRITTLE: For anyone who loves really rich flavors, this one had really deep chocolate flavors along with lots of almonds (duh)
-TERANGA BAOBOB JUICE AND COCONUT: whoa this ice cream is non-dairy?? It's really refreshing and slightly tangy, but still so so good! 

THE LONG VERSION: 
Whenever I wonder, "How much better can an ice cream get?" IT GETS SO MUCH BETTER THAN I COULD HAVE IMAGINED. I finally had the blessing of Salt and Straw opening a location in SF so that I could try it. I was lucky and snagged fairly close street parking and I walked up to a line that was shorter than I had mentally prepared myself for. Hooray! 30 mins is fine in my book when I was expecting an hour or more. Inside there are about 6 or so bar stools along the window, but other than that, you'll have to take your goodies to go. I was (again) lucky and snagged one of these seats. When it was finally my turn, the employee helping us was extremely helpful and cheerful, encouraging us to try everything. Who am I to say no!?!? I went with only trying 6 though because I felt bad holding up the line (okay fine I lied, I totally would've tried EVERY flavor, but my friend already paid so her ice cream was melting by the second since she was waiting for me to take a photo of her!). I don't know how, but they concoct the greatest combinations of flavors I've tried and I can't wait to come back!
author: Maleah M.

description: Lots of unique flavors at Salt & Straw. I'm usually a Smitten guy but sometimes I'm looking for a bigger variety of unique flavors! Salt and Straw also gets a lot more ADVENTUROUS with their flavors. A very welcome attraction in San Francisco. Not as showy as Smitten, but it definitely has a lot of simple charm to it.
author: Justin S.

description:
Come prepared to wait in line wrapping around the corner of the shop at this location. I love Salt & Straw in Portland, but this location is surely a little more expensive. However, the waffle cone is definitely enticing and worth it! They make them fresh and you can smell the sweet waffle cone just waiting in line. 

I got the strawberry cheesecake, and they really stacked the scoop up in the cone. The salted caramel was a tad bit too sweet for me. But overall, if you want it, just be prepared for the long wait.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Yes. It's excellent. 
Yes. It's insanely popular.
Yes. I will be back.
Is this the 3rd best ice cream in SF?

Order the Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches! There is a reason every third review talks about it. Start here. It's what to get. 

The first time I went to Salt & Straw on NE Alberta St I wasn't super impressed but I thought since they made it to the city I'd give 'em another try. I'm so glad I did. It's spectacular! Where did I go wrong in Portland?

This is one of those places that I truly hope opens a shop in every town around the world. Everybody deserves to try it.
author: Justin S.

description:
Went with three of my friends on a hot Saturday afternoon. One of us was super disappointed she fucked up the date of an ice cream festival two weeks early, and we still needed something cold to bring down the summer heat. Luckily the SF bro recommended this place, and our timing was perfect to minimize the ridiculously long line.

Even around 12 on Saturday the line circled the corner shop. Lucky for us, the line moved super quickly and we got to the ice cream window in about 15-20 minutes after about 50 people, so not bad! Plus you get a sneak peak of the menu at the window to consider your choices to sample.

I opted for a Single Scoop on a waffle cone, and split it so I could try two flavors. Honestly, 50 cents is totally worth it - you basically get one scoop completely inside the cone and one on top - 2 for 1! I tried Double Fold Vanilla on top, with Almond Brittle and Salted Ganache on bottom.

Not sure about Vanilla "dialed up to 11", it just tasted like solid vanilla ice cream. That ends up being the base anyways for the brittle/ganache variant. The almond brittle was excellent, nutty and sweet, but the Salted Ganache may as well have been SALTED Ganache. The ganache had a great texture, but it was extremely salty even the brittle didn't salvage it. It's a good thing I had the split Vanilla scoop to divvy out the salt - I don't think I could've eaten just a single scoop of just Almond Brittle and Salted Ganache.

Salt and Straw gets props for highest creativity in SF ice cream shops, that's for sure. But I also find that in general they're going towards the extremes of taste - besides my salty ganache, flavors my friends had were extremely floral or sweet. I'm still interested in trying some of the other flavors, but I just can't see my friends and I waiting in the peak lines of over an hour.
author: Dave N.

description: Absolutely delicious! This ice cream is creamy and unique! Definitely try the seasonal flavors, they are super good! I got the fresh cheese and strawberries! We also got the salted caramel, it's really good but it is super salty! There's usually a line to get the ice cream, but it's well worth the wait! I definitely like this place better than bi-rite, better flavors and bigger scoops!
author: Nicole H.

description:
5.6.17 
3.5 STARS 

So what's the hype? Their unique flavors all the way from Portland. 
So is it worth the trip? Well it depends on what flavor ice cream you enjoy, it's either a hit or miss. If you have an adventurous taste buds for interesting and sweet flavor combination, this is the place for you!    

For someone who enjoys ice cream with well balance sweetness and natural simple flavors (specifically tea flavored ice cream), S&S flavors seem to be trying too hard on some flavors, with multiple components and flavors packed in one. Therefore, it was a solid 3.5 in my book. S&S is similar to other ice cream shops such as Bi-Rite, Humphry Slocombe & Mr & Mrs. Miscellaneous and Garden Creamery (My fav by far!).  

ICE CREAM: 
Salt and Straw offers combo packed flavors ranging from fruity, floral, nutty and natural sweetened (honey, caramel, etc). They have their original flavors, in addition to rotating monthly flavors. Sizes begin at $4 for a kids scoop which comes in either a regular sugar cone (free) or a cup. Then $5 for a generous scoop of ice cream + $1.25 for a home made waffle cone. The scoops size and price increases from there. In addition to ice cream, they also sell S&S branded items included jarred cream and jam and clothing items. I tried a couple of flavors, but they were all really sweet (even for a dessert lover like me). The flavors we tried included: 
+ Rainbow Sorbet (May Flavor): a sherbet with a amalgamation of fruits and flower. Like spring in my mouth! Flavors actually worked really well together but I would not be able to eat a whole scoop of this as it was far too sweet for me. 
+  Honey Lavender (Original Flavor): The lavender flavor was diffidently there & reminded me of Bi-Rite's honey and lavender. But there was too much honey added - making it again, too sweet. 
+ Wildflower Honey w/ Ricotta Walnut Lace Cookies (May Flavor): Tasted almost like vanilla based ice cream with, honey and chunks of soft chewy cookies mixed in. I actually liked this one the most because of the texture the cookie gave the ice cream and the flavor. 
+ Olive Oil & Lemon Custard (Original Flavor): think of a lemon sherbet mixed with olive oil. Didn't really stand out for me, but definitely one-of-a-kind flavor. 

SERVICE:
There was a line out the door at 3PM on a Saturday. Not surprising. Though it went pretty quickly because we wanted around 15 minutes. There are multiple ice cream scoopers stationed to help an individual customer - grabbing them (generous) samples and then scooping their ice cream. You grab the cone and pay at the register. Very efficient service.  

AMBIANCE: 
Grab & go kind of shop. As there is very limited seating and is usually way to crowded to eat inside the shop. The shop has the typical ice cream shop look and pretty spacious. 

 Verdict: Although S&S did not blow me away with their flavors I did appreciate their creativity. I would return possibly to their their monthly rotating flavors.
author: Samantha F.

description: Ummm, yeah... Not really sure any combination of words that I can string together can do Salt & Straw justice. Literally the best ice cream that I have ever had... Well worth the long lines. The only trouble with coming here is choosing which flavor(s) to go with. Try out the samples to make sure you're going with the right ones. Incredibly friendly staff. Can't wait to come back and venture away from Strawberry Tres Leches.
author: Jarrad W.

description:
What the flavor?! Peach vinegar cobbler and toasted nutmeg! Seriously! The juicy cobbler peaches were so wonderfully paired with a semi-sweet vanilla. What even?! There are a handful of creameries that tout their unique flavors around the city so believe me when I tell you that this spot does not mess around! 

Each one of their flavors are so intriguing and seem to incorporate various levels of sweet and salty elements. I will definitely also consider dropping in just to pick up a pint to go now that I've had a taste of heaven. Right now it's summer so they've got some seasonal berry-themed flavors that I highly recommend you take advantage of! The berry sorbet is smooth and close to the consistency of ice cream (for those of you who refuse to follow the rules of your body -- ain't no lactose-intolerance is gonna stop me!) 

If you're getting a single, it'll cost you almost $5, but that seems to be the going rate now. Trust me, it's worth it. Treat yo'self! 

My ONLY issue is that our ice creamerista appeared rather unengaged when we went. If we did not ask any questions, she would have happily stood there until we said something. The cashier however was delightful and really brought the whole experience together. I'm not trying to split hairs..but come on, it's summer and you work at possibly the best ice creamery in SF, you're living the dream, girl! LIVE IT UP!
author: Greg Y.

description: I had heard about this place and finally had a chance to try it recently.  There's a lot of incredible flavors to choose from and you might be overwhelmed at first.  Take your time. . . ask for a sample or two and see what you like. I tried the salted caramel (delicious! but very strong) and also liked the mint one.  What I settled on was a unique concoction called "Happy Birthday Elvis" which had banana coconut ice cream swirled with peanut butter and marionberry jam.  There was also something salty in there.  .  . it was heavenly.  Will definitely return to this place when I can.
author: David Z.

description: Such a great ice cream place! They have so many flavors and they encourage you to try out a bunch! The line is usually long but moves decently fast. Very small space to eat there.
author: Sheetal L.

description:
Gotta say S&S's ice cream is an interesting addition to the Fillmore neighborhood.
Luckily, I visited with buds B & J when it wasn't super crowded. The wait was only about 10 - 15 minutes in the mid-afternoon. Why so long, you say? Duh, samples offered - that's why!

fyi, ice cream shop etiquette dictates that you should sample no more than 3 flavors if there is a line behind you. It was tough but I followed the rule. For my samples, I started with the Chocolate Gooey Brownie. You gotta love chocolate to get this flavor because it was a very assertive & bold with a deep dark chocolate taste. My second sample was the caramelized almond s'mores. This flavor is reminiscent of going camping.

The flavors we ended up ordering were the Caramelized Almond S'mores and the Sightglass coffee with Dandelion chocolate bits. 

How were they, you ask? The caramelized almond s'mores had a really good tasting graham cracker cookie ice cream base, pieces of sweet almond and chunks of chocolate. De-li-cious!
The coffee ice cream was coffee-centric and again the chocolate bits were a nice dark chocolate from local chocolatier Dandelion.

Both flavors were enjoyable and the staff were great. Very patient!

All told, I think I'll wait a bit until the hype dies down to return to try other flavors.
As some Yelpers have advised, if you don't care about sampling, just buy a $11 pint and go.
It's a bit too maddening in the shop (super small space). 

In comparison to the S&S in Portland (NW shop) that I visited last Fall, this is about a third of the size of floor space. They too have a line at the Portland shop. I'm hoping they'll introduce some of their other wacky Portland-centric flavors down here.

For sure, there seems to be a battle royale brewing in the San Francisco ice cream arena....let's see what happens in the months to come and may the better shops win.
author: Joanna T.

description: Line was long and also moved pretty fast. There are a lot of flavors to pick from, which is why it took us a while to figure out what we wanted. Staff are super friendly and constantly come out to help the customers in line to order. We had Sightglass coffee & single origin Dandelion chocolate and fresh cheese & strawberries on a waffle cone. Perfect combo.
author: Carrie Z.

description: Having just moved to SF from LA I was stoked to find out that there was a Salt & Straw within walking distance from our new digs. Yes! However, this is not good for the "wedding diet". Ha! I'd suggest going at a off hour to avoid a long line, but the workers here are very efficient and the line moves fairly quickly. You also have the option of skipping the long scoop line and going straight to the freezer to grab a pint or two and pay at the register. If you are not familiar with Salt & Straw they have their classic flavors menu and another menu with flavors that change monthly, so it's nice to come back and try something new. I always do the two half scoops in a waffle cone. It's the perfect amount of ice cream and I get two different flavors. If you're undecided about what flavor(s) to order, just ask for samples!
author: Sara P.

description:
I had super high expectations of this place since it's so well known in Portland and LA. I really wanted to try the Pot of Gold & Rainbow flavor (Lucky Charms cereal spin off) that I heard such great things about, but they didn't have it here ): I was super disappointed and decided on the Honey Lavender and Strawberry Tres Leches instead. The Honey Lavender was refreshing, not too sweet or floral for my sensitive tastebuds. But it wasn't anything spectacular, or that I haven't tried before. I wasn't really a fan of the Strawberry Tres Leches, but my friends really like it. It was too sweet and cake-y for me. I'd totally come back to give the other flavors a try; I just feel like I didn't find the right one for me yet. 

The line can get pretty long and go out the door, but the workers work pretty efficiently so the wait isn't too bad. Parking is impossible during peak hours.
author: Nancy C.

description:
Love: everything about this heavenly place! I've been to the Portland locations a couple of times and it definitely is the saaame woot woot winning.  My personal favorite flavor is olive oil and lemon custard.
Eeeh: absolutely nothing actually that it's far from my house lol
author: Jul C.

description: Best flavors I could've ever hoped for! Bruno and Joelle were very friendly and let us try each flavor before we chose which ones we wanted to get scooped. Very impressed with the customer service!
author: Thomas D.

description: Tried this before in Oregon for the first time and fell in love with it. So glad we finally have them now in the Bay Area. There's always a line but it's worth the wait. My two favorite flavors are: Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons & Chocolate Gooey Brownie
author: Andrea P.

description:
I came here so full and food never tastes that good when you're full, and I wasn't even planning on finishing my ice cream. I just needed to taste it. But here I am, giving this place five stars, and still recovering from eating two scoops of this after a huge dinner and still waking up alive the next day.

I had a scoop of the salted caramel and the chocolate almond brittle in a fresh waffle cone. Usually cones are underwhelming and I only get them to hold the ice cream. I have convinced myself that ice cream tastes better when eaten out of a cone versus a spoon. But this cone was probably even better than the already fantastic ice cream. It was so fresh and sweet, good enough as a stand alone thing to try if you were just into cones and not into ice cream. Like, I still can't get over this cone. 

But back to the ice cream. Fantastic. The almond brittle had crunch pieces of brittle and what tasted like brownies. I must have eaten at least half a brownie from just that half scoop. The salted caramel was so good. I love when you can see the caramel drizzle decorating the ice cream. Both flavors were so rich without overpowering each other. That's always important when getting two flavors--subpar ice cream places will have one clear winner flavor that makes the other flavor unmemorable. Both were phenomenally executed. You can't go wrong with any flavor here. Just get the fresh waffle cone.
author: Nancy W.

description:
My favorite ice cream shop finally comes to the Bay Area. And in a spot where there's parking. What can go wrong?

Oh right, the line that wraps around the corner at 10pm on a Wednesday when it's 55 degrees out.

Salt and Straw, you're delicious, but there's other ice cream shops in SF almost as delectable. I'll wait 6 months for the craze to die down.

Also, .50 cents for sprinkled salt. Really? Just why.
author: Trang B.

description: The Portland giant is finally in SF! I've missed this place ever since I moved from Portland to the bay area and now they're here. A great big line greeted me when I showed up to try the place on day 2 of opening. After about a 45 min wait I finally made it. Was so worth it though, easily the best ice cream I've had in the bay area. Innovative flavors and tasty ice cream. Great staff who know exactly what ingredient is in each flavor and where it is sourced from. Great to see them support so many local SF businesses too. Hard to beat that combo. Only wish they had two doors, would surely help with the constant traffic in and out! Apart from that, get over to Fillmore and try a flavor (or two or three), you won't be disappointed.
author: Sudipto G.

description:
My honest rating is more of a 2.5. Maybe my palette is too simple for fancy ice cream, but Salt & Straw really didn't do it for me. I am sitting here wondering if I just ended up getting the wrong flavors when I went. 

I dropped in with a friend around 6:00 pm on a weekday. There was a line, but definitely nothing crazy. We were super excited to try a bunch of flavors and decided to grab and ice cream flight which includes 4 different flavors. We went with Sightglass Coffee + Dandelion chocolate, roasted strawberry tres leches, sea salt with caramel ribbons, and chocolate gooey brownie. Out of those 4 flavors, the only one I even remotely liked was the roasted strawberry tres leches. The biggest disappointment for me was the sightglass coffee + dandelion chocolate combination. It tasted almost sour and had a very strong flavor that I can only describe as spoiled sour cream. The chocolate gooey brownie was as expected, but tasted like old or freezer burned ice cream. The sea salt with caramel ribbons was good, but a bit too salty for my liking. 

Like I said, I may have picked the wrong flavors or just gone when the flavors didn't match my palette. However, with the crazy lines and expensive prices, I may just stick to my local ice cream stores.
author: Lakshmi M.

description:
Just flew in from Hong Kong and it was 10:30 pm so went to Fillmore for some ice cream at Salt & Straw. Still very busy at 10:45 pm Friday night. The staff was so friendly and helpful. I tasted the Apple Brandy Pecan Pie, Gingerbread Cookie Dough, Carmelized Grapefruit Egg Nog and Almond Brittle Salted Ganache. All these flavors were excellent. 

I went with Apple Brandy Pecan Pie and the Almond Brittle on a waffle cone and also bought a pint to take home for the family. I have to say the Apple Brandy Pecan Pie was off the charts yummy. 

My updated review of this place is a solid 4.5 stars!!!
author: Michael C.

description:
Came here on a Sunday morning and there was no line out the door (surprising!).  The patrons ahead of me sampled about 5 flavors and a woman behind me was getting impatient.  I didn't mind as I was planning to do the same (and she actually did too).

I sampled a few flavors and landed on a split single scoop of Honey Lavendar (subtle flavor) and Almond brittle with salted Grenache ($5.50). 

Even as a single scoop, it ended up being more than I could eat and I felt the sugar rush and crash. Note I'm not an ice cream or sweets aficionado so I'm not the best person to give a review on ice cream.  They do offer a kids scoop for $4 which I probably should have asked if I could have instead.

The reason I'm giving the experience 2 stars is towards the bottom of my cup, in the Almond brittle scoop, I discovered a light brown hair.  I didn't end up saying anything about it because wasn't expecting a refund and didn't want them to feel bad, but it definitely ruined the experience for me.

Overall experience was fine and would come back with friends who may love ice cream more than me and only if there's no line.

Post-review update: The owners reached out to me to give a gift card for the experience.  It never came even after a reminder, so I would have to say the experience is less than stellar.
author: Siv L.

description:
I visited the OG location in Portland 2 years ago, and I couldn't be more excited to have Salt & Straw open up in San Francisco. Loved it so much that Erick T. almost surprised me with 5 pints of ice cream delivered right to my doorstep. But he spilled the beans one day, and I vetoed this idea because I couldn't get myself to allow him to spend $65 on ice cream. But who knows, I may have to take him up on his offer sometime because SF's location was sort of a disappointment for me. Would rate this location 3.5 stars. 

As much as I wanted to order a waffle cone, I opted for the tasting flight so I can try more flavors. None of the flavors really stuck out to me except for the Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache. My heart dropped when they said they ran out of this flavor. Already sold out at 2:30pm on Memorial Day?! Tears.

I ended up ordering the following:

1. Sea Salt Caramel (server recommended) = Realized I don't like this flavor at all
2. Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches (server recommended) = 4/5
3. Olive Oil & Lemon Custard = 5/5. A must try! Very refreshing and was my favorite flavor
4. Sightglass Cofee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate = 2/5
5. Chocolate Gooey Brownie (sample) = 3/5

The creaminess was great but was a bit too sweet for my liking. I also found the flavors at Portland's location to be more unique and interesting.

I'm not ready to give up on Salt & Straw just yet, so I'll be back soon to see if any new flavors will leave my mouth watering for more. As of now, Bi Rite still wins as my first choice ice cream joint.

#basic #sf
author: Christina L.

description:
The best ice cream I've ever had was at the Salt & Straw location in Portland, and so no doubt I had to check this place out. What I absolutely love about this ice cream chain is their over the top flavors. Each one is so unique and contains ingredients that are not something you would except to work together, but oddly does, most of the time. 

I ordered a split scoop of the salted honey marshmallow and walnuts and the roasted strawberry tres leches. Both super interesting and yumss. Only thing is that they were both overly sweet after a while. The strawberry tres leches had a cake-like texture that I surprisingly enjoyed. 

Most def going to be coming here often. Just hope the line doesn't get too extreme.
author: Annie H.

description:
Tasty ice cream and boy does the place smell heavenly... But worth the hype? Eh. Our other fancy ice cream shops here in the city are just as good, in my opinion. Of course, Salt & Straw makes their own waffle cones so that's something. I did like that you could try a ton of flavors.
I got the Sightglass Coffee and Dandelion Chocolate ice cream. pretty good, but like I mentioned, not necessarily the holy grail of ice cream.
Still, I'd go back.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Ice cream=bomb!~

Salted honey marshmallow and walnuts...thank you and that's all you need to know.

Ok seriously...the wait is so worth it. The service is great, they're patient and will get you whatever you want/need....the portions are great=meaning large! The flavors are all creative and wonderful together...the texture is smooth and creamy, I heart this so much when it comes to ice cream. The waffle cones are delicious...but do yourself a one up and get a sundae...it's super big, sweet and probably too much for one person but who cares lol. If you're an emotional wreck...do it. You'll be happy shortly after.
author: Guisela L.

description:
I REALLY WANTED TO LOVE THIS PLACE... but sadly I didn't.

I'm thankful that we found parking across the street right when we pulled up and the line was nonexistent until after we ordered but overall the ice cream didn't wow me.

Between my boyfriend and I, we sampled more than half of the flavors on their menu (a decently extensive list) and I was struggling to find a flavor I even liked enough to order! My boyfriend loved the salted caramel but I found it a bit too salty for my taste. A lot of the flavors were too sweet and thick for my liking. After extensive sampling I settled on the Strawberry and Rhubarb crumble (May seasonal flavor). I was into fruity but the flavors weren't overpowering.
