I especially liked the crumble with the Rhubarb - tastes just like pie!

I'll give it to S&S that their flavor combinations are unique and most are ones I've never tried at other ice cream locations before. But I am not convinced the hype around this place was worthy. I may be back again Salt & Straw but my heart will always be loyal to Bi-rite... especially since the Bi-rite market is down the road on Divisadero!
author: Carissa G.

description:
FINALLY SALT & STRAW HAS ARRIVED IN SF!! Originated in Portland, Oregon, this is one of the few ice cream places that blends exotic and glorious flavors like you've never imagined! This isn't your average ice cream place, this is a place that is able to make turkey and bacon ice cream! If that doesn't convince you to come then I don't know what will. 

Came during their grand opening to a short line that within minutes grew around the block. Every item on their menu is creatively designed with fresh but insane combinations of flavors that the only option is to get the tasting flight because really how can one choose. 

Cool thing about this place is that they have a set of limited flavors that they created specifically for this SF location that you won't find at their Portland or LA locations. BUT it rotates every 4 weeks so basically that means coming every 4 weeks hahah

Tasting Flight ($11.50): 
-Roasted Strawberry Tres Leche: strawberry ice cream with hints of tres leches cake!!! 
-Olive Oil & Lemon Custard: taste straight up like a lemon pie and my favorite! 
-Almond Brittle w/ Salted Ganache: I was told the almond brittle is the owner's grandmother's recipe so you know it's good. 
-Honey Lavender: like eating a flower :)

PARKING: metered parking on Fillmore St, unmetered 2 hr residential next couple blocks 

SERVICE: awesome!! The owner is super nice and humble, out greeting and thanking customers. They're super patient with you, encouraging you to sample to your heart's desire and tell you their own personal favorites. 

PRICE: very reasonable. Even the single scoop is big. The tasting flight is kid size scoops. Only thing is that they charge for splitting 2 flavors. 
-Single $5
-Double $7
-Kids $4
-Split Scoop +$0.50 
-Tasting Flight $11.50 
-Pints $11

**they're planning on opening a second location in Hayes Valley during the summer!
author: Vivian S.

description: So happy Salt & Straw finally decided to open a store in San Francisco! My favorite's the almond brittle with salted ganache - I've even gone here just to buy a pint to bring home. The best part about buying a pint is that you can skip the line (if there is one) and go straight to the register to pay! I definitely want to come try the rest of their flavors some time soon!
author: Carrie L.

description:
Ice cream itself has excellent texture and adventurous flavors (e.g., Baobab + Hibiscus Tea + Coconut). Be prepared for a long wait outside and dropping $$$ (adjusted for the ice cream category). 

FOOD: Flavors are New American (i.e., Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches, Honey Lavender, Balsamic Nectarine Crumble, Buttermilk Meyer Lemon with Blueberries) Deluxe (every ingredient is one or more of artisanal/local/small batch/organic). Texture and flavors (from the ice cream to the waffle cones) are an A+.  The vanilla was my favorite and a strong reminder of why true vanilla is anything but "vanilla."  
Water tap inside which I as an aquaholic deeply appreciated. It's hard to enjoy something as sticky as ice cream while dehydrated :). 

SERVICE: Despite the fantastic ice cream, I think the servers are the most outstanding part of Salt & Straw. Super friendly staff who give generous tastes and are as patient as you've been to get to the front of the line :). Maybe even more! I love the system of your server coming to meet you at the front of the line--it makes the noisy shop seem less chaotic and there is no confusion as to who is helping whom. 

AMBIANCE: Inside walks the line between chic and adorable. Very expensive, pretty Portland merchandise. There are only a few stools at the window (where you will face the envious stares of the queue outside). You can lurk by the merchandise if it is terribly cold outside, but otherwise consider taking a walk with your treat!


Pricing as of 7/2017: $5 single scoop, $7 double scoop, $11 pints, and $1.25/cone. $.50 for some Portland salt on top
author: Helen W.

description:
I go here every month for the 5 new flavors of each month, I really enjoy the ice cream here. It is expensive but going once a month keeps the joy of tasting the ice cream and makes it worth it in my opinion

Time of day : 9:15 pm
Wait time: 30 minutes
Ice cream flavors I got: sweet potato casserole(a November edition came back!) and my girlfriend got apple brandy & pecan pie(December limited edition) which is also a good recommendation if you are planning to go in December
author: Brett H.

description:
I have been looking forward to trying this place even before it opened because I missed it during my trip to Portland, it smelled absolutely amazing when I first walked in and I was able to try three very generous tasting samples! All the flavors were great but I decided on the Roxie Road which is one of the flavors they make with leftovers (super cool concept). The ice cream was creamy and delicious but I probably should have gone for a classic flavor. That coupled with the fact that I paid $5 for a kids scoop leaves me giving this place 3 stars.
Will probably be back for a tasting flight though!
author: Rachel N.

description:
Salt & Straw finally has a home in the Bay Area!! Super excited because I was hooked when I first tried it in Oregon. My experience at this Sf location was seamless. Lines were long, but went by quickly. Employees have excellent customer service, very knowledgeable and patient when it comes to trying samples :) 

Kids scoop | $4.00
1 scoop       | $5.00
2 scoops    | $7.00
Ice cream Flights | (4) scoops $11.50

My favorite flavors are: Honey Lavender, Slightglass Coffee, and Salted Honey Marshmallow and Cashews. 

Their limited edition flavor: Cinnamon Ancho &Anjeta is a must try! :)
author: Rachel A.

description:
As far as ice cream goes, this place is pretty darned good. As we walked up to the shop, the aroma of fresh-made waffle cones drifted down the block to greet us. 

Service was top-notch--my group of four got to try all the flavors we wanted (it's company policy to allow you to try as many flavors as you want!). Line was out the door and wrapped around the corner when we got there, but it moved pretty quickly. 

Since it was my first time here, I tried:

- Olive oil and lemon custard
- Sea salt with caramel ribbons
- Cheese and strawberries (seasonal) 
- Peach vinegar cobbler with toasted nutmeg
- Roasted strawberry tres leches
- Salted honey marshmallow and walnuts

Despite the peer pressure and cajoling I got from my three guy friends (SO not fair that guys have faster metabolisms in general) to get a double scoop, I opted for a single scoop of the Sea Salt Caramel in a waffle cone. It tasted exactly like what it sounds like--hint of saltiness complemented by the sweetness of caramel, all wrapped in a creamy ice cream scoop. I finished the entire thing, felt slightly sick after, but was satisfied. 

Why 4 stars and not 5? Because,in my deepest ice cream heart of hearts, Humphry's, where I can eat a pint in one sitting and still want more, still holds first place. And because, despite all the rave reviews for S&S, I honestly wasn't super impressed by the flavors. 

Would I come back? Probably, since it's a pretty good place for ice cream and easy to get to from my apartment. Would I choose it over HS if given a choice? Honestly...likely not. I do recommend trying S&S though, as everyone's tastebuds are different!
author: Evelyn C.

description:
New ice cream place?! Yes please  I've never been to any of their other locations so I can't really compare, but the SF location seems awesome! All their staff were very friendly, and some of their flavors were very innovative. They had an SF only green apple mayo flavor that was really good, but I opted for the strawberry coriander off of their seasonal and local menu. This flavor was like strawberry jam turned into ice cream. Very delicious! They have their standard menu with, I'm guessing, year round flavors like sea salt caramel ribbons and strawberry tres leches, both of which sound amazing! They also have a local (SF only) and seasonal menu that changes. 

The prices here are a little bit pricey for what you get, ($6 for a small scoop in a cone) and i do wish that they had more vegan options, but overall a good addition to the ice cream scene in SF!
author: Kay A.

description:
If you have a ridiculously high tolerance to super sweet desserts and I'm talking about at risk for dental caries sweet tooth then you my friend have found your dessert haven. Salt and straw is by no doubt the most hyped up/ go to place to check out in the city. Why? Because it's a famous ice creamery straight from Portland. It has 12 classic flavors and 5-6 limited edition SF exclusive ice cream flavors. Okay let's talk food! 

TIP: DON'T BE SHY IN ASKING FOR A SAMPLE OR 9. I SAMPLED BASICALLY THE WHOLE MENU BEFORE CHOOSING. #noshame

What Me and my friends got/sampled: 

-Sea salt Caramel Ribbons
-Almond brittle with salted ganache 
-Honey Lavender
-Roasted strawberry Tres Leches 
-Peach Vinegar Cobbler with toasted nutmeg
-Salted Honey Marshmallow and Walnuts
-Teranga Boabar Juice and Coconut 
-Cascara Shrub with Candied Hibiscus 
-Raspberry Liqueur & Edible Flower Sorbet

As you can tell, I chose to sample the most out of this world flavors/ Bizarre AF/ popular flavors to get an idea of what I do like and what I won't try again. I really wanted to understand why Portlanders swear by this ice cream. The only way to learn, is to try it out. Now why is this 3 stars? After tasting a plethora of flavors, one common theme kept reoccurring: it was overly too sweet. Although, Most of the flavors come though, the overall sweetness level kills the whole dessert. Their was no fine balance. Alright let's dissect my notable flavors. 

Sea Salt caramel Ice cream was one flavor I was excited to try because the creation of this ice cream was helped by no other than James Beard Award winner Mark Bitterman. He is like the pioneer of the creation of why there is sweet and salty ice cream flavors. This ice cream delivered. If your in a salty and sweet kind of mood, then this is your ice cream flavor. However personally for me, I like my ice cream not too sweet but if your in the mood to try an Ice cream by the renowned James Bitterman without burning a hole in your pocket, this is it! 

Peach vinegar Cobbler, is a hit or miss. When I tasted it all I tasted was that bright vinegar taste. However my friend who also tried the peach vinegar cobbler loved it! This flavor is a must try! it will really get your taste buds going woah, that's some bizarre got me feeling some type of way. 

What I eventually got is the Raspberry liqueur with edible flowers. LOVE IT! It was a balance of sweet, tart, and the textures of the edible flowers got my taste buds revived from all the sweet ice creams. YOU MUST TRY THIS FLAVOR LAST, TO RECOVER FROM SWEETNESS OVERLOAD. THE RASPBERRY LIQUEUR THEY USE IS A $40 dollar St.George Spirit which is an artisanal liquor made in Alameda. It's a sorbet that was definitely thought out. The edible flowers they use are a mixture of: pansie, rose petals, orange blossoms, and borage according to their website. This flavor will only be here in the month of May, so make sure to try it out before it goes away! 

Overall, the taste and experience is 3 stars. It's not a place that I would honestly go back to just to have ice cream. Thought I must say customer service is amazing! they were really encouraging me and my friends to sample everything before picking without judgement. 


Parking: HA! Good luck. Either give yourself 30 min to find parking or park 4 blocks away to the residential. 

Line: although the line looks daunting and long, it actually isn't. The wait time is actually 15 minutes, so it's not that bad compared to 1 hour wait. 


Happy food tripping! Remember their is no shame sampling here. LOL just make sure you end up getting something in the end.
author: Roseanne V.

description: Been hearing about this place since it opened and finally gave it a try. Def interesting and unique flavors. Samples the rhubarb flavor which was good tasting of berries. Did a scoop of the salted marshmallow with walnuts and the peach cobbler with vinegar. I surprisingly enjoyed the peach cobbler the most. The vinegar added a nice twist with tons of actual peach filling. Lines were long...worth the wait..? I'd prob wait till the hype dies down before I go back for seconds.
author: Linda H.

description:
I am not local but I am ice-cream crazy fan! While traveling by bus, I found that a long queue outside the shop. It drew all attention to it and bus driver also opened the gate to ask "how's taste " to the eater. It made me to determine that's must-try item and get back for it even long queue.

No doubt and no regret! My decision is absolutely right . The lavender and salt bitter are very very lovely and drooling to me!!!!!!!!!
author: May Q.

description:
Lord have mercy. 
The line moves fast, the holiday/limited edition flavors are great, the regular flavors are delish.
This is the ice cream you dream of.
author: Mima G.

description:
YUM. Like, wow. I've been to so many ice cream shops & I've got to say that Salt & Straw has the best, hands down.

Salt & Straw is fun & modern. Line forms from the inside & continues outside to wrap around the shop. It moved fairly quickly on a Saturday during lunchtime. Yes, it's on the pricier side, but it is worth it! They don't have a limit on how many flavors you can sample & their sample sizes are big! So you must try as much as you can - I am not exaggerating when I say that all the flavors are amazing. Customer service is just as exceptional. Two thumbs up!
author: Janine M.

description:
My new favorite ice cream place in town. Their flavors are all so unique and you'll find some seasonal ones there too, so if you get tired of their classics, you can switch it up. My personal favorites are the walnut ricotta (seasonal) (5/5) and their strawberry dulce de leche (4/5). I will say that their ice cream is a bit on the sweeter side, so for those of you with less of a sweet tooth, maybe give their sorbets a try. Service here is great too. All the workers are super friendly and quick to chime in when you're looking for a suggestion. And of course, before you decide on a flavor, you can try as many as you like. Minus one star for the hefty price tag. If you're planning on sharing, it's better to get a double scoop than to just get 2 separate scoops since it ends up being only a dollar more for 2 scoops vs 2 individual scoops. 

Pros:
- Unique flavors that just work 
- Seasonal flavors available for people who come often 
- Sorbets available for people who aren't a fan of ice cream or can't eat dairy
- Very friendly and helpful staff 

Cons: 
- Very limited seating inside, so be prepared to eat your ice cream standing or take a pint to go 
- Pricey for what you get
author: Diana C.

description:
This Salt & Straw to me is just OK compared to the one I've been to in Portland. From the experience/staff to the actual flavors itself, I feel like Portland was just a tad bit better in those categories. I got to try out several flavors here, including: Imperial Stout, Roxie Road, Sea Salt & Caramel, Olive Oil & Lemon, Peach Vinegar Cobbler, Honey Lavender, Coffee, and a couple more that I can't remember. Some of the flavor combinations, to me at least, weren't really clicking and wasn't really that good. It feels as if it was a little too adventurous. Maybe other's did enjoy them though. My normal go-to is Coffee ice cream, but to my surprise, their coffee ice cream here, as coffee ice cream is so simple, was not that good...pretty disappointing.

I remember in Portland, the flavor that caught my attention was the Strawberry Balsamic Vinegar with Black Pepper. Now that definitely sounds like some random insane flavor, but that was REALLY good! I ended up getting the Peach Cobbler flavor here in San Francisco, but it's once of those flavors that are really really good in the first few bites, but then get's a little too rich and tiring.

The line is always long at this location as well, in prime time Pac Heights. So if you're heading this way, be prepared to wait anywhere around 15-30 minutes for your cone.

They should bring the Strawberry flavor to this joint, I'd be back everyday!

*** Misc Info ***
-Street Parking
-Accepts Card
-Ask to try as many flavors as you want, they advise it!
author: Benjamin W.

description: I'm loving that Salt & Straw is so close to my house! They have a bunch of different flavors so don't be shy to try all of the ones you want. I'm a huge strawberry fan so of course I had to go with the Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches. It's essentially a strawberry flavored ice cream on steriods. The ice cream is pretty rich and really creamy. The cake chunks of the tres leches was my favorite. It added a bit of texture to the ice cream. This place is a bit expensive but pretty much in line with the rest of San Francisco. I would definitely recommend Salt and Straw!
author: Eric L.

description: Extraordinarily good ice cream place. One of many amazing place to eat if you visiting Portland. It feel like I was a kid again every time I went to that store there are so many flavors of ice cream and most of them are super good.  Expecting long line if u go there but worth it.
author: John P.

description: There was a super long line, but it was needed in order for us to determine which flavor to get! There are so many delicious flavors here, and you can taste each one (although it's a big obnoxious to do so when there are 30 people waiting behind you.
author: Michael K.

description:
Did I wait in line for one hour to try some hipster ice cream?

Yes.

I did indeed.

I came on their second opening day. It was Saturday at around 11:00 pm, and the line stretched down the block! Luckily it wasn't very cold, and the anticipation of ice cream kept us in line. (There were a couple people who gave up waiting in line after 20+ minutes. Suckers.)

Luckily the workers came out to give free samples to whoever was in the back of the line! Also, they reminded everyone that if you were buying a full pint, you can skip the line and go straight to the front.

(But a pint isn't IG-worthy, so in line we stayed.)

Jenny was the employee who helped me and my friends, and she was awesome. She was very patient in letting the three of us sample anything we wanted. And she gave decently sized samples so we could really taste the flavors.

Strawberry tres leche: PERFECT. The cake pieces were so delicious. If I were to return to buy a pint, I would choose this flavor by a mile.

Olive oil: Surprisingly awesome. This is my second favorite flavor, and I ended up pairing strawberry tres leche + olive oil for my single split scoop waffle cone. It doesn't taste like olive oil, it's hard to explain but it's sweet and not weird tasting.

Cascara shrub with candied hibiscus: Meh, not good.

Green apple mayo sherbet: Disgusting and tastes like crap. Don't get this one. It wasn't sweet, it was just gross and kinda savory.

Strawberry coriander leaf sorbet: Too sorbet-like for me. I want ice cream, dammit, not juice!

Honey lavender: Delicate and subtle-tasting. Can't go wrong with this one.

Peach vinegar cobbler: Weird.

Sightglass coffee and dandelion chocolate: Chocolate notes definitely overpowered the coffee, in my opinion. It just tasted like chocolate.

I highly recommend the strawberry tres leches and the olive oil. They're incredibly good and the ice cream is high quality. If you give zero fucks about Instagramming the cone (lol) you should just get a pint of the strawberry tres leches and the olive oil and be done with it.

BTW, no samples when you buy a pint, unfortunately.

The only con is how stupid it is you have to pay an additional $0.50 to have two different flavors for your ice cream scoops. That makes zero sense to me and indicates to me that they are just trying to grab my money lol.

I would go again, but probably not wait in line for an hour since I already know what flavors I like.
author: Nicola Y.

description: Best ice cream in San Francisco! They have so many different flavors; it's awesome! The flavors are very interesting; which makes it fun. The employees are super friendly and let you taste test plenty of flavors before making a final decision. One employee even gave me my ice cream cone for free! The shop doesn't have much room to sit so be prepared to take your ice cream to go. Great vibe, ice cream, and service!
author: Trevor J.

description:
love salt & straw! I originally tried this in Portland last year, and when I heard they would be in SF was super excited! The line was crazy long though, and wrapped around the corner.  We just didn't have the bandwidth to wait, so ordered a Pint to take out.  The cashier was super friendly and helpful describing the flavors we had questions on.  

We tried the Peach Vinegar Cobbler - it was delicious, and filled with peach jam and cobbler pieces.  Perfect combination of cream, peaches, and cobbler - the vinegar wasn't too strong.

Their creativity in flavors and quality of ingredients is apparent in every bite! I also appreciate that they partner with local brands to source their ingredients: Dandelion chocolate, Sightglass Coffee, etc.  I'll be back to try the other flavors :D
author: Tramy V.

description:
Once in a blue moon, a new ice cream shop pops up and I gotta check it out. With all the hype that Salt & Straw has, this was def a no brainer. I actually even went to the pop up on Thursday at Westfield but they only had 4 flavors of which none tickled my fancy. So Friday, the hubs and I took a early afternoon break and headed over. The line wasn't that bad actually and it went at a decent pace. The founder was there too which is pretty cool. 

Interior was nice but not that many tables to sit at. However, you can buy other stuff like chocolate, popcorn, and apparel. They have actually 3 different scooping areas where you can go to. You can also try as many flavors as you want. They have a list of classics and then a list specific to SF which I think is cool. I settled on the Strawberry Tres Leche and Honey Lavender. Def 5 stars for the ice cream. It tasted fresh, on point, and worth all the hype. The hubs got a homemade cone and freckled flavor and really enjoyed it too. Their single are also pretty big scoops for $4.50. However, why am I docking off a star - WHY IS IT AN EXTRA $0.50 to split a scoop? That's a bit annoying when all the other ice cream shops around do it for free. Regardless, I'll be back for sure.
author: Tao Tao W.

description: The inside is really cute and aesthetic, and smells of waffles... yummm! We did the flight of ice cream which comes with four single scoop flavors. We had the strawberry tres leche, salted caramel, almond brittle, and chocolate brownie. All were delicious and fulfilling. Recommend doing the flight of ice cream with another to share!
author: Renee S.

description: I found my go to ice cream place! Well, it actually found me, as it just opened within minutes of my apartment. Part of me was hoping that it was another not so frosty ice cream dealer that I could easily stay away from. Truth is: it is everything I ever wanted when it comes to ice cream. I stood in line (!) for about 30 minutes on their opening day and it was so worth it. They let you try the different flavors and I went with Chocolate Brownie (a no brainer) and Olive Oil & Lemon Custard. I loved both flavors. Creamy, but still reasonably solid. The Olive Oil one was my favorite, I'd come back for that anytime. Well, I'd come back for any of the flavors. Service was on point and I'm mostly very happy with my new neighbor. The part of me that handles finances and workouts not so much.
author: Katja S.

description:
5 stars for the line not being too long & for the flavors I've tried, there is a huge menu I would definitely come back & travel far for.

Honey lavender -if you like floral tasting stuff then this is it, I love how it's not too strong where I would get tired of it fast
Chocolate brownie- the sweetness level is just right
author: Precious C.

description:
Best ice cream ever IMO

They let you try flavors!!!!
author: Esther K.

description:
I missed stopping by Salt & Straw when I was in Portland and was so upset - but so happy to hear that they opened a location here! 

Location: Right in the fillmore, great for a pre- or post-shopping treat. Parking is mega difficult in that area. The line is very long, but please be courteous and don't block residences and businesses! 

Service: The folks here are SO nice! They'll give you a great summary of every flavor and give you so many yummy samples. 

Now.... at $5 a scoop, this ice cream is pretty expensive. But I think it's a good treat once in a while. They have some super creative flavors and some even more creative seasonal ones as well. 

My favorite ice cream flavor is honey lavendar - and they did it really well. Perfect balance of the floral and sweet without making it taste like soap. That's how you know they're good. 

Stop by for a sweet treat! The line is worth it.
author: Shelley K.

description: Just let the smell of fresh waffle cones being pressed drags you in. Line has been long. Or, grab a pint of pre-scooped ice cream from their freezer inside and skip the line. The hold up? Everyone trying each flavor. Naturally i did the same . . Stand outs were the Salted Honey Marshmallows & Walnuts and their fruit based ones like Peach Cobbler and Strawberry. I've been to the PDX location and Whiz Bang Bar a couple of times yet the hype of Salt & Straw making it's way to SF still got to me. Happy to have another ice cream shop in the city!
author: Samantha L.

description:
Oh my, we waited over 45 minutes on their second day of opening... for the BEST ice cream we've had! When we first joined the line, it didn't look very intimidating. However the line moved slowly - the only caveat of the wonderful and patient service they have for their customers. At the front of the line, there were a couple servers that allowed you (and the friends in your group) to taste however many flavors you'd like until you knew what you wanted! I think we tried half the menu among the four of us, and our server was INCREDIBLY patient and insisted we try more if we wanted. Best service ever! I ended up choosing a single scoop of the honey lavender on a waffle scone... so, so delicious.  It was exceptionally fragrant and light. My boyfriend had the roasted strawberry tres leches. This was the best strawberry ice cream we've had, but it did taste too sweet as we ate more of it. We enjoyed our ice cream inside the store - there are several seats by the window, but if it's crowded, there is space to stand around too. 

If you love all the flavors or cannot decide which one to order, they have a tasting flight of four flavors for $11.50! We didn't order this, but we saw many people who did. 

Lastly, the only con is that their waffles are inconsistent. Two of the four cones we ordered were stale... and the other two were amazing. Luckily we had boyfriends we could steal the amazing cones from!
author: Christine L.

description:
I've gone to the Portland locations and the LA location. The Portland ones are comparatively roomier, cleaner and more inviting. LA is more tightly packed, but feels cozy because they stuff it with merchandise. The SF location has a lot of empty, unused space, so the ambiance is not 100%. The flavors are just as unique as the other locations. However, my ice cream melted pretty quickly upon purchase, so either the freezer isn't turned up high enough or they're using too much cream. It wasn't as mindblowing of an experience as the other times I've had Salt and Straw in Portland. But still worth trying in SF.

Service wise, I came on a Thursday at 7pm, right at prime dinner time so the line wasn't that long. I imagine it gets much longer post-dinner. I wasn't too bothered with the wait and our server was incredibly patient with us and encouraging us to try samples. Great service.
author: Melissa T.

description:
The line was an hour long my and passers-by would ask me if it's worth it. Well, considering that I flew up to Portland once to eat this ice cream, I suppose it's worth it. :-) The flavors are really complex and bright, and they are very original. The textures include smooth and creamy, crunchy, buttery, gooey, etc.  It's a different experience than the purest flavors of Bi-Rite, or the smooth texture of Smitten.  

So go for the experience of standing in line, sampling all the flavors, and sitting on the little bench outside to talk to strangers who ask you if it's worth it.
author: Benjamin H.

description: Parking was a little hard since it's all street parking. The store was very clean and was appealing. The workers were also welcoming. I basically sampled all the flavors and the worker was super patient and nice about it. Their most famous flavor was the sea salt with caramel ribbons which was my favorite as well. It's a little pricey where 2 scoops for a cup is $7, but it really is worth a try. Overall it was a good experience and I will definitely be coming back!
author: Tracey N.

description: Line is long, but it is so worth it! Customer service is amazing, they're so patient even though understaffed, and they won't make you feel bad for trying all their delicious flavors. All their flavors are SO GOOD. They're interesting, with a twist to keep you on your toes, from peach vinegar cobbler, to green apple mayo. You can taste the quality! Also you simply cannot NOT get their fresh made cones (arguably as good as the ice cream itself). I fell in love with salt and straw in Portland, and I am so happy it's in my city now!!
author: Ke C.

description: The line was short when I arrived and seemed to take forever. I do understand people were trying all the flavors as they are unique. Flavor tasting is crucial because the flavors I went to get were not very good, the Carmel ribbon was way too much Carmel, over powering and salty. The brownie ice cream was good. The strawberry is the most popular, but I found it hard to eat as there was so many components. Tasted like apple pie in it, which was good, but too over powering. Usually I enjoy lots of components but it was too much. Ice cream is great quality though. Price is ridiculous for ice cream.
author: Brielle W.

description:
There was shockingly no line when we got there on a Saturday night, but then a bunch of people came in after. 

They have the classic flavors (slightly different from what I recall from the Portland fun LA locations), then they have monthly seasonal flavors (you can sign up for email updates on flavors). 

There's not much room to hang out inside, but Fillmore is probably one of the nicest streets to hang out at in SF. 

As usual, the staff is extremely patient with letting you sample. 

If you want to bypass the line, you can go straight for the pints to go.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Finally, my favorite Portland treat made its debut in San Francisco! The flavors are all an ode to the fresh produce and locally grown ingredients that you'll encounter in the bay area , and they partner with local businesses like Dandelion chocolate. I sampled:
- green apple mayo: surprisingly refreshing and light, you can't taste any mayo.
- almond smores: yummy crunchy toasted flavor (I ended up buying a scoop of this)
- sightglass coffee & dandelion chocolate: intense espresso flavor
- peach vinegar cobbler: like eating a fresh peach pie mmm

Can't wait to come back in the future to see their rotating exclusively SF flavors. Also FYI you can have as many samples as you want! Welcome to SF!!
author: Wendy L.

description: This is my favorite spot! The line is a bit long but it was well worth it!!! Big scoops and and taste great! I'm in love, I can't wait to go back for their seasonal flavors
author: Katherine D.

description:
Amazing five-star ice cream, but docking a star for the overall so-so experience.

Brought a friend here who was visiting from out of town since I'd heard great things about Salt & Straw and knew that they had just opened a location in SF. We came at about 6pm on Sunday and the line was roughly 20 people long. I didn't think it would be a terrible wait and so we decided to stick it out. It ended up being a wait of over an hour, and just because of pure inefficiency and probably because the employees were new and still learning how to do their jobs. The line barely moved, and once we were part of the line inside the store, it was still a good 15 minutes to our turn. 

We opted to do both a tasting flight of 4 flavors plus a single cone (yes, we're fatties I know =P) so that we could try more things. We got the wildflower honey with ricotta walnut lace cookies, roasted strawberry tres leches, sea salt with caramel ribbons, and chocolate gooey brownie in the tasting flight, plus a single scoop of the sightglass coffee + dandelion chocolate w/ a waffle cone. Amazing, amazing flavors and my mouth was in heaven. It's too hard to choose which one was my favorite!

Props to the worker who was helping us for giving us generous spoonfuls of flavors we wanted to try before ordering, but I had to repeat my order several times before she got it right, and she didn't know where each flavor was located and had to run around opening all the lids before finding the right one. There was no line at the register and the bottleneck was definitely all within the ordering station. 

Once they are able to smooth out the ordering kinks, I'd love to come by more often. I do wish there was more seating (there were only ~4 stools at the front of the store), especially for those opting for the tasting flight but have nowhere to eat it. But in the meantime, you can always just grab a pint and head straight to the register, so you're in and out!
author: Vivian L.

description:
I first experienced Salt & Straw in Portland and fell in love with it. I never thought an ice cream shop could be so amazing! I came to this SF shortly after I came back from Portland and was not disappointed. They are pretty much the same. The only big difference I noticed is that the SF store is super brightly lit, whereas Portland was very dim. Everything is delicious here- my favorite is the Freckled Woodblock Chocolate which is a salty chocolate. There is always a long line but it's worth every minute.

They have new limited edition flavors every month so it's difficult not to want to come back and see what's new. There are really interesting limited edition flavors. I remember in October they had a matcha flavor with real crickets and mealworms (from a local vendor in Oakland- Don Bugito), and in November they had a mashed potatoes flavor!
author: Linh N.

description:
This is good ice cream. I'm not sure what great ice cream even is, but this is good. I've sampled the following flavors:

- Honey Lavender: no kidding, this has a very strong lavender flavor. It's good if you're into that.

- Terenga Baobab Juice & Coconut: the coconut part is not strongly apparent. The ginger-baobab blend of flavors is unusually refreshing and interesting, so that's a fairly strong recommendation.

- Chocolate gooey brownie: as far as chocolate goes, this is fine, but I was a little put off by the texture of the brownie chunks in the ice cream. 

A very important commonality of all these flavors is that they're not overly sweet -- in fact, I rarely have ice cream where the sensation of pure sugar is so markedly absent. I appreciated the focus on actual flavor.
author: John L.

description: I sampled several flavors, but the lavender honey is the best among those I tried. The staff is friendly. The scoop prices are reasonable. It's not the best ice cream ever, but it's above the curve.
author: John J.

description: I stood in line on the second day Salt & Straw opened for 1 hour and 15 minutes, and the wait was worth it! The individual that served me was extremely patient and helpful! There are so many unique flavors, and I had a hard time picking just one; so I decided on a double scoop and I split both scoops so I could have four flavors (chocolate gooey brownie, peach vinegar cobbler with nutmeg, olive oil & lemon custard, and caramelized almond s'more).
author: Keisha K.

description:
I am giving this place a full stars because their service is really good. We came to this place because of a recommendation from my sister. We waited in line for about 10 mins which was actually perfect because it gave us time to look at the menu and decide what we wanted. This place is unique in the sense that each server has their own pod of all the ice-cream flavors decreasing wait time and allowing each server to spend time with their customers vs having to shuffle around scooping ice-cream. 

Fun Fact that our server told us: Each of their locations has different flavors in addition to having seasonal flavors!

Our server was extremely nice and did not make us feel like we were trying too many flavors. I have a huge problem deciding when presented with a wide variety of ice-cream combinations that I have never heard of before but the server did not make me feel like I was taking too much time or couldn't try what I wanted too. 

We tried the sea-salt & caramel ribbon, almond brittle with salted ganache, roasted strawberry tres leeches, peach vinegar cobbler with toasted nutmeg, honey lavender, olive oil and lemon custard. We got the roasted strawberry tres leeches (!!!!) and peach vinegar cobbler w/ toasted nutmeg. 

I also sampled some of their halloween flavors but did not love them. They are really well made and go so well with the halloween theme! Love the creativity!!
author: Minati D.

description: I'm a fan of their monthly flavor theme. They are really unique and adds so much more variety to their already large regular selection. Last June was about limiting food waste. I had the roasted sunchoke mock apple pie, which I actually was not that big on, but sure enough tasted like sunchoke. I absolutely loved the imperial stout wort and peaberry coffee bark. Last July was all about berries, so I had Meyer Lemon Buttermilk with Blueberries as well as the creme fraiche and strawberries. really nice fruit and cream pairings. I also tried the Goat Cheese marionberry habanero, which really did deliver on all three flavors, impressively. I was a little bit underwhelmed by the freckled Woodblock chocolate. I like woodblock chocolate, but the flavor was not as rich. The sea salt with caramel ribbons by comparison was exactly how I imagined it. Love the sightglass and dandelion chocolate too, a SF-specific flavor. I also tried a skittles flavor they had during Pride, and it just reminded me of rainbow sherbet. It looked just like it too. Overall, I sometimes come across flavors I'm not too big on, but I love the experimentation and variety so it's all good.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
BEST ice cream in the nation!

We fell in love with Salt & Straw in Portland during a road trip to the Pacific NW last summer. Their Carrot Cake Batter & Pralined Hazelnuts is hands down the most delicious ice cream I have ever tasted! We make a point of stopping at their LA locations whenever we can & are thrilled they chose to open in SF.

A group of us (kids+adults) were on Fillmore St today for the grand opening & enjoyed the festive, welcoming atmosphere. Staff encouraged us to "sample all 17 flavors!" and the co-founder made his way through the crowds welcoming people in too. 

All four of us agreed that this ice cream takes the craft to a whole new level. Much as I love our locally owned creameries, Salt & Straw's quality really is far above them all. 

Love the inventive, luscious, sometimes savory ice creams. And their split scoop is something I hope more SF creameries will adopt too. We'll be back soon!
author: Sharand N.

description:
The line was short when I arrived on a Monday afternoon. Service is great.  They let you sample the ice cream as many as you like. 

Worker said the most popular items are Sea salt Caramel Ribbon and Roasted strawberry Tres Leaches. Sea Salt Caramel was too sweet for me but Roasted Strawberry was really good. Kinda tasted like cheesecake. Decided to get Strawberry and Freckled Woodblock Chocolate. 

Portions are huge. You will be surprised!
author: Maki K.

description:
This shop opened on Fillmore last month, and I went to check it out with some friends. The line was very long. Very long. We waited just over an hour. This shows our true dedication to exploring the ice cream scene in San Francisco. Once we arrived at the front of the line, I was impressed with the kind customer service, and focus on us. The flavors were varied. I'm betting you can feed your craving of a flavor you want (caramel, vanilla, chocolate), or try something more exotic.

If this place was cheaper, I would have given it 5 stars.
author: Jason P.

description:
My goodness.

Salt and Straw puts different flavors in into tastes that you cannot describe!! I came here 3 times last week hahaha, but their flavors are amazing!! There were three different types of chocolate flavors and some surprising ones like Duck Fat ice cream. The wait is pretty long, but it's worth it!! The ice cream is pricier than other ice cream spots in the bay, $5 a scoop. And they charge extra for waffle cones. So tempting coming into the shop and you get a good whiff of warm waffle cone. It's a trap!!
author: Aileene S.

description: Just simply the best. So glad we have this Portland favorite here in SF now! I had the black olive brittle goat cheese ice cream. SO GOOD! Very rich, i might suggest getting it as a half scoop and pairing it with another favorite. But a delicious sweet and savory ice cream.
author: SHELLEY M.

description:
If you're in San Francisco and the clock hasn't yet run out on 2017, run -- don't walk! -- to Salt & Straw for their Apple Brandy & Pecan Pie ice cream. According to the store's signage, this flavor is being retired at the year's end, which is a huge shame, considering it was the best ice cream/gelato I've ever enjoyed. (To put that into perspective, I ate at San Gimignano's Gelateria Dondoli in 2009, the year they won World's Best Gelato.) 

I entered believing I'd get their [also seasonal/soon-to-retire] Gingerbread Cookie Dough ice cream, so when we finally got to the head of the deservedly long line and a very friendly staff member asked if we could sample anything, I deferred to my fiancé. He tried several flavors and licked the sample spoons clean, but when he got to the apple brandy and pecan pie, he turned to me wide-eyed and said, "You have to taste this," almost shoveling the half-sampled spoon in my mouth, knowing how much I'd love it once I tasted it. The staff member helping us chimed in, "A lot of people say it tastes like Christmas," and it does in the sense that it's a magical gift to your tastebuds, so delicious that every bite and lick elicits the child-like anticipation and overwhelming joy of Christmas morning. 

The ice cream itself is flavored with apple brandy, dotted with generous chunks of pecan pie.  I've NEVER liked pecan pie, but Salt & Straw's was so good that I could've easily enjoyed the pie on its own -- I also could've enjoyed the apple brandy ice cream solo, but Salt and Straw made an excellent call in combining them to make one orgasmic ice cream.  Seriously, before this, I can't recall any food that has ever made me moan aloud in uncontainable pleasure.
author: Katelyn R.

description: Five stars for the service and taste, but this place does not have enough vegan flavors. Often it's only one, and I have actually walked out and just gotten ice cream from the grocery store for that very reason. Please add more vegan flavors!
author: Marissa B.

description:
I FREAKED OUT!!! I went to Portland last year and I screamed when I saw that they were gonna open one here too. I went there hoping to get a certain flavor but forgot that each place has different ones. They're all about locally sourced, in season, etc so of course my flavor from Portland wasn't here which super bummed me out!

They have a carrot cake flavor right now for the season and it's soooooo freaking good. Open pretty late and there is still always a line. Go, enjoy. Yes, it's worth it.
author: Ruby S.

description:
The ice cream is delicious. Cream of the crop. The flavors, unique and dynamic for sure. The line, long. Haha. Even if it doesn't look long, trust me, it moves slow. There's a reason that I'll explain in a bit. 

While I'm all for classic flavors, the creativity of this place deserves credit. Novelty flavors is what this place represents. They feature limited edition flavors that rotate I'm assuming. You can sample any flavor and as many as you want. To give an example of the flavorful chaos, they had salted caramel over turkey as a flavor around Thanksgiving. Not your cup of tea? Not mine as well, but...

I got the roasted strawberries tres leches. This was my kind of flavor. Sweet and rich. For the foodie adventure seekers though, think fancy flavors like honey lavender, butter roasted pecans, almond brittle with salted ganache, peach vinegar cobbler, or olive oil and lemon custard.  Flavors that you have to read three times over because your brain is confused that this is ice cream. 

A couple of observations though... 1) the line is long because the checkout process isn't quite efficient (maybe it's in the works). The scooper is also the one to ring you up so he/she has to stop serving and bounce back and forth between the register and ice cream. There was a point where I'm pretty sure, no, absolutely positive, that I could've just walked out without paying because no one was at the register for a few minutes. Everyone was scooping. 2) Sampling is awesome, but slows down the line big time.
author: Stacey L.

description: Probably one of the best ice cream places I have been to. The flavors are amazing! Highly recommend honey lavender and the strawberry. The workers are also super nice - they let you try as many as you want (we tried all of em) and were pretty honest with their opinions on the ice cream.
author: Augustus Y.

description: My first time here!!! The staff who took our order was really nice and kind! To me, the first and the second most popular flavors (sea slat caramel and almond brittle) are not my fav one. I ordered Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches which is taste like strawberry cheesecake , not too sweet and very light. Its texture is really good as well. I'd recommend to try this unique ice cream place. You'll find many amazing homemade ice cream flavors
author: Tiratiwan L.

description:
My new favorite ice cream place! The flavors are oh so intriguing and delicious in their combinations. Depending on your personal taste, you'll find what you like- or not. The flavors are bold and interesting and that's what makes it fun to eat, in my opinion! The texture is also very smooth. The ice cream melts in your mouth smoothly and with much flavor. I loved the ice cream that I got, which was Olive Oil & Lemon Custard and Salted Honey Marshmallow & Walnuts on a cone. I'll definitely be back to try their other flavors, including their limited edition flavors. 

The store also sells Dandelion Chocolate products- one of my favorite chocolate brands! They have one of their single-origin chocolate bars and a few of their collaboration products. One of the ice cream flavors is also made with their chocolate! Yum!
author: Joy C.

description:
My favorite ice cream place in San Francisco. You're not going to find their perfect combo of flavor intensity, creamy texture and unique flavor varieties at any of the other heavy hitters in SF (Bi-rite, Smitten, etc). 

They even vary a large portion of their menu every month, so you have all the more reason to be a regular. I can only imagine how devastated Portland's tourism industry is going to be.
author: Madhur B.

description: This is my favorite ice cream in SF (just edging out Bi-Rite and Humphry Slocombe which are also excellent!). I am addicted to the Salt Caramel Ribbons flavor and these guys make the best ice cream cones around!
author: Bennett V.

description: This place is SUPPPPER yummy! We came here after trying a sample of their ice cream at Museum of Ice cream & we completely in love with the unique taste! They make their ice cream HAND MADE guys! I got the salted Carmel and my friend had the honey lavender! Both were sooo delicious! I loved the honey lavender way more than my own chosen flavor. The shop itself is super cute and clean as well! The staff is amazing. They have their merchandise displayed all around the shop. I really, really wanted to purchase a beanie but told myself "next time" so I can for sure be back when I'm in the city visiting.
author: Jatinder K.

description:
I LOVE that Salt & Straw is now in SF. And not one but two shops. Have to admit I wasn't sure they would open since April 1st had passed and no word on seasonal flavors, but they came through and opened mid-month with some tasty flavors.

We came on a Saturday night a few weeks after opening day. Foolish me I was not prepared for the line down the block which ended up being an hour long wait. It's Salt and Straw though so we waited in the cold.

Once it was our turn to order, I went for it, trying all of the new flavors leaving nothing untasted. Don't be shy here. They encourage you to try some or all of their flavors and I love that about them. My favorites were the some of the SF classic flavors but as always there were a few rotational flavors that were good too.

Note, if you're not familiar with Salt & Straw, they have 12 "classic" flavors; six unique to each city they have shops: Portland, LA and now SF,  and six available at all of their shops. These 12 will always be available.

The Friday before the first of every month they offer a changing menu of at least 5 flavors that follows a theme across all shops. The flavors and ingredients are unique to the city in which they're served. April was different for the opening of the SF shop in that they opened mid-month and didn't follow the same Inventor's Series theme of the other shops. Nonetheless we enjoyed trying what they came up with :)

*SF Classics*
- Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches: while I like Portland's Strawberry Balsamic, I can't resist gobs of carby mix-ins. Not sure if tres leches specifically comes through but I'm definitely ordering again to verify
- Peach Vinegar Cobbler with Toasted Nutmeg: my favorite SF classic flavor so far. I can rarely resist cobbler, crisp and the like. The fruit was sweet but not cloyingly. Trust me just order this.
- Sightglass Coffee and Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate: Salt and Straw's best coffee flavor. Coffee flavor really comes through while pairing nicely with the chocolate
- Olive Oil Lemon Custard: my second favorite SF classic flavor. The olive oil flavor is subtle but adds a nice texture. The lemon custard was lovely. Citrus fans should scoop this
- Salted Honey Marshmallow and Walnuts: the Salted honey is definitely prominent which I liked but the marshmallow fluff swirl overwhelmed my sample. Need to scoop it to get a better feel for the taste.
- Teranga Baobab Juice & Coconut: need to try this flavor again. I can't decide if I like it or not yet

*SF April Flavors*
- Cinnamon Ancho & Cajeta: very cinnamon forward but I enjoyed it.
- Caramelized Almond Smores: I wanted more almond and graham cracker swirl in this, but the Marshmallow just took over
- Cascara Shrub it's Candied Hibiscus: haven't tried anything like it before, kind of liked it but I didn't get a scoop
- Green Apple Mayo Sherbet: mayo overpowered the green Apple in the sample. I think maybe in a scoop I might've enjoyed it more. Really creamy texture too
- Strawberry Coriander Leaf Sorbet: good strawberry flavor but I wanted creamy ice cream this trip

Salt and Straw has now taken a strong 1st of place in my list of best ice cream shops in the Bay Area. Run, don't walk, and taste this amazingly delicious and creative ice cream!
author: Lindsey C.

description: Incredible ice cream and delicious original flavors! While visiting SF I tried their peach vinegar cobbler with toasted nutmeg ice cream and it was delicious! I also tried the dracula's blood pudding (seasonal flavor for fall) and it was sooo good! Both were flavorful, and weren't overly sweet. I'm not a fan of cones but I highly recommend their house made waffle cones - you can smell them being made fresh from outside the parlor. Crispy and totally worth it! I heard these are sold in pints in New York, so I'm glad I can at least get my hands on them in the east coast until I can visit SF again!
author: Cristina V.

description: First discovered this in Portland around 3yrs ago. It was the most outstanding ice cream I ever had ... At the time.  Nowadays, however, there are so many local ice cream shops that are just as good if not better. Salt n Straw comes a little late for me and wasn't as excited as I was the first time I tried it. Still great ice cream but just not the greatest in a town now filled with other awesome shops ;-)
author: Melinda V.

description: Probably the best ice cream I ever had
author: Kevin L.

description:
Salt & Straw gets really experimental with their flavors. On the menu here is bone marrow and cherry as well as olive oil and lemon curd. It's really a hit or miss in terms of which flavor you get, but I will say all are consistently rich, smooth and creamy without being overwhelmingly heavy. 

The selling point at the store is that you can stand up front and try as many flavors as you want. This naturally results in the line backing up and it's pretty variable how long it'll take. Usually very speedy, however. If you're with friends, get the tasting flight to maximize returns.
author: Annie M.

description:
Multiple 5 star votes, from both myself and all the friends I have brought here, who all muttered in unison as they crushed this ice cream: "this is so freaking good!"  This place will turn you into an ice cream fiend.

Do not, I repeat do not, miss out on the Peach Cobbler!!! This is my favorite ice cream in America. My friends say the same. Also amazing are the Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches and the Banana Bread Pudding. Don't stop eating for anything-- someone might take it away from you.

The reason why Salt and Straw is head and shoulders better than any other ice cream is because each and every one is hiding a full scale bakery dessert inside the ice cream. What? An incredible 5 star dessert inside an incredible 5 star ice cream? Actual peach cobbler in a complimentary ice cream to die for? Impossible you say? Go find out!!
author: Camille B.

description: I was excited to try this place out since everyone keeps talking about it. We went after our brunch/lunch. There was a little line and it wasn't bad at all. The customer service was good, but sometimes you feel rushed. We got to try the different flavors. The flavors were on point! The ice cream is really good. You don't get much for the price, but that's okay. My husband got the rootbeer float and it was kind of dinky for the price. There isn't much seating room, but we were able to snag an area to sit. The line kept on getting longer and longer. One time, okay. I don't think I'll be back for awhile. There are some other quality creameries around that are cheaper with bigger portions.
author: Crissy G.

description:
LOOOVEEE!!! 

I'm so excited a Salt & Straw location opened up in the Bay Area! Ice cream is my favorite thing ever and I've never been to the Portland location or any of the ones in Southern California. 

I wish I didn't live an hour away so I can be a frequent customer and try out all their different flavors, but knowing yesterday would be my only opportunity for a while, I HAD to try their Honey Lavender-- it's one of my favs! And.. I was NOT disappointed. Mmm so, so good!! Very reminiscent of Santa Clara's Mission City Creamery's honey lavender, which is also homemade. Super delicious! 

Service was great. We were greeted by friendly employees and the line wasn't that long when we stopped in. Guess we were just lucky. Hope to be back again soon!!
author: Jessica D.

description: Salted malted cookie dough was insanely delicious. Only request would be more pieces of cookie dough in the ice cream because the few pieces in it were SO good. Best artisan ice cream I have ever tasted. Line moved quickly and the store itself is darling. Can't wait to go back and try more flavors!!!
author: S A.

description:
TIP: If you're just picking up a pint, skip the line!

Never thought I would be the type of person to stand in line for 40 minutes on the second day after the grand opening of an ice cream shop, but that's exactly where I found myself in front of Salt and Straw.

Tried the following flavors:
- Honey Lavender (3/5): Very strong tasting and not nearly as light as I expected. The taste of this ice cream was mostly lavender and surprisingly overpowered even heavier flavors like the chocolate and coffee I tried. Out of the four flavors I tried, this was my least favorite and I would have replaced it with another scoop of the other flavors if I could choose again.
- Sightglass coffee and Dandelion chocolate (4/5): More chocolatey than coffee-flavored but the ice cream was nice and creamy with good depth of flavor without being too rich or overwhelming. The chocolate nibs instead added some nice crunch and difference in texture to the ice cream.
- Strawberry and tres leches (4/5): Honestly just tastes like good strawberry ice cream until you hit the chunks of cake which honestly taste like the graham crust of a cheesecake which wasn't necessarily a bad thing.
- Olive oil and lemon (5/5): YES. YES. Y-E-S. Really hit a gold mine here. The flavor was perfectly creamy and the lemon flavor was just enough without being overpowering. The flavor was just really light and refreshing overall without being too sweet.

The workers were also fantastically patient despite all the people asking for tons of samples of each and every flavor. 

Overall, the ice cream wasn't as creamy as Bi-Rite or others but that made the ice cream feel lighter and not as dense either. I'll definitely be back some time!
author: Jason W.

description:
I absolutely love Salt & Straw. I've been to the Portland location, and enjoyed it just the same. The sweet scent as you walk in will overtake you and make you feel much happier than you were before you walked in.

Their vegan ice cream is incredible. There are only a few vegan flavors, changing often with the season, but they're good enough to overlook that minor gripe. It is so creamy (I believe it's coconut-based), perfectly sweet and flavorful. The employee helping us checked to make sure their waffle cones were vegan as well.

I happen to love this area of San Francisco, even if it may come off as a bit pretentious. I daydream about living in the beautiful surrounding homes, and taking in the magical views every day. I can't wait to come back, and only wish there were a Salt & Straw in Reno.
author: Claire H.

description: A+. Service was just as great as in Portland. They are generous with samples. At the end of the day we still got the almond brittle and sea salt caramel. Oh and 4 pints for takeaway. Mmm. Still winners in my book. Right now their special flavors are Farmers Market themed which means eat your veggies in ice cream form. Took about 20 minutes to get ice cream, lines out the door.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Ridiculous amount of wait (on one of SF's hottest nights--Sept 1, 2017). The staff was very friendly but the ice cream was way too sweet--and I have a sweet tooth.

Update: Salt & Straw reached out to me to invite me to have another scoop on them. Very kind of them.
author: Thomas D.

description: I got two scoops on a cone - honey lavender and salted honey marshamallow & walnuts. I really enjoyed the honey lavender. The salted honey marshmallow was a bit too sweet and I couldn't finish it. I also sampled most of the other flavors - they're all unique but I can't say that I enjoyed all of them. The waffle cone was really good though, make sure to get it!
author: Jeana Y.

description:
I had my first S&S experience in Portland, and it was fantastic. When I heard one had opened up in SF, I went to check it out as soon as I could. The Fillmore location pretty much always has a long line, but the customer service is fantastic. Employees come through the line to give you samples of all the creative flavors while you wait. By the time you get up to the counter, you've probably already tried everything and will know exactly what to get... the hardest part is making up your mind! I got the peach crumble bar this time around, and it was delicious (and dairy free... no issues for this lactard!) Move over Bi-Rite, Swenson's, and Smitten... I think I have a new favorite ice cream in the city!

S uch a variety of creative flavors
A lways sample as much as you can
L ong line, but it's worth the wait
T ry some of the tasty dairy-free options
author: Kenny L.

description: Being a local Portlander, I was curious to see how my hometown favorite showed up in San Francisco. I was so impressed with the new location! All of the staff were incredibly friendly and helpful, as I've come to expect. They offer small metal spoons for you to try all the unique flavors including seasonal  and year-round offerings. The interior is large enough to house a lot of people and there is plenty of sweet merchandise available for purchase! Worth the wait!
author: Mary S.

description: Super cute place! Smells of fresh waffle cones when you walk by. Everyone was so nice. The guy serving us didn't ask IF we wanted a sample, he just told us we could have as many samples as we wanted. They also use metal spoons for samples instead of creating a bunch of trash with plastic ones. Some of the flavors seem pretty odd, but were surprisingly good. Not the BEST ice cream I've ever had, but still pretty good.
author: A W.

description: Love this ice cream shop! It has unconventional ice cream flavors but they some how work! I love how you can sample as many as you want, and they don't judge you for it lol. I love the cheesecake and salted caramel flavors. Come with friends and family so you can try a bunch! Or come by yourself so you get all the yummy ice cream to yourself.
author: Joelle L.

description: Great ice cream with many options for everyone. I always have to try the seasonal ice creams because they're so unique and delicious. There is always something for everyone, even vegans! Staff is always extremely friendly and great about giving out samples. Highly recommend! :)
author: Brian O.

description: I went to Salt & Straw for the first time a couple weeks ago and it was an amazing experience.  It was a Friday night and the line was fairly long, but it moved fast.  I love that they let you sample as many flavors as you like and I did quite a bit of taste testing.  My favorites were the gooey chocolate brownie, the honey lavender and one of the seasonal offerings bone marrow and smoked cherries.  I ended up getting the bone marrow and smoked cherries because it was one of the limited seasonal flavors.  I got a single scoop, but splurged and upgraded to a waffle cone (a must as a first timer).  The ice cream was some of the best I have ever had; it was so creamy, with just the tiniest bit of savory as an aftertaste, because of the bone marrow.  I walked back to downtown with my cone in hand and it was honestly the perfect way to end a very long week.  I am both happy and sad that Salt & Straw is located out on Fillmore.  Part of me wishes they had a location closer to downtown, but part of me is also thankful that it is far enough away that I can't buy a cone every single day - because I would be very hard pressed not to.
author: Josie C.

description: I tried this chain down in LA and was hooked. I  tried all their flavors and the only good one was the roasted tres leches strawberry ice cream. Only downside was when the server handed my double scooped cone to me. The ice cream was placed lopsided and was about to fall off. I immediately pushed my mouth to it and some got on my nose. No way was I'm going to let some good ice cream go to waste. Only problem was the slow scooping because my mine was melting before it got to my mouth. Be back for more fatty goodness.
author: Eve H.

description:
Great variety.  GF options.   I had salted caramel which for me was too salty. 

Great changing flavors.  Waffle cones available.  Family liked it.
author: Jacob S.

description:
Best ice cream in town!! Their variety is outstanding. Awesome, fun staff. You can try any flavor you'd like, and they encourage you to try many of them! I love this place!

There's usually a line, however, so expect to wait a little. This place is awesome! Fun, unique flavors, and delicious all in one!

Highly recommend!
author: Yotam I.

description:
The line is always long, even thought it is 10 pm in the cold and windy Fillmore neighborhood. However it is worth to wait!!! 

Everything was so tasty and unique!! The friendly staff gave us everything we want to sample. We ended up getting two flights and double scoops. Waffle cone is delicious too.
author: Ffaahh N.

description: I've come to this place twice in my life, the first time in late May and the second time just last week. Every single time I come to Salt N Straw, I am never disappointed. Both times there was nobody in the shop because I came on weekday afternoons, so obviously the service was pretty fabulous. The first time I came, our server even OFFERED us to sample each four of us every single flavor on the menu! Their unique flavors were all super delicious, and I could never find another kind of creaminess and specialty in ice cream anywhere else. They even had metal spoons for samples, something that I think is really cool and environment-friendly. Their scoops were generous, and the pricing for a boutique-unique ice cream shop is adequate. Our server Andy was ESPECIALLY marvelous!! I enjoyed every single flavor that I've ever tasted in this ice cream shop, but I must say that my favorites were the almond brittle, arbequina olive oil, goat cheese, and honey lavender.
author: Kristine C.

description: Wowza! Best ice-cream of my life! The unique flavors are decadent. I tried probably half of their menu and the workers were great about it. I eventually went with Sightglass coffee and almond brittle for my brownie sundae. Heads up, the brownie wasn't good so stick with the ice cream. I even tried my friend's dairy free scoops and they were good too! Don't worry about the line, it moves fast! Pro-tip--if you get a pint, you can skip the line.
author: Laurisha C.

description:
Roasted strawberry tres leches ice cream is so refreshing with strawberry jam. Highly recommend it!  Sightglass coffee and single origin dandelion chocolate ice cream has tiny toffee crunch in every bite. Interesting combo! However,  I don't like the bold coffee flavor which overpowers the chocolate flavor in the ice cream.

Price is decent for the city. $5 for a scoop. Have some very interesting ice cream flavors. The wait time may be longer on the weekends. They sell a variety of ice cream in pint which you can grab and go without waiting in the long line. However, you may miss the chance to sample a couple of flavors before buying it.
author: Yumi G.

description: I love their honey lavender and that's like the only ice cream flavor I get here. It has a very strong lavender taste rather than honey. I sample all the weird sounding and unique tasting ice cream of course but still not able to get myself to get it! The service here is really quick and the waiting in line ain't that bad, maybe about 15 minutes. Definitely less than the wait time in Portland. One scoop cost $5 already and double scoop is $7, waffle cone is extra $1.25. Their pints are $11 and to me that's kind of costly.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Super unique flavor offerings with quite possibly the most enthusiastic staff! Honey Lavender and Olive Oil Lemon Custard are my two standard favorites. They give such generous samples, which I really appreciate! If you can't quite decide which flavor to go for you can always opt for the ice cream flight too :) There's usually a short line out the door but it moves fairly quickly. I'd say def come give it a try if you're craving for some quality ice cream!
author: Mandy H.

description: First time here and I got the flavor Strawberry Tres Leches. It was delicious. I am not ever a fan of strawberry ice cream but this was different. It is their most popular flavor so definitely sample it when you're there. There was a long line but it went by pretty quickly. The service was stellar. Love how they come up to you in line first.
author: Rebecca T.

description: My husband and I were pretty excited to hear that salt & straw was opening in San Francisco. We have been anticipating their grand opening for quite some time. The day finally arrived when we had the time and pleasure of visiting SF. We came after dinner around 7PM to a 20 minute wait. The service is good although I felt they needed more service providers. The line doesn't move too fast here. The ice cream although a bit expensive was very good. Definitely worth the wait.
author: Sarah C.

description: Delicious, and worth the wait.  The line went quick and the flavors were quirky but great.
author: Jason L.

description: I jumped off the Muni 1 while passing by when I saw there was no line! Check out their seasonal ice cream flavors. I had rhubarb, and it so creamy, yummy good. Go on "off" hours if you can or early in the day, otherwise there will most likely be a line. Bring good company or a book!
author: Maile N.

description: Great quality ice cream. Organic and fresh. One of my favorite ice cream shops. Every month they have a new theme. This month (August) was farmers market. My favorite was the carrot cake batter. Tastes like your literally eating carrot cake. I'm sad that it's only a limited time flavor. So get it while you can. It truly is the best!
author: Casey W.

description: All the flavors here are amazing! I am obsessed with the black olive & goat cheese ice cream. I actually bought an extra pint which melted before I got home, but refroze pretty good. Definitely worth a visit!
author: Julia L.

description: Xander should be employee of the month! The guy is patient and a total happiness ambassador. Oh yah, the ice cream is good here too. ;) I got the almond brittle/ganache and coffee/choco.
author: dianne l.

description:
FIRST TIMER!!

Walking within 100ft from this place already has you smelling their homemade waffles! This is located on the corner of Fillmore street and the line was around the corner (not too bad though). One good thing I like about this place is that you sample EVERYTHING that you want, and they don't have a problem with you trying them all. With that being said, after all the samples my boyfriend and I tried, we ended up getting a split scoop of SF's classics: Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches and Chocolate Gooey Brownie to top it off. This combination will have you craving more, because we did! I really recommend this place if you are in the area, even if it is cold out. But, whoever said it was too cold for ice cream right? 

PS-I APPRECIATE all the friendliness and smiles that the working staff had to offer to every customer that came into the door. Our patience for this delicious scoop of ice cream was WORTH the wait!
author: Chazmine D.

description: Wide ice cream flavors options. Maybe event to much and to many but those lines means something and yup they were delicious !
author: Jerry B.

description:
I'm a bit torn. Salt & Straw is basically legendary, and I was really looking forward to its SF opening, but given that artisanal ice cream is all the rage these days, does S&S really live up to its expectations? In my opinion, not really. 

The original Portland location with the really long line's claim to fame is its interesting flavors and pairings, but ice cream places in SF like Bi-Rite, Smitten, and my personal favorite, Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous, all do this much better than S&S in my opinion. The S&S flavors are still interesting but I don't think their texture is as smooth and creamy as some other places. I think once the hype dies down, S&S will settle into one of the many great options in SF for ice cream. 

They have an ever-rotating and SF inspired flavors in this location, with very cool seasonal sorbet options as well.
author: Kate M.

description:
Excellent ice cream! I am a huge fan of salted caramel/sea salt flavors in ice cream so I was stoked to try their sea salt ice cream with caramel. I am someone who's usually disappointed with the salted caramel ice creams at other places because the salt flavor is so minimal (clearly, I love salt!). The flavor here is comparable to my favorite salted caramel ice cream from Jeni's. 

I'm giving four stars because I found there was small chunks of ice cubes in the ice cream as I was eating it. I absolutely hate finding ice chips/chunks in ice cream. It makes me think the place hasn't quite perfected the art of ice cream. Otherwise, I highly recommend and I can't wait to be back to try the other flavors. 

Another pro: adequate parking even on a weekend night!
author: Kelly L.

description: The ice cream here is amazing! By far my favorite! We drive all the way from Modesto to come here. I recommend the olive oil ice cream. Weird right? They have other flavors that are very unique and delicious! 5 stars!!!!!!!!!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
I stumbled here during opening week and was lured in by be smell of sugar wafting down the block. 

Get the salt and caramel. Thank me later.
author: Darcy P.

description: I had the best ice at this establishment. The people were wonderful! Who wouldn't be serving people some of the best ice on earth? I selected two scoops, one of the Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache and another scoop of the Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons. It was truly delicious ice cream experience. It made me wish that I lived in SFO so I could have it more often and it made me glad I did not live in SFO so I would have it more often. You know what I mean?!!! Hope you get to try it, too.
author: Enoch P.

description: Why is this place so popular?  Why did I wait in a line that wrapped around the building for OK ice cream?  Between my husband and I we had the California Honey Rocky Road, Chocolate Gooey Brownie and Marshmallow Honey Walnut.  Was not too impressed with any of them as well as the other flavors that we sampled.  Definitely willing to give them another try, however can't justify the 20 minute wait for this place!
author: Jann B.

description: Portland based ice cream place that uses local ingredients to make DELICIOUS ice cream. They have a rotating menu that offers new seasonal flavors, and that menu changes every 3 months or so. Only about $5 for a large ice cream-- all the flavors are delicious, please try them all so I don't feel bad about setting that as a goal for myself.
author: Lai-Nin W.

description: This place is my new addiction!! Ice cream is incredible! Customer service is on point, super friendly!
author: Michelle D.

description:
Not worth the hype at all. I tried it when I visited Portland and thought those locations were way better. Since I enjoyed it while I was there, I was pretty excited for them to open up in SF.

Oh but I was SO wrong. We came on one of the first weekend they opened and the line was crazy. Their staff did not know how to manage the line at all. Out of the 4 people you can see working behind the counters, only 1 person was actively scooping ice cream for customers. They instead had 2 busy busy making waffle cones, even though there's already a ton of waffle cones available on the counter, and 1 guy standing behind the register to check out guests. However, with every single customer in line wanting to try like 6 different flavors, they took about 10 mins just to serve 1 person. Most inefficient line management I've seen at a popular ice cream place. 

Other than the poor line management, by the time it was finally my turn, they gave me the tiniest scoop of ice cream. For how much they are charging I genuinely felt cheated. Not to mention my ice cream was half melted so it was instantly dripping everywhere all over me before I could finish paying. 

Bi-rite and Mr & Mrs are still way better ice cream places in SF. Salt & Straw doesn't even come close.
author: Julia M.

description: I've died and gone to heaven! Thank you Salt & Straw for making the best tasting ice cream I have ever had in my life and finally coming to San Francisco! I love that they're open until 11pm for a late night ice cream fix. By that time, the usually enormous line that wraps around the block has died down. We tried the Honey Lavender in a sugar cone and a double of the Salted honey marshmallow and Gooey chocolate brownie in a cup. I have also had the Coffee flavor paired with the Carmel ribbons and it was amazing!
author: Taryn S.

description:
Salt & Straw has finally made it's way to the Bay! After seeing all my friends hit this place up in LA and Portland, I was so happy I'd get a chance to add it to my list of ice cream escapades. Seeing their unique flavor offerings against a sea of standard "gourmet ice cream" places (exception being Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous which you must go to as well!) had me dying to grab a bite.

So my sister and I trekked our way over here up a massive hill from the Marina and decided on a scoop of the Sightglass coffee and Dandelion chocolate (really tongue in cheek nod to knowing their local brands), plus the vinegar peach cobbler. First off, the scoops we got were MASSIVE. Not sure if this was because we got an amazing worker or that's just how they do things. Both were so creamy and packed with the flavor of their namesake--it made other artisan ice cream places I've tried seem bland in comparison! The acidity of the vinegar really balanced the sweetness of the peach and of course, I loved the cinnamon-y cobbler bits.The only thing is it melts incredibly fast, even though we visited on a chilly SF day.

The workers were super helpful and friendly and move the line fast. They also have a rotation of much weirder seasonal flavors like zucchini bread ice cream which you should be sure to sample for fun.

I will definitely be back to sample their Honey Lavender and indulge in whatever flavors they come up with next
author: Rene B.

description: Stumbled into this shop while we were walking around. Super bright and very clean. Smells amazing! Lots of cute souvenirs to buy and luxury chocolates. Unique flavors of ice cream and really delicious.
author: Taylor J.

description:
I am not sure what all the hype is about...I was extremely excited for this SF location after following S&S on instagram for months.
